review_body: Stayed here several times. Can't beat the location being in the middle of Honolulu and near the Ala Moana mall right across the parking lot. Rooms in the Kona tower are usually reserved for kama'aina specials and have queen beds and no view. Rooms in the main tower usually have king beds, better views and are slightly bigger. Kama'aina rates aren't too bad given the location of this Outrigger resort.

Very cosy hotel, just beside Ala Moana Mall. Very convenient if you intend to do shopping. 10 minutes walk to Ala Moana Beach and Waikiki Beach as well. The Kona Tower rooms are the small ones, but even though are nice for solo traveler or couple. This a hotel to consider.

The room was extremely small, the bed was so bad that it left bruises on my back. The springs were poking me in every position. Left a set of headphones behind, security called and was rude and seemed like they did not want to be calling to remind me to pick them up.

This is a very nice hotel with potential for some good views, given its height. The location is directly next to the Ala Moana shopping centre, but a fair walk from the 'down town' of Waikiki. The room was a good size and well appointed, wifi throughout the hotel was fast and very stable. Starbucks in the foyer was a good and quick option for breakfast. The biggest let down was when I needed to do some printing. It was disappointing to be charged to print, but also be charged to use the computers (per minute). All up printing about 7 sheets of A4 cost me about $10.Overall, well located near the shopping centre but I would stay in Waikiki and get a bus to the shopping centre.

clean tidy good amenities and location good pool. we rented a larger apartment room than the standard hotel rooms. Hotel got busy the day we left (Friday) due to conference centre activity. Staff helpful and a short walk to beach and shopping mall.Used by a lot of airlines for their staff stopovers.

On my last business trip I was upgraded to a one bedroom suite with an ocean view. All the rooms have been recently received a much needed upgrade, but this was a first time I stayed in one of their suites. I just wish my trip was longer so I could have enjoyed this fabulous room longer! The hotel is next to the Ala Moana shopping center, park and marina. The hotel staff is attentive, friendly and helpful. They serve a great breakfast buffet and have a popular nightclub in the hotel lobby.

Located in the city, close to dining and shopping. However, our room we stayed in was very dirty. The bed we slept in was disgusting. The comforter had a hole that was covered up with grey duct tape, which was very obvious. Also there were bugs in the kitchen drawers. I would not recommend anyone staying here. Go to The Modern

This motel is attached to the mall, which is great! It's about a 5 min drive to Waikiki beach. It is also a short walk to the Waikiki yacht club. The staff is friendly and there is a Starbucks and gift shop in the lobby. I would definitely stay here again.

I never get tired of the Icon, Ala Moana Hotel. The front staff goes above and beyond, I like the good size rooms, plus the shopping center, walk to beach, and a 10 minute walk to world famous, Waikiki.

We can directly get into Ala Moana center from this hotel.The room is not so wide as a hotel in the US. But it is not so bad, because it is very clean.This hotel is not a type of resort. Ths hotel is located near by Hawaii Convention center so if you have some thing at this center, it would be very convenient.

On check in we didn't get the room with king bed we requested. We did get the partial ocean view. The room had a noisy ac system. Luckily we could turn it off at night. There was a frig and microwave. The microwave barely worked and ended a good cleaning.It was located next to the Ala Moana mall which was nice for food options. It is a very busy hotel. Long waits for an elevator.

The actual room was huge, like most rooms in America ( in fact, Americans have a continent, not a country, so, yes, their rooms are the size of a two bedroom apartment in London- the downsize is that when they travel to Europe, they must feel really claustrophobic!) but the view I had was almost unreal: hundred of boats were aligned outside my view and that image was changing as the sun went down or up.

Recently returned from staying 10 nights at this hotel. Its clean & comfortable but lacks what is expected of a Hotel in this day & age.I'll list both positives & negatives so you can judge for yourself.POSITIVESHad the most comfortable hotel bed ever.Exceptionally clean throughoutHousekeeping staff friendly & efficientPool area clean, with towels available for use outside of hotel.Easy access to Ala Moana ShopsLocated closer to airport & cruise ship dock.Where there's good, there's also not so good;No entertainmentNo Bar on ground floorNo Bar/Drinks available in pool area despite infrastructure in placeNo Room Service availableNo Jug/KettleLack of cutlery/crockery - not so much as a spoon to make tea or coffeeCombination oven had no instructions for useWifi extremely lacking - would drop out every few minutes at bestThe location has both good & bad points - good that you are away from the hustle & bustle of the main Waikiki Beach strip and the closeness to the huge Ala Moana shops. The downside is that its a good 20 min walk to the main beach & popular restaurant areas.If there was a hotel shuttle say once an hour to & from the downtown part this would be a huge incentive.

This was our first time coming to Hawaii but it won't be our last. We're just never going to stay at this hotel ever. 7 days of opening our window to look right into the car park. When they say partial ocean view they mean partial as in seeing an inch of the ocean. Asked if we could be changed and were told to come back twice and then after two days we were told they couldn't. So now we're stuck in the car park for another 5 days. Not happy.

we booked this small studio directly with the owners AAron and Deanna nielsen through Homeaway. We were on our way to Sydney from WA. and stayed 3 nights here for a short break. The unit is small and has a partial view of the ocean. I cannot say how pleased and happy we were with our choice. The unit is immaculate and has everything you can imagine to make your stay comfortable and enjoyable. The keurig coffee and bottled water, to beach chairs, hair dryer even q tips. The bed was so comfortable and the room was exceptionally quiet. The location couldn't be better next to the ala moana center, with countless choices for eating and shopping. The hotel itself is spacious, airy and comfortable with a huge

We enjoyed our stay at the Ala Moana for a number of reasons:1) it was a short distance from Waikiki Beach - therefore less busy, but a quick walk to the shopping, restaurants, beach2) we had a beautiful view of the ocean from our room3) it had a great breakfast restaurant and a Starbucks - super convenient4) it had a supermarket where we could purchase alcohol, fruit, etc. - it literally had everything. We bought an inexpensive cooler, filled it with drinks and snacks purchased here and headed off to the beaches.5) it had great underground parking6) it was connected to the Ala Moana shopping centre - GREAT shopping, restaurants and bars7) the Ala Moana beach was nearby (a very quick walk) and it was a great place to unwind on our first day in Hawaii.8) the price - it was way less expensive than the hotels in WaikikiThe only negative was the WIFI - was very unreliable.

This property is just okay. I feel the room are old looking and the carpet was old and dirty in the room and the hallaway...The bathroom fixture are so old and outdated. The area has alot of homeless individual. You can walk from the second floor to the Mall area. With is super nice and alot of thing to do. The hotel is downtown Waikiki and you can walk to the beachs and the Hawaii shopping center by the Hitlon and many other hotel on Waikiki Beach. Just need a update....the furniture look like something from the 60'a or IKEA.....

While the area around the hotel is not the best, for a tropical island, it is right across from the Hawaii Convention Center.It is also very close to Waikiki beach and a few others.Lobby, parking, pool, workout center and all others were clean and well managed.We ate in only one of their restaurant, the Steak House on floor 36. Nice atmosphere how ever the food was a let down for the price.Rooms were basic, not real fancy but clean and well worth the money for the area.We were happy overall with the hotel, but we wished for a better food offering.

The Ala Moana Hotel is very nice and clean and a great location in downtown Waikiki.Bit pricier for being on the edge of Waikiki and not on the beach but with the right side of the hotel you can have spectacular viewS!

Booked room at a very busy time. Lots of events. Didn't research, my fault. Big indication should have been the room charge per night. Not worth it. Room cramped with 2 beds requested. Barely room to walk around. Lanai a big plus as to not get too claustrophobic in the room. Convenient location, adjacent to shopping center. Stayed in the Waikiki Tower was told larger than Kona tower. Kona tower must be the size of a closet. Front desk staff efficient & friendly. Valet parking convenient w/quick service

I recently spent a week at the Ala Moana during a business trip. The room was attractive and well maintained with a comfy bed. The hotel staff (including valets) were friendly and helpful. I was worried about long waits for the elevator, but never had a problem; even though the hotel seemed to be quite full. The Starbucks in the lobby was an added bonus that made a quick breakfast on my way out the door in the morning a breeze. The property is located next to the Ala Moana Shopping Center and only a short walk or trolley ride from the heart of the Waikiki shopping district. I will definitely stay here the next time I'm in town for business or pleasure.

The wife and I stayed here before joining our cruise on the Pride of America. Very handy to the Ala Moana Center and there is even an access ramp between the two buildings. There is also a Walmart and a Walgreens a short walk away.This was handy for some precruise shopping. The room that we stayed in was on the small side but adequate. We had no complaints about the cleanliness and would definitely stay there again.

We arrived by cab from the airport around 1230pm on Christmas day and since our room wasn't ready yet, we went looking for a restaurant. The adjoining restaurant was closed, leaving only a choice of Starbucks on the main floor or a Chinese Food restaurant on the fourth floor. We opted for the Chinese menu and were very surprised to see how busy it was with local patrons. Turns out we were guests during their daily Dim Sum, and were able to participate in our very first experience with this type of menu. Our room was average, but very expensive non the less, probably because it was the Christmas Season. We were disappointed there wasn't a lounge/bar area. That was the downside. After our two day stay, we met up with our pre-arranged shuttle to drive us to the airport. When it arrived, the driver said to follow him. We walked out of the hotel, down the hill and around the corner to find him parked on the road curbside. (I don't know why he couldn't have parked in the checkin/out part of the hotel.) We stood in disbelief as he shut the doors to the shuttle bus and told us he was full and we'd have to take the next one! Really?? He told us in the hotel lobby to follow him to his parked shuttle!! This really upset me, because I have had a total knee replacement and walking up and down hills is tough. Gracious!! What if we had not decided to get to the airport early for breakfast? We could have missed our flight!

We had the most wonderful time at the Ala Moana Hotel. The room, staff and location were perfect for us. Everything was closeby and convenient. We would definitely recommend the Ala Moana Hotel. It was heaven!

Okay, this place could use a facelift in some areas, but it's a great place to stay in Honolulu, right on the edge of Waikiki, next to the Ala Moana Mall and pretty central to places in the city. The value is in the location and the price, the nice service and the little amenities that make a stay there worthwhile. The valet service (cars) is the best we've ever experienced. The reception staff are efficient and available. There are restaurants in the hotel, the Signature being pretty much world class...with a breath taking view of the city. The rooms are mostly small, just adequate, but the beds are comfy, everything is clean and everything you need is there...coffee maker, little frig, microwave, hair dryer, even an iron (for those who know how to use one or need one). There's a good Starbucks in the lobby. We had a good stay there and would recommend it to anyone who doesn't need a lot of luxury and frills.

While tourists don't visit Hawaii for its shopping, you'll find the fabulous Ala Moana Shopping Center a short walk from this hotel. One of the best food courts I've ever seen with every variety available amid the hustle bustle, especially during the lunch hours! For the fine shopper there are high end stores and for the value-conscious shopper there are all kinds of choices for you. Also, the Japanese Koi swimming lazily by in beautiful ponds throughout the mall. Although the hotel itself is a bit generic in nature (there are typically lots of business or club meetings being held so the lobby is often jammed!), the service is fine and the rooms are okay.

The place is old school 70's style never going to change type hotels. I felt so disconected but it could have been the long flight. I can say my room faced the park across the street and that was nice.

Nice restaurants, helpful workers BUT annoying when keys don't work. Constant trips to the desk when workers always blamed you for what was going wrong. Close to a great shopping center with easy access to museums whale watching.

We have stayed here in the past and my (now) husband and I stayed here with some of our other family member's for our wedding. They upgraded one in our party but not us the bride and groom, they said we could upgrade for a fee. The room had a lot of wear, when we got there the bathroom door wouldn't even close, when it was finally able to it wouldn't open all the way and made a horrible noise. The shampoo provided doesn't condition very well so make sure you bring your own. Kona tower doesn't have a balcony so upgrading to the Waikiki tower is the way to go unfortunately then it defeats the purpose of choosing this hotel (price). Room service was great both times we stayed here.The room was terrible for the wedding party getting ready, the Waikiki tower rooms probably would have been better since they are slightly larger and have the balcony.We left the day after the wedding and moved to ASTON Beach Waikiki, who upgraded up to the 23rd floor and we had an AMAZING view of the ocean for a comparable price as what we paid at Ala Moana.
user_name:
Andrea R
Richfield, Minnesota, United States

review_body: Extremely disappointing hotel. Rooms have not been refurbished for a long time. Bad news since this is a very busy hotel with lots of wear and tear on the rooms. Great proximity to the shopping mall. Would not recommend staying there. Long check in and check out lines. Would never stay there again.

My wife and I stayed at the hotel before,when our trip was delayed and were stranded in Honolulu for a day. ( Not that I don't dislike it..it's Honolulu for crying out loud!) The airline booked us in this hotel for the night. Obviously, airlines use this hotel for their staff.Anyway, our first stay was not extraordinary. It was ok! Not great, just ok! The room was decent , clean and efficient but just plain ordinary. Nothing to blow your mind away and call home to brag about. I assumed that since the airline paid for it, we were given a room just to accommodate us for the delay. Anyway, we went back to Honolulu on our own and we picked the hotel because it was inexpensive-- Honolulu standard!! Besides, if you plan to shop in Honolulu, the hotel was right beside the Ala Moana Center and therefore convenient.It turns out the hotel has two towers. One relatively new and tall and the other old and dilapidated (supposedly refurbished), unobtrusive and shunted at the back. The taller one could probably provide you with good views while the older one does not.We've learned and observed that if you booked the more expensive rates you would get accommodated in the newer, taller tower and be afforded amore pleasant attention from the front desk. I f you happened to book the less expensive rate thinking that you pouched a good deal, you're in for a rude awakening. Get ready for and be accustomed to being treated like a second class citizen. If you asked for assistance from the front desk for anything at all, as soon as they fine out you're billeted in the older "refurbished" back lower-rise tower, their initial pleasant disposition turn to a curt, dismissive and uncooperative one.The front desk desk acts like a back office as if on cue!!! Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde!!! We're never going back again, ever!!!

Just stayed here for a brief couple of nights and although I had a low room with just a view of the mall parking lot from my balcony (But hey, I could have paid more and got a higher room) the wheelchair accessibility of my room was fabulous and what a difference that makes. Full grab bars around the toilet, a sink you can roll under and a mirror low enough to see your face in . Built in seat in the roll in shower close enough to reach the waster controls and shower head. Power assist for that heavy hotel room door and a bed low enough to get in and out of without help. I really appreciate such good amenities for a wheelchair user, the only tough thing inside the hotel was that they have such great carpeting it's tough to roll on. Hard to complain too much about that! So nice to stay somewhere that doesn't entail my spouse having to help me get in and out of bed, on and off the toilet and in and out of the shower. Whoever is responsible for the level of ADA amenities should pat themselves in the back and know that they are much appreciated by the people that need them

Corner room was a view to die for......The room service was not by the hotel itself but by the condo affiliated with Las Vegas corporate office.This room was quite small with a King size bed and 1 lounge chair. Bathrm was of a sufficient size(appropriate for only 2 adults).Good for the convience of Ala Moana Shopping center and nearby Waikiki

it is an older hotel. not inexpensive, but it was a business trip. The foyer is grand with white marble. I didn't find the staff extremely helpful. It seemed they were 'tired' of tourists asking the same questions..but if it is your first time there, it is YOUR first time asking the question (haha). anyway. rooms were clean, not terribly spacious. It is located downtown. walking distance to Ala moana shopping center for those who enjoy shopping. Prices in Hawaii are high. Also food court with a variety of choices for eating. Tip: eat as much Korean food as you can! :)) other's on this trip tove this hotel and stay every time..for me it was just 'good'. Internet struggled. difficult when you are trying to do business.

Decent property, typical pricing for Hawaii - everything is overpriced here. Staff is great. It's an older property but nearly all hotels in the area are old. My only complaint is there is no lounge and the parking rate is ridiculous. With that said I do have issues with any business that wants to charge me to come and spend money with them. Must be a Canadian thing lol.

Very nice hotel, everything you need. If traveling there again I would book my stay there. Our room was clean and quiet and a good view. Walking distance to Ala Moana shopping center with a huge food court. If you love to shop this is the place to go.

Local residents looking for a comfortable and convenient place to stay will find this a super value. Away from the madness of Waikiki, adjacent to Ala Moana Shopping Center and close to many restaurants - location can't be beat and the price is always great. The rooms in the Kona tower are smaller but still meets the basic needs. Stayed in the Waikiki tower during this visit and having a balcony was nice. Appreciated having a fridge & microwave. No resort fee - YAY!! Pool was a bit cold, perhaps it sits in the shade of the building for most of the day? Rooms are always clean and staff very friendly. The only downside is that they hold pretty firm to a 3:00pm checkin - rarely able to check in any earlier though the bell staff will hold your luggage for you.

I was looking for the location, and in that regard it is stellar.Steps to the convention center, and Ala Moana Center and Beach Park.Hotel is a bit dated, but clean and well maintained. .Room was comfortable and fairly quiet.Gorgeous ocean view from the 35th floor.Room was ADA complient, therefore the bathroom was a bit odd ergonomically for someone not requiring those amenities. The shower was about the right height for Frodo.But there is a Starbucks in the lobby.This scores major brownie points in my book.

I love it,run very well,great bar,good food,international crowd,you can buy a condo there..CondoHotel.Stay on the Kona ,mountain side its quiet,Hotel renovated just 2-3 years ago.Front side never ending NOISE!

We had a king room, ocean/city/volcano views, on the 20th floor (there are 36 floors). The room was spacious, very clean and had all amenities to make us comfortable, including microwave and refrig. The staff is great and very helpful. It is right next to the Ala Moana shopping center, where there are lots of shops and restaurants and a huge food court. The hotel is very close to the Waikiki area; you can walk there. It's across the street from a huge park/on the beach. We enjoyed our stay.

Went down for a business trip and found a back curly hair in the tub! Not very clean - given another room, major construction and no view so went back to the original room after they cleaned it. The club is VERY dated, not worth going to - overall the only great experience was Kona, a fantastic concierge at the hotel. The internet was down at the front desk as well as the room. Would not stay here again. Was told not to walk to the beach or outside at night as the area was too dangerous ... yikes!

I booked an ocean view 1 bedroom suite and got mostly a parking lot view of the mall instead because it was on the 13th floor. If you do decide to get a ocean view, don't accept a floor lower than the 20th otherwise it's not worth it. Only the housekeeping staff was friendly. We needed a couple of items the 1st night and the staff was very helpful and came back to give us a forgotten item.Check in staff needs better customer service training. The lines were long at check in and the staff I don't think smiled at all. Quite impersonal. I also witnessed one of the reception staff yell at an Asian tourist who didn't quite understand English to fall in line and was told he should know what "fall in line" means as that is common travel? language. (Service at the DMV in Minnesota is better than that, btw. They MN people are very patient with non-English speakers)Location is good, walking distance to the mall. But that's about it.

The hotel is in a nice location. It is at the edge of Waikiki and is near many buses that take you to different locations. The lobby is nice and quite large and includes a Starbucks coffee shop. I did not experience a very long wait by the front desk when checking in or checking out. When I initially checked into my room, there was visible dirt (possibly sand) on both the sofa-like chair and reclining chair. I called the front desk and within a few minutes, housekeeping came and vacuumed this dirt. Also, I noticed that there was no desk chair and again I called and within a few minutes a desk chair was brought to my room. The hotel provides a free daily newspaper. However, the hotel does not provide a free breakfast. The hotel provides free wifi in your room and the wifi worked well. The hotel has a business center but charges to use the computers in the business center with a minimum $5 charge. I very rarely see hotels charge for use of the business center and recommend that the hotel change their policy and allow free business center use. You can check out and leave your bag by the bell desk and go touring until you need to leave later for the airport. There is no charge for storing the bag by the bell desk until later that day. I would stay at the hotel again.

We stayed there for one night near Christmas. Our room was rather small, with a "view" over the Ala Moana center parking but very quiet and quite comfortable, probably a decent value for this time of the year.

I expected a lot more from this hotel. I've stayed in a lot of hotels for work and leisure and this place was underwhelming for the high price and spoilt our first night in Oahu. I don't usually stay in hotels like this, but I wanted to stay in a nice place before a flight back to Australia but wish I'd found somewhere else. My friend and I are staying here now but instantly wanted to leave after seeing the room. There had been a request for double beds and now we're in a room with a queen bed and I'm sleeping on a sofa bed not even as wide as a single bed. The rooms are tiny so I might as well be sleeping in a hostel, With the bed folded out, there's nowhere to unpack our bags and barely room to move. I've stayed in a lot of hostels and their rooms are even bigger than this room. There's a microwave in the room but no utensils, plates or glasses. I expected a lot more for the price, and enjoyed my stays in much cheaper hotels on the Big Island and Maui much more than this hotel.

I have stayed at the Ala Moana more times than I can count and find it my favorite low-key option near Waikiki. Located next to the huge Ala Moana Mall and near the Ala Moana beach and Magic Island, it is far enough away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki and yet close enough to what you love about Oahu. Some rooms have an ocean view toward Magic Island and others face the mountains and city but all come with a kitchenette which includes a mini-fridge and microwave which is a great way to cut food costs. The rooms were recently refurbished with new carpeting, drapes, chairs and linens and look very clean and modern. A room with a lanai in the front tower is much preferred and a nice way to feel the island breeze and enjoy the fresh air.A lot of convention-goers stay at the hotel because of its proximity to the Center, but it is a good choice for any traveler who would like to feel a little bit more like a local than a tourist.

So many things wrong so let's start with the good. When we finally paid a fortune, we got a king bed with a beautiful view that included a "partial" view of the ocean. The maid was wonderful...and after dealing with security a couple times, they (he) were wonderful. Although I am not a fan of Starbucks, the baristas in the lobby Starbucks were so welcoming at 6 am each morning and the coffee was great.What was wrong? Let's start with the room. If you get a bargain price - it's no bargain. Queen bed maybe, but when the room is only slightly bigger than the bed and the only window overlooks a roof with cooling units, it's not a dream location for a week. After upgrading an Expedia reservation at a cost that would have gotten us in a Hyatt Regency room overlooking Waikiki, we had a king bed with a kitchenette. Terrific right? Not exactly. We picked up dinner and brought it back to the room only to discover that there were no kitchen utensils or silverware....or even a plate to eat off. A quick call to the front desk cleared that up - silverware and plates are an extra $25 to rent. Serious? If you're not too sympathetic because we ARE in Hawaii for the week, after all, it gets much worse. I won't bore you with the details except to say I have never been told "no" more times by hotel management. We spent cumulative hours going between the lobby and 26th floor only half dressed from the beach, trying to get a room key that worked. Each time, facing the same staff, but nonetheless having to wait for security to escort us to our room to confirm our identity. Do yourself a big favor and STAY SOMEWHERE ELSE! Get yourself a king room at the Hyatt (or the like) where you're not cattle and really relax. Note that ALL the airlines are contracted with Ala Moana. Hang out in the lobby and you are guaranteed to see you flight crew. The airlines don't contract for the best experience. It's all about $$. And if you still think you're ready to take on the Ala Moana jungle, at least do yourself the favor of bringing a real pillow, because anything you get at Walmart for under $2 will be better than the house pillow - even a wadded up wet swimsuit.

For the past few decades we have stayed at the Ramada Plaza Hotel (creatures of habit) and we would occupy 1 of their 2 suites. On this recent trip to Honolulu the Ramada totally messed up our room booking, so it was with trepidation that we were booking elsewhere. We took a punt on the Ala Moana Hotel (a mountain view suite).Thankfully it was a VERY positive experience. Our flight from Australia arrived early (6.05 am) so we were at Ala Moana by 7.30. Instead of the usual 2.00 check in, they were helpful and we were in a few hours later. The suite clean, 2 huge door size windows in the lounge room -so nice to have big windows that OPEN. A comfortable double bed, and a secondary fold out couch bed if needed, TWO fridges and the lounge area a slide door in case someone wants to sleep etc in the bedroom. A small balcony (with table/chairs) in the bedroom. The location, a sky bridge links the hotel to the Ala Moana shopping centre; we had 8 bags of mail so luxury to walk across it to the Ala Moana post office. (It links directly in front of Macy's dept store for those wishing to shop). Possibly the best house keeping staff we've EVER dealt with. Noises- city noises but the hotel itself was quiet. The pool (level 3) clean, lots of space if you want privacy. One set of traffic lights and Ala Moana Beach Park is a 2-3 minute walk (also Magic Island). After several decades the Ramada Plaza Hotel has lost us, in a few months we will be back at Ala Moana Hotel. Check out was efficient and a taxi was waiting for us.

While not being overly impressed with the front desk staff at differing times of the day, including answering phone calls from the room; my stay was otherwise a good one. The room has had some appeasing updates in furnishings. You'll find a half-size refrigerator and microwave, two ceramic coffee mugs with a drip-filter, but no utensils or dishes. I found the room impeccably clean ~ and the room attendants in the hallways were delightful. (as were the attendants in the Starbucks downstairs - a REAL Starbucks people!) The patio, was not overly sized but comfortably seats 2 to enjoy the views and the breeze. The proximity to the beach is not ideal, but the pay off is the Mall being so close.Overall, I really like this hotel ... if only their front desk service staff can get it together.Oh ... one thing I might add, being further away from the heart of Waikiki, the city noises from outside seemed marginally less here. * there's shampoo, but no conditioner ... but they do have a shoe shine sponge! :D

I love going to Honolulu because for us islanders from another island, shopping on Oahu is a MUST. Staying at the Ala Moana Hotel is one of the best places to store all of the things you buy at the Ala Moana Shopping Center. Going to and from the shopping center to your room couldn't be easier ~ just a quick walk across the parking lot! Just Google the Ala Moana Shopping Center, and you will know why I love it!The Ala Moana Hotel is also close to "everything else" Honolulu has to offer! The hotel rooms are modern in design, and consistent in finishes. The hotel is not outlandish, and the employees are always very courteous.

This hotel was fantastic! Perfect location! Everything you could ever want within walking distance! Great price too! Lovely rooms & view if you choose the ocean view and stay in Waikiki Tower! There are two Ala Moana Hotel towers and we chose the Waikiki tower due to reviews on trip advisor! Now I am happy to add to the reviews & say that we are so thankful for previous travellers advice! We chose an ocean view room & it was fantastic! The view from our balcony was beautiful, not as spectacular as we had hoped, but still beautiful. The room was lovely beachy colours, and was nice & clean. Whoever was servicing our rooms each day was amazing! Thank you! We stayed on the 29th floor and we loved it! This hotel is located right next to the Ala Moana Shopping centre which is a massive shopping complex! There is also a Starbucks in the lobby, along with a convenience store, a massage place, & a couple restaurants. There is also free wifi with excellent connection! Some of the staff were very friendly & helpful, others were not. Overall, we were very happy & will definitely be staying again! Thank you! Mahalo!

Stayed here for a night during Anime Matsuri in Hawaii. Lots of space for laying out my costumes and whatnot along with ample counter space for my friend and I to put on our makeup.The location is great because it's so close to the convention center and Ala Moana shopping center.

Had a not so fun experience to start, as when we arrived, we were told that there was no reservation for us. Even though Booking.com said we were confirmed. A rather lengthy discussion issued between all parties (booking.com blames the hotel and the hotel blames booking.com). We were eventually able to stay for a few days, but had to find a second hotel for the rest of our stay. Booking.com was helpful in getting us the second hotel. Supposedly we were the 3rd booking.com issue that day with that hotel. When all was said and done, they did find us a room (at first said they were completely sold out). Was a rather nice hotel. LOVED, and I mean LOVED the bed and pillows. Wish I could have taken it home with me ;). Was great that it was beside the mall (boy that mall is huge!), so lots of shopping and food options close by. Not a lot else around there though. Could walk to the "beach" there, but was pretty rocky. We still found places to explore though. I heard it is about a 20 min walk to Waikiki, but just took a taxi instead ($11 I think). Would stay again, but would find a different way to book it. Oh, and wifi was a bit spotty. Had wifi in our room, lobby and pool which was nice.

The hotel is fairl central the yacht clubs and park are across the street.Not as hectic as Wakiki but still busy. We stayed a night until the condo we rented was ready. The room we had was fresh and clean

This is a great place to stay in Waikiki for a family looking to get a decent price at a nice hotel. It is clean, service is good and the mall is right outside the back entrance. Since on the same trip we moved to the Marriott Resort on Waikiki for a 4 day short stay after two weeks at the Ala Moana (had to extend stay unexpectedly), I can honestly say the accommodations at the Ala Moana are equivalent to the nicer, more expensive hotel. Though it is not "IN" Waikiki, it is only a few blocks off the main drag and one can easily walk or catch a bus to go to all the fancy Waikiki Hotels and enjoy their beaches. I stayed here with my husband, daughter and 4 grandchildren and everyone enjoyed the pool, several restaurants, and gift shops. You get everything here that you get in a more expensive Waikiki hotel except for the beach. However, the really nice beaches in Oahu aren't in Waikiki anyway. You have to go to places like North Shore Turtle Bay, Waimea, Makapuu lighthouse, and Lanikai. They are within 30 to 60 minutes of driving (without traffic) and you will get the real feel of Hawaii.

We stayed at this hotel from 12/21 to 12/27. Overall the hotel is good. We enjoyed it.During our stay, there were also hundreds Secret Service agents staying at the hotel. We can see them on shift changes. President Obama was on the same island during that time on vacation.

Horrible Christmas Vacation, Was given a 1 bedroom when I paid for a 2 bedroom as shown in picture when booking, the front desk manager said everything was booked and she had no where else to put me and they been having this problem with third parties booking and there not getting what they paid for. Told me I could find another hotel which I felt was very rude how can I find another spot on Christmas Eve ? Then said she couldn't do a refund and I have to go through the third party for that because that's who I paid when booking. Then said we can't do anything not even something complimentary which was horrible because that just showed they don't even care all they want is your money. They could at least gave a complimentary free stay for next time doesn't matter if it's going through a third party it's the simple fact that you want good service then give good service if someone else is making you look bad don't be just as bad as them and act like you don't care that's bad business and that makes me not want to attend to that hotel again because of the service I received on Christmas Eve.

We chose this hotel out of necessity as others were booked for the periods we wanted over the Xmas/New Year period. It was touted as THE hotel to stay at to enjoy the shopping at the Ala Moana shopping mall. True. The shops are extensive although we didn't find too many bargains. If raining, we would have got very wet getting to and from. Lots of eating places. One Jap bar on Level 4 has $1 happy hour beers each afternoon from 5.50 for several hours - that was a find. We also found a great Italian/pizza place on L4.The hotel itself was disappointing, particularly the staff. The check-in check-out experiences were curt and it felt as though we were doing them a favour. When we checked in, we were given no advice about facilities or shops available in the hotel and we had to find those out for ourselves (like a shop that sells general food items, gifts, drinks and liquor). We were staggered for a hotel of this size that there was not a single thing in the mini bar (not even water), no room service, nor any on-site eatery for lunch or dinner (only for breakfast which was very good, friendly with generous buffet selections).When we eventually did spend a day at Waikiki Beach, we noted there were endless shopping areas right along the beach strip so there was no need to stay at Ala Moana to enjoy good shopping. We would never stay at this hotel again and would not recommend it to others unless you were looking for a cheap rate and could get it.

Bed was very uncomfortable, and so full of 20 years of accrued dust mites that I had asthma all night. The bed was so dated it even had a bed skirt! Seriously, a frilly bed skirt in 2015! Lines to check in were ridiculous - over an hour waiting to check in. Hotel advertised the "all new" "renovated" Ala Moana -- misleading, false advertising - their website seems to have removed this false claim now.I won't try to save money by going to this "hotel" ever again.Higher price rooms may have a view and be renovated - but why not just go to a better hotel in the first place. Was told renovation is up to individual "owners" & they can't require them to update their rooms - soif you're willing to take a chance on a cheap owner, then take your chances with the Ala Moana - its a gamble.

This hotel is an excellent choice for a pre-cruise. It is located right next to the mall which is an easy walk from the hotel. It is right around the corner from the pier 2 where our cruise line, Pride of America, embarked. The mall has many eating establishments to meet any budget. I would recommend this hotel for any budget-minded traveler. The rooms were spacious and very clean. Felt very secure in building needing key card to use elevator. The view from our balcony was absolutely amazing seeing the ocean and watching the sun setting. There was also a place to leave luggage after checkout to do any tours. The personnel were pleasant and very helpful with any questions.

This is our must stay hotel when in Honolulu. The location is perfect. Next to Ala Moana Mall, where there are great restaurants and shopping, if that's your thing. There is Ala Moana Beach across the street, which has places to run, walk, lay on the beach, and great place to swim. The hotel service is great. This time the great new upgrades are the automatic doors leading to the ramp to the mall and the new Starbucks in the lobby, we can go down for a quick cup of coffee.

Room was clean and we had an excellent view of Ala moana park and beach. The location was good as we was close to the beach and shopping center.Was disappointed we had no tea making facilities or any cutlery. There was a coffee maker but that didnt work so we had to provide our own tea bags and boil our water in the microwave. There was no WIFI in our room as promised because the room was privately owned we could not get much help off the hotel staff. Could not work out how to use the showers there was only one setting hot. Wasnt worth the money we payed for it. Recommend if you book any hotels make sure they are not privately owned as you do not gt any help.

If you get a room with a single bed it is a bit cramped but the double bed rooms are perfect. Hotel is close to the beach and mall which allows you to purchase anything you might have forgotten. Plenty of food options. Clean hotel. The front desk and staff are extremely helpful and friendly. I don't think there is anything extraordinary about this hotelbut nothing glaringly awful. If you're looking for something affordable, that will provide you with what is necessary and nothing extra this is the place for you.

My wife had work in Oahu so we stayed here. My wife had been here before and it did not disappoint on most fronts. The valet service was bang on, and waiting for your vehicle was almost non existent. They were always pleasant and always assisted with the babies (never asked, they just did it). The front desk staff were very friendly and always making suggestions on where to go, and what to do. The rooms were very clean and spacious, and the lanai overlooked the outdoor pool area, with great side views of the ocean. Our room was 614.I would say the only complaint I had was the breakfast buffet. For what you got, I found it to be a bit over priced and the food wasn't terrific by any means. I had poached eggs with a mushroom sauce. As I am eating, I bite down on something hard. I pulled out what seemed to be plastic. I did notify the server and she took it straight back into the kitchen. She returns to tell me they cook eggs in the same pan as the sauce and it is just egg that hardened. I have my doubts, as I am a chef and my judgement says it was plastic. I didn't have breakfast there again.

Do not get the room by the elevator.....6 elevators buzzing, cables clanking....starts about 5:00 AM.Also the wi-fi is poor......the desk gave us instructions to connect with a PC...not an Apple product. It took 20 minutes with their tech line to get any answer. The female manager was NO help at all and was not interested in our problems.

Stayed for a conference at the nearby Convention Center, and subsequent holiday. Somehow ended up with around 4 separate bookings for various periods so had to call (from the UK) at least twice to sort it out after a confused chain of emails. Eventually sorted but by that time only a slightly higher rate available, which wasn't a great start.Luckily once there the hotel was generally very good value for the great location. Close to the large Ala Moana shopping mall which has a food court and good restaurants, so you don't necessarily have to walk to Waikiki. If you do, it's about 20-25 minutes away on foot, but there are plenty of buses. Nice rooftop pool on the third floor above the Lobby but a little small for the size of the hotel and not enough shade or parasols. But proximity to a relatively quiet beach makes this less of a problem.We stayed in the Kona Tower, which has limited views compared to the main tower, so request a room there if possible. The room itself was large enough with a comfortable bed, plenty of wardrobe space, a good sized fridge and desk space.On at least two nights we had power cuts caused by flooding elsewhere on the island, which affected the downtown grid, but not the Waikiki grid. The longest was around 5-6 hours. The staff dealt with the situation well and did their best despite some very angry guests and obviously not being able to do much themselves.Breakfast was available but a little too expensive considering there was plenty of cheaper choices nearby and a Starbucks within the hotel. There is also a small shop selling a good range of snacks and drinks, with souvenirs, though obviously at a bit of a premium.Overall a very good hotel, particularly if you need to be near the Convention Center rather than in Waikiki itself.

We chose this because it was central and close to the shopping. Since we were only here one night, and didn't really want the hustle and bustle of Waikiki this time. The hotel is fairly new compared with a lot at Waikiki, and has excellent restaurant in house. Rooms comfortable and clean.

The Ala Moana Hotel is the ideal location for a shopper. It's just steps away from Macy's, Bloomingdales, Nordstrom, and so many other shops. The hotel itself is very clean and pleasant. Staff are courteous and helpful.

i was invited to a company Christmas party at the Garden Lanai Room at the Ala Moana Hotel. There were about 100 guests at this event. Always enjoy coming to this hotel for banquets. Atmosphere and general set up always makes me feel comfortable, but this visit was exceptional. The food was excellent and was very well presented with the Holiday Season motif. The one thing that always impresses me with a dinner buffet is how the cooked vegetable dish is prepared. Most times the cooked vegetables are overcooked and "soggy." The vegetable medley of squash, carrots, broccoli, and onions were perfectly cooked when served. Served hot but still maintained the fresh "crunchy: texture. Service was excellent, Banquet service was always around to meet our requests. The waitress on our table was very personable and met our needs before even being asked. Desserts (red velvet cake, pumpkin cheesecake, bread pudding, pecan pie, pumpkin pie, an d chocolate cake) were well presented and very tasty. According to the staff, most of the desserts are baked in-house. Overall, the taste of the food, the presentation of the salads, entrees, and desserts, the service, the general appearance and the atmosphere of the room, made the experience a very special evening. Another observation was that the guests loved the food and desserts by the multiple times that they returned for more food and desserts. (Just happened to be sitting close to the buffet line and guests passed table to the start of the line). My wife wanted to add that she loved the potato salad. Everyone on our table agreed that there was something special about the way this salad was prepared.

I stopped in at the Ala Moana for five nights on the way home to Sydney after some time in New York. I chose it primarily based on price and because it was near the Ala Moana shops. It met expectations on both of those counts. Pros:- it is close to the Ala Moana shops, you really could not stay any closer- there are a range of food outlets and ABC shops in easy walking distance- it is close to bus stops for getting around Waikiki- the room I had was fine - good shower, good bed, clean enough. It looked like it had been freshly painted Cons:- it is not close to the main part of Waikiki; it's a good 20-30 minute walk, or 10 minute cab ride- the neighbourhood around the area is not particularly nice. There are a few strip clubs and seedy looking dive bars around - despite its massive size, it doesn't offer room service - I didn't find it practical to walk to the beach; too far and too much hassle. The hotel obviously serves a lot of airlines, you could see a lot of them around the place. So it is serviceable, but economical. Staying here made me realise that next time I come to Hawaii, I'll stay near the main part of Waikiki. I'd rather be able to walk to the beach and then get a bus to the shops than vice versa. All up it was an ok stay. Shopping was good, and there are some good restaurants in the Ala Moana Centre.

The location of the Ala Moana is it's greatest asset. I thought I could get along without a car, but I injured my achiles heel and even the block walk to the Convention Center was painful. I rented a car and found parking more convenient than I imagined, the parking fees are for 24 hours and you can go in an out with ease. The hotel has a deep, salt water pool which is not attractive to small kids, but makes a great place for the flight attendants who stay here to sunbathe. the hotel is in good shape, much of it newly remodeled. Very urban and upscale. The rooms are tiny and the balconies scary. The ceilings are low and my 6'5" friend had to duck the smoke alarms and felt cramped.I do recommend the hotel for conventions or shopping. If you're here for the beach stay closer to the shore or further south. If you're here for vacation try to spend a couple days on less crowded parts of the island, or other islands. Ala Moana is not a romantic hotel, it's very business like. I booked through a third party and saved a lot but also didn't get the maid service or amenities other guests got.It's a short walk to nice restaraunts and the Honolulu Coffee Company so you don't have to drink the Starbucks over roasted french roast coffee in the lobby. The local shopping center is upscale, high retail, but six blocks away is a walmart. Waikiki is a small Asian city now, and there are good cultural opportunities, lots of sushi and Asian food places. Diners and Drive ins are suspect, we got rare hamburger at one of the recommended places, seems everyone relates to uncooked food, even beef.You can probably tell I'm not an urban type, the rustic countryside is more to my liking, but if you're here on business the Ala Moana is a convenient choice. My room was neat and clean and the fitness center was big. Most of the airlines put their flight crews here, so they're a good resources for tourist information.Note, it's a $34 cab ride to the airport, $12 on the shuttle but you often have to wait a long time, or $2.50 on the bus which is quite fast, but they don't allow suitcases or big duffels. Everyone tells you you can't take pineapple home in your suitcase because of agriculture requirements, but you can. But not papaya. If you do nothing else, go snorkeling at least once.

Recently stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel in Waikiki. The location is great for visiting Waikiki. The hotel is on the end of the beach area and next to the mall of the same name. The rooms are a bit dated but the rate is reasonable for the area. It was convienient for us as we were taking a cruise out of the port which is close by.

Recently stayed on the Ala Moana hotel early December 2015 and it was good but not great especially for the price. Great lobby and all the looks of a luxury hotel however, wi-fi is very weak you better off using your own plan. The essentials (soap, shampoo) were tiny not something you would expect. If this is your only option its not bad...but xould be better.

Perfect hotel to shop at the mall.Two choices of rooms-partial water view with street noise or mountain view with mall noise. Decent fitness center with sauna, no cold water and no TV, small pool with view of Macy's parking lot. Clean rooms with fridge, microwave and coffee maker. New Starbucks in lobby. Steak restaurant on the top floor,Club/dance by lobby. Several Chinese and Japanese restaurants in hotel.Large gift and food store.Long walk to Waikiki. Lobby reception has friendly, courteous check in and and activities staff.

Actually, it is not just the centerpoint for shopping but also for dining, parks and practically for everything. I am not very sure about the rating of this hotel but for me personally I would rate it high, How about 4-5 stars. Upon your arrival, you get the warmest aloha welcome basically from all personnel starting in the lobby area. And when you get to your room and they happened to assign you to an ocean view then your stay in Honolulu, HI is made. You don't really have to go out to eat outside because they can always serve you the specialties of the house through their wonderful room service.

This was a return trip to the Ala Moana Hotel after visiting about three years ago. If you're not looking for the upbeat Waikiki lifestyle, then this hotel is an excellent choice. It is within walking distance of Waikiki but is much closer to the retail heart of Honolulu. In fact there is a walkway on the second level that leads directly to the carpark of the Ala Moana shopping mall, the largest mall in Hawaii with a huge food court, a wide range of restaurants and shopping heaven for those who like such things.The rooms have free WiFi which works surprisingly well and is reasonably fast.Service is fast and efficient and the rooms, while slightly dated, are comfortable and every room has an open air balcony which is a great place to relax and enjoy the cool evening air. There is also a pool, fitness centre and sauna. Downstairs as well as a gift shop, is a small shop selling food, snacks and alcohol at quite reasonable prices.Breakfasts were excellent with plenty of hot foods as well as breads, cereals and fruit. As holiday makers we found that after a big breakfast we didn't really want to eat again until late afternoon or early evening. There are two sets of food selections that alternate each morning.Our only problem was in the room we reserved when we booked by phone. Because one of us has balance and mobility problems we could not use a standard room that has a shower head over the bath. Therefore we had to book a disability or ADA room. When booking, we were advised that there were no ADA rooms in the Kona Tower (the cheaper part of the hotel) and we had to book one in a dearer tower. This we did and it was confirmed by email. However when we arrived, we were advised there were no ADA rooms available apart from one in the Kona Tower. We accepted this but when we asked for the rate to be reduced back to the Kona Tower level we were told that reception staff could change almost anything except for the rate on their computers from the original booking. Not a good start to our stay.Apart from that, it was an excellent stay in a very good hotel.

Given the many choices in Honolulu, I was surprised that my company chose this hotel to board us for a conference. When I checked into the hotel, the first thing they told me was that my room had a partial ocean view. Naturally, I was excited to get up to my room to see the beautiful view.When I entered my room, I truly felt I had been transported back to the 90s. The room was this cheesy aqua color and was incredibly small. My "ocean view" was a parking lot. The room itself was subpar. My pillow had a hole in it and the shower head was half blocked. My friends were also staying in the hotel and they had brought their infant daughter. I found it incredibly disappointing that they gave my friend a broken crib.Being in Hawaii, you would think the pool would be amazing. Not only did they not have any type of bar at the pool (alcohol not allowed), but the pool was about as underwhelming as a motel pool.Another quick tip- the hotel won't tell you, but technically your room key doubles as a Macy's discount card. It would have been nice to know that before I spent $200 there..Needless to say, if I ever visit Honolulu, I don't think this would be my first choice.

Maybe you are part of an airline flight crew. Maybe you LOVE malls. Maybe you have work in the immediate vicinity and need to walk (my case). Maybe you are very price sensitive. The Ala Moana was one of the first big hotels built in Honolulu. Since then, it has been surpassed except in the cases above. The rooms are small but sufficient. Very ordinary appointments. The soap smells like formaldehyde, so bring or buy your own. The price, however, for Honolulu, makes up for that. The value is certainly there, for this city.But you are a long way from Waikiki. In many ways. Also, to walk to the Ala Moana park beach or the Magic Island beach, it takes about 15-20 minutes. Waikiki is about a 20-25 minute walk. On the plus side, you are 5 minutes from the Ala Moana mall, which is expansive and interesting. But, only the Japanese actually buy much there. Not a bargain mall, by any means.They have added a Starbucks in the lobby. Also, the pool is just fine. The gym is actually excellent, and quite well utilized. They have 3 restaurants on property, but I did not try any of them.The neighborhood, besides the mall, is sketchy. Lots of girly clubs. I did not feel a safety issue though, even walking in the late evenings.So, it is a functional and affordable hotel. So ask yourself, why are you in Hawaii?

The old classic Hawaiian hotel. Still has the old mid century modern feel. Good service, old rooms, but that's fine, it's a classic. Good location to be wlking distance from Honolulu, but not in the middle of the city. Good food, easy access to the Convention Center.

Seems that my wife has stayed here several time when I wasn't with her but in the 17 years I've lived on Maui & came to Oahu, I had not. It is a nice hotel, clean and quiet, rooms on the smallish side but that's not abnormal for the area. I did notice the lighting in the microwave/coffee make area was poor. No real light except from the entry or the bedroom area. Also thought it quite odd that there was no exhaust fan in the bathroom (steamy mirror after showers). The lobby bar seems to think they are in LA as they require long pants on the guys or you cannot get in. Hey! It's Hawaii!No resort fee. $20/day self park. Very convenient to the restaurants at Ala Moana Shopping Center.

The Ala Moana hotel is right next door to the Ala Moana Shopping center....just walk over a foot bridge and you are there!! There is a Chinese restaurant on site and....a Starbucks!!!! Brand new carpeting as of this writing. I stayed in a King suite which had a full kitchen (small but very serviceable) stove, refrigerator, microwave, and even a dishwasher!Stay on a high floor or traffic noise may be a problem...especially if on the lanai. However, the sliding lanai doors do a good job of blocking the noise.If you are interested in the Waikiki scene and being in the middle of it...this is not the hotel for you. Although you can take a taxi, bus or other transportation. Waikiki really is just a few blocks away...but too much for an old lady like me to walk! :-)Ala Moana Beach Park is just across the street!!

Recently returned from a convention and stayed at the hotel. We booked through United Vacation for air and hotel combo but BEWARE (we did not know this when we booked) the tickets on UA are NOT upgradeable unlike if you book through BJ or Costco vacation. Anyway, it turned out to be a good choice for hotel because of the proximity to the convention center. I walked everyday instead of waiting for the shuttle if we had stayed at the headquarter/official hotel 1.5 miles away. Check it was a breeze and our room was in the Kona tower with partial view of the ocean. The room is small but clean, average bedding.There is a small fridge, and coffee maker with awful Kona blend coffee. For better coffee, Starbucks is in the lobby and this one has a Clover machine, so make sure you ask for the Clover machine for your coffee. Bathroom is small but clean and they replenish supplies daily. There is an ice machine on the floor. I suggest you take the Kona Tower elevator since it is less crowded during peak hours and it is shorter walk from the side entrance. There is a pedestrian bridge connecting the hotel to Ala Moana Center Parking lot and you can walk into the Mall from there. Ala Moana Park is right across from the hotel and you can catch a bus to go to Waikiki Beach or to Iolani Palace. Bus fare is 2.50 exact change and very comfortable and air conditioned. The hotel also has a swimming pool but I did not use it. Free wifi is included with our package. Usually you have to pay extra. They have restaurant for brunch and a Chinese restaurant with great dim sum.

I stayed one night on a recent business trip. Clean rooms with new bedding and carpet since my last visit. Located next to Ala Moana Mall. New Starbucks in the lobby & friendly customer service at check in & at both hotel gift shops. Walking distance to Marina, Hilton Hawaiian Village & Waikiki Beach

We stay regularly at the Ala Moana Hotel when we visit Family on Oahu. It's always clean and comfortable and the desk moves people through pretty quickly. The hotel is situated next to the Ala Moana shopping Center so it is conveniently located to shops, restaurants, and the food court. Waikiki is in walking distant or you can take the Trolley that stops out front. The Lobby is large and comfortable furnished and contains 2 curio shops and a wonderful market for drinks and snacks. There is also a Japanese restaurant Yozo on the Lobby floor with delicious curry and cha. The Hotel is great for small Conventions also with a floor dedicated to conference rooms and break out rooms, and the Convention Center itself is just across the street. Ala Moana is an old standby but they have kept up their looks!

This place has no concept of taking care of customers. Not only do the rooms need renovation, everything in the room is cheap and low quality.I am working a convention and needed to extend the stay by one day. They will not confirm it on the spot but ask you to call the day you are supposed to check out. That makes no sense. I am glad to be checking into another hotel for my last night in Honolulu.Next, the A/C has a high pitched squeal rattle when it is on. Maintenance came and said it was normal when running on high. Really? It was. It even running on high so then he said it was a normal noise on medium....I will get no sleep listening to that all night. He did not even try to improve it.Don't bother with this dump unless you like being treated poorly.

We chose this hotel because it was the cheapest option and it was still relatively close to everything. The mall is just right outside, the walk to the beach is maybe 15 minutes or so, and there are tours that pick up from here. We got there really early and tried to check in early but unfortunately they were fully booked during our stay. But they did have a bag holding area and once it was time for check in, the process was smooth and getting to our hotel was easy. Our room was nice and clean. We got a view of the car lot which was too bad, but considering how much we paid for it, we were pretty happy. There's also a microwave and a fridge. Downstairs, there's a tour desk and we booked our tours with them. He was extremely helpful and picked the best tours for us! Overall, nice place!

Located next door to the Ala Moana Mall. Ample self parking, clean modern room/ bathroom, decent ocean view, quiet, fridge, microwave, coffee maker, and close distance to nightlife, restaurants and other amenities.

This hotel is relatively cheap compared to the other ones in Honolulu. This might be because it is a bit further away from Waikiki. However for people who want to go to the beach the Ala Moana beach is within several minutes walk. Also the shopping mall is within walking distance.The rooms were spacious and clean and it had a big comfortable bed.The only negative thing I encountered was, that the walls aren't that think. Once I could hear the neighbours talking.

we got out of taxi from cruise ship the bell just looked at us . didn't offer to grab our bags . we carried our bags to reception . it was 10 am and we arranged early checkin. guess what lady was rude said come back at 1. checked bags went shopping come back told nope try 3pm but there will be a big line . asked to transfer booking to another outrigger she laughed and said no. come back at 4 we waited in line for 40 minutes . what a joke . do not book at this place trust me go somewhere else . when we checked out we dealt with our own bags tipped the taxi more

...........Stayed only for couple nights and really enjoyed it! ......Room was clean and comfortable! .......Liked that it had a microwave and wifi!! View was okay! ....Staff was great and helpful! ....Location seem good, close to everything!

We stayed at this hotel while attending a convention. The hotel was clean and updated. The pool area was nice with plenty of chairs and shaded area. You can pick up a pool towel at the pool. It's a great location if you like to shop. Waikiki beach is within walking distance. The closest beach is Ala Moana Park. It was great to have Starbucks in the lobbey.

Very nice high rise hotel and perfect if you have business at the Convention Center since it is a couple minutes walk from the hotel. Surprised there was not room service in such a huge hotel but they had just opened a brand new (huge) Starbucks in the lobby and the fine dining restaurant on the top floor was great. Rooms had a newness to them and every room has a balcony. All-in-all a good stay

I have stayed here many times in the past. It seems to have lost some of the "aloha" spirit for which this hotel was well known. Staff are not very friendly. Location is awesome adjacent to the Ala Moana Shopping Center but that's about it. Room I had in Waikiki Tower was very average, in need of upgrading very soon. $25 for self parking in the underground parking lot was outrageous.

The room was nice and comfortable. The staff was very friendly and attended to your needs. I booked a visit to the spa in the hotel and it was the best massage I have ever had. Very nice restaurant in the hotel for a good hot breakfast to start your day. The shopping mall was right next door and has great places to eat plus a lot of different stores to shop at.

I thought the rooms would have been better. Our bathtub, had a hard time to shower the water was up my ankle when i was try to bath. Also no hot water in the morning to shower. I think i would have been better at Pagoda.

The lobby and my room were recently renovated. Just opened: a new Starbucks that helps make the lobby a pleasant place to sit.Two key things to understand:1. This is a mid-price hotel, not a luxury hotel. It is roughly comparable to Holiday Inn, but with features that are sometimes higher end and sometimes more budget-like. For example, it has valet parking, but also a coin-op laundry. It has a nightclub but not a full service restaurant. It has breakfast with waiters that costs about $17, but it is only a buffet that is no better than the free breakfast at a chain motel. The bellboy will whistle for a taxi, but the front desk gives you a page of info on city buses.2. It is located close to a mall and the convention center. Anything else is a bit of walk, or a ride, to get there. For example, a 15 minute walk to Waikiki beach, Ala Moana beach, or breakfast places.If those two things (price point and location) are ok, then you will be happy. However, if you really want a luxury hotel on Waikiki at a budget price, it isn't so. I mention this because some reviewers who complain seem to expect it to be something it isn't.Guests are a mixture of vacationing Americans (mostly without children, but some with), convention-center goers with name tags, and airline crews from Asian countries. Also, the building is partly 2 BR condominiums and partly hotel -- I never noticed the condo owners, actually.Overall I was quite satisfied. Nothing was exceptional, but it was quite reasonable given the price and location.

This is a review of the restaurant endorsed by the hotel and located on the top floor of the hotel: Well, we were there for good three-and-a-half hours earlier tonight... Started around happy hour and left not long before closing. The food and drinks were great, though expensive; the happy hour pricing early on helped to temper the blow, but we left several hundred dollars at the place.We had one of the best waiters I've ever had... and I get around. There were 7 of us, plus a two year old, all somewhat scatter-brained, hungry, and thirsty. He handled it all with class, promptly, patiently, and politely.So, what's wrong with the place? It's the floor manager. The tall fellow who may greet you when you come in. Turns out, he is enough of a *** to make it worth my while to write this review to warn you about the place. Simply put, he is unpleasant, unprofessional, and as far as I can tell a racist of some sort.One of us, a great semi-professional jazz pianist, with permission from a waiter and once we were just about the only guests in the place sat down behind the piano and started playing some light jazz tunes. He is good! Waiters were appreciatively turning around to see who is playing (their two regular pianists are very pedestrian...). We just paid the bills and were about to go home. Then the manager fellow comes up to the piano, abruptly tells my friend to stop, and then gets in his face about guests not being allowed to play. Really??? A restaurant manager getting in the face of a guest with no reason or provocation whatsoever. And when I got up to diffuse the situation, the fellow threatens to call security and kick us out. Never happened to me before. Truly beyond unbelievable.The bottom line: Stay away from the place until they post in big bold letters that they have fired the guy! And for now, I'm disputing the restaurant charge on my CC as the incident has made the whole experience worth nothing at all.

We stayed here our last night in Hawaii after a week on the Northshore. The place is off the chain in "super nice" really..over the top. We stayed in a suite on the 26th floor overlooking Dimond Head. There is something about a five star hotel with moon shining off the ocean in Hawaii that drives the little woman Crazy!! (wink,wink) the beds are amazing but we didn't get much sleep. Slept on the plane home with a big ol stupid smile though. Would I go again? Can we leave today?

Great hotel with ocean view. Bed was comfy and there was a pull out couch for extra guests. The mall is within walking distance with many places to eat and drink. I just stayed one night after a long night of dancing at Rumors club downstairs.

I spent just two nights in Honolulu before cruising home to Sydney, Australia. It was therefore predominantly a shopping trip to take advantage of the great prices on goods that cost so much more in Australia.The hotel was clean, the bed was comfortable, and the AC worked really well. Reception and bell staff were very friendly and helpful. The lobby store had a good range of inexpensive, fresh breakfast items, coffee, sushi, sandwiches, etc that helped to keep costs down. The location for shopping was excellent. A walk up to the second floor took you to a ramp that was about 200m through the Ala Moana shopping centre carpark. You were then at Macy's and all the other stores in this massive mall. A 10 minute walk, and you were at the Ward Center for a variety of discount stores such as Ross Dress for Less, TJ Maxx, and Famous Footwear.I was extremely happy with my stay at Ala Moana Hotel, and would happily stay there again.

The hotel is attached to the Ala Moana shopping center, which means Macy's, Starbucks, and a variety of restaurants and shops are just steps away. It is also located one block from the Hawaii Convention Center, so it's super easy for convention goers. The hotel itself is fine. It's nothing elaborate or fancy, but it's just fine. It sounds like they're in the process of doing some remodeling, and in fact, they're building a brand new Starbucks in the lobby. Our room was totally fine and normal. Nothing out of the ordinary or fancy. I liked the ceramic tile floor around the bathroom and entry way. The room had a fridge and a microwave, so that was pretty convenient. The AC worked very well and we kept it blasting the entire time. Our room had a nice balcony (the AC shuts off when you open the balcony door). We did not get service, so I can't comment on how the cleaning staff did other than to say that when we got to our room, it was clean. When we passed the staff in the hallways, they always greeted us and were friendly. There are a couple of restaurants at the hotel - one off the lobby (diner/casual?), one on the third floor by the pool (Chinese) and one up on the roof/higher floor (steakhouse). We did not go to any of these, unfortunately, as we had too many other plans, but it was nice to have options. They also have a few small shops off the lobby for souvenirs and snacks and stuff if you don't feel like venturing over to the mall. We went to the pool several times and were pleasantly surprised. My sister swore it was salt water, and after a while, I started to believe she was right, but I still smelled like chlorine when I got out, so I don't know. Can it be both? I don't know :) Anyway, the pool was never crowded and we were always able to get an umbrella or shaded area. The area was relatively quiet, mostly occupied by people reading books or sunbathing. There were a few smaller children but nothing majorly loud. There are lounge chairs and also some tables and chairs in the shade. There's a very nice staff member who provides you with two towels upon arrival at the pool. We took Uber to several places and it was always pretty cheap to get anywhere (no more than $15) so I'm sure we were within walking distance of a lot of places, but it was unusually hot and we were tired and hungry/thirsty, so we decided against walking. If you're looking for a beachside adventure, this isn't your place. But if you don't mind having to walk a little bit to get to the beach and/or don't ever intend to step foot in the sand and just want a nice stay in Honolulu, this is your place :)

We stayed one night as we travelled between Maui and Australia. The location is adjacent to the Ala Moana Mall and thre are lots of dining options as well. Most stores are pen until 11pm so heaps of time for shopping..Rooms in the Kona tower are small and I wouldn't like to stay here for a week but overnight is fine. Mall and is great. Lots of food options in the mailman

When coming, going, and asking for assistance, the front counter personnel were always very friendly. Check-in was very easy and uneventful. Crews from most airlines stay here, so I enjoyed our many, brief discussions about aviation with them. Our room was on the 31st floor, and we had a nice view of the marina and ocean. Waikiki is about a 15-minute scenic walk, so if you are planning on using the great exercise room, why not walk down to the beach instead? The convenience store on the first floor has just about everything imaginable. Our room had been remodeled, and I had no complaints about its comfort, appearance, or cleanliness. However, most of the Filipino housekeeping staffs and waiters at the cafe were unfriendly and not at all helpful. They clearly and desperately need customer service and attitude adjustment training! On the other hand, Kathy, a Chinese lady in the Plantation Cafe, was the friendliest and most attentive server we have ever met. Her contagious smile and happy demeanor started our days off right. Every morning, we enjoyed the breakfast buffet and all of its fresh fruits. In another review, someone complained about the "Plantation" name. Give me a break; can we have more Political Correctness Gestapo members scrutinizing and reporting on everyone's thoughts, words, and actions? I liked being next to the Ala Moana outdoor mall and all of the unique shops, restaurants, and the food court. When traveling, I am not enamored with resort hotels. I can lie around a pool or go to a beach all day just about anywhere close to home, and I do not need to travel 2,400 miles to do so. I like to devote most of my time to driving, enjoying the sites, and participating in activities. Several times, we took visiting mo'opuna to the pool. However, it had too much chlorine, and it closes at sunset for some reason. There is no sauna, nor a smaller or shallower pool for children. I was on vacation, and I did not bring my iPad or laptop, so I cannot comment on the efficacy of the wi-fi signal. Parking costs $20/day and was not an issue, but we were there off-season, beginning 9/16/15. When I dropped off passengers and friends at the front entrance, the valets--who were usually just standing around and talking-- could have at least opened the car doors for them as a sign of courtesy and class. Overall, I liked this hotel and will stay here again.

For a conference, we did ok. This hotel has an identity crisis. It's odd layout and location is blocks from the business district and too far to walk to the tourist areas. It is situated next to a mall but you get those anywhere. You need a cab just about anywhere you want to go and that adds up fast. Rooms in the older tower are small

I was in Honolulu last week for a convention and stayed at the Ala Moana. This hotel is located just a short walk from the convention center, which is great, because it seems to rain every single day. It's also right next door to the Ala Moana Center, which is a huge open air mall (again...rain). So the location is great. That's about all that's great. Service was neutral. Not unfriendly, but not friendly either. My reservation was in order, but no one at the front desk smiles or does anything to make you feel welcome. There was a line to check in, and we waited about 10-15 minutes...it was like an assembly line. "Next!" Definitely not a warm welcome. I do have to say, though, that the servers in the restaurant during the breakfast buffet were very friendly and outgoing. Best service in the entire hotel was there in the buffet.The only food I ate in the hotel was the breakfast buffet, three times. The food was substantial and good. Not gourmet, but more than adequate for a quick breakfast. The coffee was GREAT. Loved the coffee.I had a room on the 7th floor of the Kona Tower, which is the tower without balconies. (The Waikiki tower has balconies and is a much taller tower). The rooms, overall, are tired, although very clean. The surface of the desk was very well worn, although it had a nice piece of glass over it, I suppose to extend it's life a few more years. My room had one double bed. The biggest shock was the 1970's quilted bedspread. These frighten me, because I don't imaging they are washed very often. It looked worn and grungy, and I tried not to touch it. There were two teenie tiny pillows that barely covered half the width of the bed. All that said, I have to admit I slept well and the bed wasn't uncomfortable.The bathrooms have been recently re-done with nice tile and materials, but they are beyond tiny. With the bathroom door open, you can't get in or out of the tub without climbing over the toilet. With the door closed, it's claustrophobic.Perhaps the biggest frustration was the WiFi.
