Except for the weak brew available in the room, the only choice for coffee for early risers is to walk to the nearby 7-Eleven (next to the massage parlors). The hotel would do well by its guests to put in a coffee shop or at least a coffee bar in its under-utilized retail space. One obvious area of neglect is the hotel restaurant -- The Plantation Cafe. The faded lettering on the sign for the restaurant is the first clue. This restaurant is only open for the buffet breakfast. The plate size is small and there are not many choices at the buffet. Describing the breakfast at the Plantation Cafe as mediocre is being kind. With there being no other choices nearby (not counting the 7-Eleven), the hotel apparently believes that it does not need to put forth much effort towards the breakfast experience for its guests. Instead of cold waffles, how about having a waffle maker? Or perhaps an attendant to cook made to order omelettes? Or a greater diversity of selections? My last suggestion would be to install a couple of television screens in the fitness center or better yet have equipment with screens on them.

If you have a later flight and arrive at this hotel after 9pm.... don't expect any service. Just give them your money and go to your room and shut up. The hotel basically rolls up the sidewalks at this time and doesn't want to be bothered with anything. Want to take a dip in the pool after a long flight?...forget it, pool is closed. Want a night cap to unwind after a long journey?...forget it, hotel bar closes early. You can try to ask the Receptionist at the check in counter, but she will reply in her best broken English ...EVERYTHING CLOSED...ITS LATE GO TO BED! Now you can go to the restaurant " Signature"on the 36th floor that is "NOT ASSOCIATED" with the hotel. You will be greeted by a stern faced waiter who smugly looks at his watch, wondering why you are bothering him at this time of night. We were then allowed to go to the bar, where 1 glass of wine, 1 Long Island Iced Tea, 4 jumbo shrimp and a cup of Lobster Bisque cost $70.00.For $200+ per room, one would expect a few amenities....but not at the Ala Moana after 9PM.

I chose this hotel for its closeness to the Hawaii Convention Center. I discovered later that it is also very close to a large shopping center and a nice beach park. Waikiki beach is at walking distance. Local friends recommended me to book a room in the Tower section of the hotel with ocean view, and I was not disappointed. My room was wide, well-appointed and and clean, and equipped with microwave oven, refrigerator, and coffee machine. WiFi was working well. The pool is well organized, the lobby extensive, and the staff friendly. I had been in Honolulu for conferences a few times before, and Ala Moana is by now my favorite hotel.

Perfect place to shop at Ala Moana Shopping Center. It's across the parking lot. The Ala Moana beach park is across the street for swimming and running. Rooms are small and will be tight for more than 2 persons. Parking is expensive and if you don't need don't rent one. Everything you need is at the mall.

we decided to book a room since we were attending a function here. we were happily surprised at the top notch service at check in, an unexpected upgrade and very comfortable room and bed. nice ocean view. we weren't expecting much and ended up being "WOWED"

First, the Ala Moana Hotel is just at the edge of Waikiki. So if you are local and you don't want to be in Waikiki or deal with the traffic in Waikiki, the Ala Moana Hotel is great.Second, there is a kamaaina rate that helps a lot.Third, it is located right next to the Ala Moana shopping center.The room was super clean and we could see the ocean. The house keepers were super nice and the front desk was great. Everyone said hi and it felt like we were at home. The shopping center was open late and we spent the evening there just walking around and did some shopping late at night.

Wonderful hotel in a great location. Everything is a stone's throw away - malls, restaurants, public transportation. For a first timer in Honolulu, the Hotel was a perfect choice. Would definitely stay here again.

Location for a shopaholic like me was perfect! Staff are friendly.our room view was fantastic sea view from obe of the suites facing the park and sea. Cant complain at all! In total it was an amazing experience with an excellent hotel ...

Nice hotel next to the mall, which had lots of dining options.The lobby was extensive and offered plenty of places to rest with a nice view and atmosphere.Easy to catch a bus to the beaches on Waikiki.Nice, quiet room, well appointed and a lovely view!

Visited Ala Moana Hotel on a business trip. Was just going to be an overnight stay. Checked in at 8pm, and there seems to be a mix-up at check in. While my reservation was made via a third party booking agency, and paid for by my employer, Ala Moana hotel did not get confirmation that the room was prepaid, or who was paying for stay. Not sure if it's the hotels fault or agencies error, but the front desk staff did not show too much empathy, so I asked for a manager. The manager on duty was a little more accomodating, and we agreed to work out the billing by check out in the morning, so I retired to my room. I was checking out early in the morning.Went to my room which is a standard hotel room. I appreciated the free wifi in room. My only problem is, the plumbing is so loud, I was awaken by the sound of the water running in the room next door. It was so loud, I had a difficult time going back to sleep, until they stopped running water.The stay was mediocre, but I took a some points away because of the front desk staff, not being as friendly-not too mention how airline pilots and employees are allowed to just bypass those waiting in line, and go right up to the counter to get their room keys.

I stayed here many times before and everything was great. The last visit i stayed here for business and it was nothing like the previous experiences. My check in was a bitter experience. I checked in with a guy at the front desk who had no smile or aloha at all. He made no eye contact at all and rushed me through the check in. It was a negative experience just getting to the hotel. I'm not sure if he was having a bad day (We all have those) or just ready to get off work. My room smelled like smoke as soon as i got into it. I don't smoke and the first thing that came to mind was the charge i was notified of at the front desk. I think it was a $250 charge for smoking in the room. I was alittle worried. The rooms were somewhat dirty and actually had food on the floor next to my bed. Fried rice next to the bed, how exciting of a find. The noise was horrible in the rooms, i could hear everything from someone opening a door, walking above, water being turned on in other rooms and not to mention the refrigerator sounded like a large air compressor constantly running. Overall it was a bitter experience. My opinion is stay somewhere else in downtown Waikiki and just find a ride to ala moana mall for shopping.

The best part of this hotel is its proximity to Ala Moana Shopping Centre, Ross Dress For Less & Walmart. If you like Korean cuisine, it borders on "Korean Town". Also, you can catch trolleys & buses easily just outside the mall. Ala Moana Shopping Centre is fantastic for shopping with a very huge food court. The hotel is linked/ adjacent to the mall. When you're a guest of the hotel, you get 10% discount when shopping at Macy's - bonus! Hotel staff are friendly & informative.The ordinary part of this hotel - the rooms are on the touch smallish for American hotels. Not Much room to move. The bathroom too is small. Room & bathroom is relatively clean & tidy. We had a room overlooking the car park which isn't much to look at. Given room sizing & views our intention was not to spend too much time in the room. Most likely return for another 2-3 days stay in the future. The hotel is adequate & functional for short stays up to a week.

We live in Hawaii, so we travel occasionally to other islands, this time to Oahu. We have stayed at this hotel before and had a good room with a decent view. Not this time! The first room we were given had two double beds so that wasn't going to fly! I called the front desk and they moved us to another room at the other end of the hall. It was a handicapped room! The door has a mechanism on it to help wheelchairs get in and out the door.........but you have to wait outside your door when you leave to make sure it shuts securely. Neither of us are wheelchair bound so it was kind of hilarious! The upside is that the bathroom was configured bigger to accomodate a wheel chair......but the downside is that a balcony is supposedly an "upgrade" yet mostly what we could see was the side of the hotel and parking lots. If you leaned over the railing, you could see some of the mountains........but I wouldn't recommend leaning very far.... we were on the eleventh floor! The hotel has 36 floors in all. It would be nice if this hotel upgraded their beds. They are not comfortable and we got neck and back aches. They only have queen size beds too! The shower worked great and had plentiful hot water. The fitness center is nice, but the sauna was out of order, and the pool area really needs to be updated. In room internet is free, but in order to print out boarding passes, you have to pay a fee! We opted to just do it at the airport! Parking is expensive at $20.00 per day for self parking, but parking is scarce in Waikiki so if you rent a car, look for places that have parking. One advantage to this hotel is it's connection to the Ala Moana Shopping Center. You can walk there from the second floor of the hotel so that is very convenient. There is great shopping and a big food court. Too bad this mall doesn't have a movie theater in it, but the closest stadium seating theater is not too far away by the Ward Center. The beach is across the street and past the park, so not too bad for walking if you don't have too much to carry. For the price, I guess you get what you pay for and we will undoubtedly stay there again, hoping for a better room with a better view!

I originally booked the Kona tower but after talking with the flight crew on Alaska airlines I changed to the Waikiki tower. Great advice. The room was perfect and the view from the lanai captured the sunset and the city. I was in the 35th floor and enjoyed every minute. The concierge was extremely helpful and gave me advice for several local dinner spots. His advice was spot on. I would definitely stay here again.

I v stayed at hotel many times they where rude to me but what after was worse I went to visit a friend of mine from other island visiting and left my phone in car not able to call my friend or my ride to come back get me the security started to Harass me about where I was going upset I started crying and when I tryed to leave in a taxi security blocked my way continuing to Harris me I called him a bad name while was mad and he lied said I punched him and pressed charges I never punched anyone !! Luckily taxi was nice to me took me home even bought me cigarrets till I got home and payed and tips him extra and was able to find my phone it was racist Asian guy harassing me I would not ever reckomend any of my friend to stay there again I know I never will again.

Stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel via Luxury Suites because the advertised rate was 30% lower. Luxury Suites? This company manages units in this hotel that are privately owned but are available for rent to the public. Check-in and out is at the Ala Moana Hotel's front desk but housekeeping, etc., is not handled by hotel personnel but contracted by Luxury Suites. Because of this, my unit was not up to the standards of the hotel's regular units. There was no shower mat, the soap was not wrapped (it was used by the previous guest, yikes!), the phone book was several years old, shower handle pulled off easily and the toilet tissue dispenser was broken off the wall. Definitely not what I expected. / The hotel itself has been renovated and very comfortable. For non-tourists. This is a great location. It is located adjacent to the Ala Moana Shopping Center which is Hawaii's largest and boasts a large number of stores and restaurants. There's a large food court for the budget traveler. Ala Moana Beach Park is just two blocks away so walking to the beach is a snap. If you're looking for tourist action, hula shows and the like, you would need to take a cab or drive to Waikiki which is a 1 - 2 miles away. Warning, rush hour traffic is horrific so plan accordingly. All in all, except for the issues mentioned which you should not encounter if you booked directly with the Ala Moana Hotel, this is a great and convenient hotel to stay. If you're playing tourist, I would suggest you stay at a hotel in or near Waikiki where the beach, nightlife and shopping are all in walking distance.

Clean rooms, hawaiian and flowerful decoration and GREAT location for shopping and restaurants. Attached to the huge Ala Moana Mall. Nice breakfast with a variety of fresh fruits. Not noisy at all. If you feel like, it is a long walk to Waikiki, though not bad at all and entertaining with a gorgeous hawaiian weather.

This is your basic average hotel, around 3 stars. Have everything you need no frills or whistles. We were on the 14th floor with a mountain view in the tower. We had no problems with anything. The breakfast at the Plantation Café is over priced, but so is everything in Hawaii. They don't have room service. Which I didn't realize before. They do have microwave and refrigerator in the room. Staff is ok, not rude but not super friendly. You can walk to Wakiki beach and shops. restaurants in that area. It's connected to Ala Moana shopping mall which is Hugh and has just about every name brand store, with lots of restaurants. Internet is free. But you have to pay at the business center if you want to print your boarding pass. Has a convenient store and two restaurants in the hotel itself. Oh, this is the hotel where all the airline people stays, so lots of flight attendants, pilots, etc. therefore it can't be that bad. Airlines have been using this hotel for years. much cheaper than other hotels closer to Wakiki beach. If you have kids, I guess to 10 mins walk to the beach might be too much.

We stayed here for 4 nights of our 11 day honeymoon in Hawaii. Disappointment doesn't cover it. I've stayed at Motel 6s that had bigger and more comfortable beds. My wife actually cried after we checked in because she couldn't believe how poor the accommodations were for the package that we booked for our honeymoon. My only compliment is that the refrigerator and microwave worked well. Otherwise, this place is a 2 star at best. Construction noise at 6 am and a pool that is open despite construction workers working with power tools in earshot, this place is the epitome of a tourist trap!

Stayed several nights here. Mixed feelings.location good,especially if you like to. Shop.near beach and waterside park. Key card system for elevator cumbersome and many lights out so not sure one was going to your floor. Really strange in this day and age is not having a free computer access to get flight boarding passes. Room wifi included but needed to use business center to get boarding passes-high cost for both computer time and for printing.have been there both for pleasure and business and this is strange. Staff generally quite friendly. Breakfast buffet atotel only fair quality though many choices.

We arrived just after noon. We live on another island in Hawaii, and we weren't in Honolulu just to shop and hang out at the beach. OK, I know the room might not be ready until 3pm. That's understandable and a stated policy. But the lady Iwalani at check-in was somewhere between matter-of-fact and unpleasant, told us we could go to the mall, and then abruptly called "Next!" to dismiss us. It wasn't a good start. Don't expect a lot of aloha from Iwalani. After mostly just sitting and shopping at the adjacent mall, we returned at 2:30 and a much nicer and friendly lady Barbara got us into our room with a smile. We were on the 9th floor, which is about where you want to be. The view is OK and the elevator time is short. Stay in Waikiki Tower. Others in our group in the Kona part didn't have rooms as nice or new. All appliances worked well; the room and bathroom were clean; and the wifi connection worked well enough to stream video, although we did have to re-log in more often than once every 24 hours, The swimming pool is excellent. Salt water. Clean. Warm. It closes at sunset, however.$20/24-hour parking for guests is a rip-off that added $40 to our final bill. But this is Honolulu, so one must just assume such costs.The location is a bit bipolar: It's only about a 15-minute walk at most to the southeast to the posh part of Waikiki, although with small kids be advised this involves negotiating a complicated and busy intersection. Just to the north of the hotel, however, and even in view from north-facing rooms, are lots of strip clubs, massage parlors, men hanging around in groups on the sidewalk in front of a convenience store, etc. We happened to walk that way once -- not again! -- because our daughter wanted KFC and that's the direction it lies in. She's personally seen poverty in Third World countries before, but it was still not pleasant walking by garbage piles and a couple people who were engaged in spirited, angry conversations with invisible partners.Food. Four local options: 1) Food court at mall. 2) Spend fortune in hotel. 3) Spend bigger fortune in posher Waikiki hotels and restaurants down the road. 3) Expose your family to the sights, sounds and smells of the homeless on the way to a kind of Asian strip mall where KFC is; 4) be part of a group that has meals otherwise arranged. We had option 4. You probably won't.We had a decent group rate for this trip. Maybe we would stay there again if we had to pay the regular price, but one friend got the same rate at a hotel right on Waikiki beach, so we'll certainly shop around first.

Centrally located and just great! For a mid-range hotel, we were pleasantly surprised. Rooms were small but clean and quiet. The lobby is open air and staff was exceptionally friendly and helpful. There's coffee in the mornings and juice in the afternoons in the lobby. The ABC store is on the first floor with LuLu's restaurant on the 2nd floor! The pool is crisp and clean, also with a view of the beach. See my review of LuLu's. Went there too many times, but all were well worth the trip. Heading back to the Ala Moana next week. See you folks again!

This was my second stay at Ala Moana Hotel and I'm a fan of the place. While it lacks the elegance of some of the more upscale hotels on Ala Moana Blvd. and it doesn't have the dining options of other nearby hotels, the location is priceless. In town for conferences on my last two visits to Hawaii, the Ala Moana is located just across the street from the Hawaii Convention Center and it's essentially adjacent to to the Ala Moana Center.With a grand lobby that boasts plenty of seating and even a tranquil area, the Ala Moana is a large hotel with two towers and over 30 floors. We stayed in the Waikiki tower and we were upgraded to an ocean view, which was actually more of a view of docked boats and a sliver of the water. But, I can't really complain about the upgrade as it was a nice gesture and we didn't really spend too much time in the room.The check-in and check-out processes were relatively seamless and the service was quite good. The rooms were cleaned well daily and the housekeeping staff was very attentive. The rooms there are simple but they get the job done. We had two beds, a desk, a couple of chairs, a balcony, a mini refrigerator, a microwave and a large flat screen TV.If you're looking for a decent hotel that's convenient to the convention center, attached to the Ala Moana Center, a short walk to Waikiki beach, shopping on Kalakaua and Kapiolani Ave, then the Ala Moana Hotel may be a good fit. It's economical, clean, has complimentary wi-fi and the staff from the bell hops to the front desk staff are quite friendly and helpful.

My whole family stayed here and the hotel accommodated all of our different needs amongst an age range of 60 years! The rooms are excellent. The old part is more quaint and a little less noise protected, but not an issue. The newer area was excellent. The Banyan bar is a lovely oasis to return to and please do yourself a favour and try the club sandwich. It is to die for.Perfect location, awesome staff and a wonderful overall experience. A lovely old lady...

We stayed at this hotel for two days at the end of our holiday after staying in Waikiki at another hotel this hotel was a real disappointment. The hotel itself is ok, reasonable price and comfortable. Although we had to ask for additional towels and an extra pillow upon checking into our room. The location is terrible.... It couldn't be further away from the beach, restaurants and hustle and bustle of what Honolulu has to offer. If you have children or on holidays forget about booking this hotel. Despite the Ala Moana Mall being right next door, there is only so much shopping and eating out of the food court and few restaurants in that complex you can handle. You can catch the pink line trolley from Waikiki for the day for only $2 and I would suggest this. The customer service is terrible, we asked at reception and they were unable to suggest anywhere to get a meal other than there in-house restaurant or the food court at the mall also asked about wi-fi and was basically ignored. The lady at the bell desk was rude when it came to booking an airport shuttle. No greeting just "yes". The finally straw was my mother was wheeling her suitcase into the front of the hotel and it fell over as she hand her hands full and two male employees just looked over at her and just watched, not one of them came over and offered to help or see if she was ok. What is with the lack of common courtesy.

If you are here on business and don't care about the beach, this might work for you. If you are a family, don't consider it. The closest beach is Ala Moana Beach Park and it's not family-friendly. If you feel like giving your kid a crash course in why people are homeless, or why some people yell at their kids incessantly threatening to smack them, that's your beach. The adjacent bus stop that takes you to Waikiki is usually taken up by homeless people sleeping on the benches. There are strip clubs right behind the hotel. I understand Honolulu has a homeless problem and I totally empathize as I don't know the right solution, but it's not where I want to take my family on vacation. If you just want to come and shop at the adjacent Ala Moana mall, the location is perfect.Regarding the hotel, it's a cattle car. They try to cram as many people in as possible. They don't have enough elevators nor do they have enough parking. People park illegally all over the parking garage as there aren't enough spaces because the hotel crams guests in like a cattle car. The hotel hosted a ton of military for RIMPAC and there was no additional security. It felt very vulnerable. Housekeeping was mostly fine but didn't replace sugar or Sweet & Low for coffee for 3 days. Only 1 pack of coffee for 2 adult guests per day. Laundry facilities are ancient and they don't have nearly enough considering how many long term guests they have. Rooms are comfortable and have fridge and microwave, but sheets are not always clean. One pair seemed to have a mud stain that never came out in wash. There are other options. Check Hotwire and Priceline and you'll get a better hotel at the same rate.

I have stayed here at least 4 times in the last 5 years with my most recent stay in June of 2013.First I have to say that I love the location of this hotel for one night stays on my way through Hawaii back to my home island in Kwajalein Atoll. Mostly becuase it is right next to the mall, and a few blocks from Walmart or any other shopping you may need. Kwajalein does not have a lot of variety, so getting some groceries from the store in the mall or Walmart is great.Second, there is a price disparity between what is offered at this hotel based on how you booked your stay. There are a lot of rooms that are owned not by the hotel but by other people who then rent them out at different prices. Those rooms when booked through sites like Priceline or Hotels.com are normally the ones owned by other people and not the hotel. This makes a differance in your quality of stay. If the person who owns the room does not hire someone to clean it on a regular basis you may not find it clean, and the one time I did rent the "condo" it had a roach there to great me. These rooms often rent for about $170 a night. And any diparities or uncleanliness you find in the room the hotel has nothing to do with it and will not help you.Third if you do book from the hotel website I recomend the Wakiki tower. This is the taller tower and the elevators to access it are right in the hotel loby next to the front desk. If you book the Kona tower it may be cheaper around $180-$210 per night but you have to drag your suite case across carpeting for almost 50 yards or more in order to get to the Kona tower elevators. I hate doing this because my suitecase is often heavy and gets stuck in the carpeting or drags considerably, so it is like pulling a 50 pound weight instead of rolling it. Honestly the hotels rooms owned by the hotel are clean and quite and I do not have a single complaint about those features. The thing that I do not find pleasent is the sticker price. The Waikiki tower rooms range from $190 to over $300 dollars. There are a lot of cheaper hotels that have the same quality rooms for less. If you stay here it is really just for the location. All of my prices mentioned are before taxes and fees.One other thing. They try to sell you on the inclusion of breakfast at their cafe, but I have yet to eat there even though I had the tickets. The food may be fine, but the line in the morning for breakfast is so long that it could take an hour before you get to the door. I have waited at least 45 minutes and gotten close but gave up when i was told it would still be a 20 minute wait. It was faster and perhaps better to eat at a local restaurant. Okay a final note: This hotel is used for airline delays and the pilots and crew. So you may have a nice quite hotel one night and a very busy and disgruntaled group of travelers the next due to some flight delay that caused the airline to give them a hotel voucher. This may make your wait in the loby's line rather long but if you avoid the loby and go out through the ramp to the mall you can avoid the lines. I also recomend calling the front desk instead of going down there durring these occations if you need something.

The hotel is adequate, near a mall, not far to walk to places on Waikiki, but the service gets on one's nerves! I travel a lot and stay at many of the budget chain hotels for work. The service at most of those is superior to what you get here. We checked out after three days and found something else because it wasn't the slightest big relaxing. My key wouldn't work, which is the only way to get on the elevator. I went to the front and found a line with 12 people waiting to check in. So, i asked the concierge if she could just help me reprogram my key so i could go to my room. "No, you have to wait in line." Really? So, I asked one of the other people at the front desk. "No, you have to wait in line." I gave up after 20 minutes of fuming, woke up my significant other, and had him come down and get me. When i finally did get my key reprogrammed, she told me i had probably put it next to my phone. Really? I know better. Upon check out, we were charged an "upgrade fee" which we had not asked for. (If you do have to stay there, don't get a "mountain view". It's really a rooftop view of a not so great neighborhood.) When i told her we had not requested an upgrade, she said, well, i'm going to have to talk to my manager. Her manager was really kind enough to take it off our bill, since we had not asked for it. Not once, was a "sorry" heard. There's lots of other good options. I encourage you to find one.

We overnighted at Ala Moana while flying Hawaiian Airlines from PDX back to SYD. We checked in about 2.30pm, avoiding the 3pm rush in evidence when we went back to reception to get our second door keycard enabled. When we got served, the rather snotty reception member immediately said "you must have had it near a phone" which was ridiculous and wrong, both had been the only things in my shirt top pocket. One card did not work from the get go, trying to get to our floor in the elevators, or opening the room door. So our first impression was pretty negative.The room was a king bed high floor with views, and that was fine thought the entire building is showing its age and was just adequate. An annoying aspect was that while the rooms have a microwave and small fridge, they are devoid of any glassware, plates, cutlery, no bottle opener, nothing. Housekeeping did deliver 2 wine glasses on request, but we had to buy a corkscrew/bottle opener with a bottle of wine over at the nearby shops.Overall our description of the hotel is "just adequate", the king bed fine and shower good to use, a small but functional balcony - with an exhortation that smoking anywhere including the balcony would incur a $200 cleaning fee. But don't expect anything extra like much friendliness or flexibility from the staff, and our second encounter with reception was memorably bad.One final plus is the little shop, quite hidden on the lobby level, which sells lots of nibbles and drinks, fruit and all sorts of bits and pieces for travellers, and is staffed by the most friendly and helpful staff. We wish we had found it earlier in our stay.

The hotel itself is ok for the price, our room is a bit older but clean and the location is a bit further away from the beach as advertised. It is a decent place to stay during a conference, not so much for a vacation.However, we had a very bad experience with the staff at the reception. My wife asked for a wifi password in the lobby and was treated like an intruder by the reception staff, who wanted her to show her ID and then first refused to give the password because the room is not registered under my wife's name. A friend had a similar experience where he was told that it is was own fault that his key card was deactivated since he must have put it too close to his mobile phone.The customer is apparently not always right in the Ala Moana Hotel.

A guide-book essential (from a company that rhymes with Hodor, for you Game of Thrones’ fans) ranks this a best bet for moderate lodging and Hawaii Magazine readers named this a top budget pick for 2014. I would happily return, despite a very rough start. We waited an aggravating half an hour to check in. (When I waited seven minutes this spring at the Marriott in Baltimore because the computer was down, I received a hand written note of apology and chocolate bars, but I digress.) Then, for the three of us, we were given a skanky, small room, replete with someone else’s hair on the pillow of the only bed, a double, with views into the apartment complex a few feet away. In my jet lagged and near-tears state, it dawned on me that we had not been give the correct room in the Tower that we had reserved. When they reassigned us, what a world of difference! The room was clean, spacious, nicely appointed in contemporary Hawaiian décor, and best of all, had a spectacular 180 degree view of downtown Honolulu from mauka to makai (mountain to sea) with a glimpse of Diamondhead in the background. Having coffee on our upper floor balcony each morning was sheer delight. Honestly, that was the most schizophrenic hotel experience I have ever had. Whatever you do, reserve and then insist upon a room in the Tower. Finally, the location is hard to beat—away from the sheer density of tourists on Waikiki (but located at its northern end near the yacht club) and next to the splendid Ala Moana open air shopping mall with its restaurants, wonderful Foodland for groceries, and $4 Mai Tais at the rooftop bar (aptly named Mai Tais) on Mahalo Mondays (with terrific live music and good pupus as well!) The crowd next door shopping is decidedly tony and international, so it is also a blast for people watching. Parking in the hotel’s underground lot is probably as cheap and convenient as it is likely to get in downtown.

I stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel simply because I attended a conference held here. I did not have many expectations before leaving home, but I did read some reviews just to get an idea. I know hotels in the USA are very different than hotels back home when it comes to service. You just get what you paid for, and dont get the extra friendliness from hotel staff. I wont say that this was a great hotel, but I have nothing to complain either. For me, this was just a place to sleep over. The hotel is close to the shopping area, with a bridge connecting to the Ala Moana Center. Lots of eating places nearby. And since I like walking a lot, I enjoyed the 15-20 minute walk to Waikiki, you can also take the Waikiki trolley at the mall ($2 one way, or even better get a $38 one-day pass form4 different bus routes). I read some reviews mentioning that the rooms at Kona Tower were small, but I don't think that was a big problem for me. If I had to travel to Honolulu again for a conference or business-related trip, I would probably stay here again, although I would be open to other options, if any.

United Airlines put us up here due to maintenance issues and our having missed our connection. It was convenient to food. The hotel had several restaurants and it was across the street from a HUGE shopping mall. Although we arrived at approximately 7 pm, the concierge assisted us in getting a tour the next day, which was GREAT. I feel satisfied.The room was quiet and we slept well.

The Ala Moana hotel is really a good choice for Honolulu - the biggest reason being its location, just a short walk from Waikiki (without being in the middle of that madness) and connected to the Ala Moana Shopping Center, which has all the shopping you could ever want and houses Honolulu's main bus terminal for great connectivity.I have no complaints at all about the room itself. It was large and had a great balcony. The bed was really comfortable, and the room had a large flat-screen TV with many channels. It also had a refrigerator, microwave, and coffee maker.My complaint is with the way the hotel sells some of its rooms to individuals and other corporate entities. Rather than being owned by the hotel itself, my room was owned by Luxury Suites International, based in Las Vegas. When I checked in, I was told that if I had any problems or issues with the room, I needed to call this company's hotline (but no later than 7pm Las Vegas time, if I remember correctly) as the Ala Moana Hotel management was not responsible for my room and could not help me with any problems I might encounter.Thankfully, I had no major issues. At one point, I couldn't locate the broadband plug in the room (but there must have been one since they did have a broadband cable). I ended up being able to connect to wi-fi with no problem, so it wasn't a big deal, but they told me at the front desk that I would have to call Luxury Suites International to get any help locating the broadband plug. I recommend this hotel, but it might be a good idea to verify first whether the room you're getting is actually an Ala Moana Hotel-owned room or one owned by some other entity, for if it's one like mine owned by some other entity, any problems you might have would not receive any immediate attention from the hotel staff.

Booked for 8 nites and checked out after 4. Would have left sooner but my conference was in hotel. Very stingy with the coffee! Asked for an extra packet for the room (2 adults in room) and was told NO! Complained at front desk and still told "no"! Unless I wanted to pay $2.50 per packet! I've never been in a hotel that would not provide extra coffee packets -- especially since there was no place to get coffee in the hotel after the Plantation Café closed at 10am. They suggested I go a few blocks away to the Seven11. I even told the front desk that denying this simple request would make me want to switch hotels! Switched to Park Shore Waikiki (wonderful!) with a Starbucks practically in the lobby... and unlimited coffee in room! Bring it on.

Huge hotel near the water (0.5 mile walk from the door to the water at the Ala Moana beach park). Walking distance to Waikiki, and the associated shopping area, zoo etc. Interior not amazing, but no complaints. Hotel has several restaurants, as well as a store with everything from gifts and aspirin to food and beverages. Rooms are sufficient, and come with microwave and fridge, so you don't have to eat out all the time. I could not ever get on the internet, and never got a person on the phone to help me trouble shoot, so that was a pain (I was there for work).*be aware there is no shuttle from the airport, cab fare from HNL to Ala Moana was $50, and going back (in no traffic) I paid $36- not including tip. This was more than I was expecting when making my travel arrangements, so passing the note along to those in the same position

If you are expecting a 5 star hotel then go to the Royal Hawaiian. This hotel is very convenient for a number of reasons. Within walking distance to the convention center, also the Ala Moana Beach Park, even Waikiki if you feel like walking. And the extra of being next door to the Ala Moana Shopping center with all its shops and restaurants. This is a great place to stay since a lot of local people and some airline crews stay there. I travel a lot and my criteria for places to stay and eat is go where the locals go. The "Signature" restaurant on the top floor is a great place to have a cocktail and a view of the sunset. I always stay there whenever I am in Honolulu. What some don't realize is that the Ala Moana is partially a hotel and a condominium.

Which is the best thing you can say about this hotel.It's the only reason to stay there. Unless of course you like bad service!!!Requested an ocean view, king room in the tower. Upon check-in was sent to a mountain view, double room. Took over an hour to get that sorted out . . . Every request was met with a "why do you want that" response from staff. Usually takes 5-6 requests to get anything done.Was told late check-out would be likely, actually we were asked to check out early!Was told at check-in there would be a room available if we wanted to shower and change before flight, but the morning of check-out we were told there is only one room and it books up days in advance . . . Pretty much bait and switch is the name of the game here!If you have to stay here, it is passable, but just don't expect much.

As a local (Kamaaina) resident, I've stayed at this hotel many times over the years. Visitors need to do their research and know what they are getting before booking a room here. Ala Moana is an excellent alternative to the craziness and congestion of Waikiki. The hotel is at the entrance to Waikiki and offers better, more plentiful and economical shopping and dining options in the adjacent Ala Moana mall. The hotel is connected to the mall by a skybridge on the 2nd floor of the hotel. If you are on a budget, be aware that the Kona tower rooms are tiny, and though more economical, we never stay in that section. You will be happier if you pay the extra $10-$20 and book the Waikiki Tower. The higher the floor, the better your view and quality of room. There were 7 in our party. My dad had a handicap room on the 6th floor which was perfect for his needs. My husband and I were in room 2814. The room was in excellent condition. The walls seemed to have been freshly painted. Our king sized bed was firm. There was a sofa bed and armchair in the room. Water pressure in the bath/shower was good. Flat screen TV, microwave, refrigerator, coffeemaker, all seemed new. Only 3 pillows on the king bed, which was okay for us, but they will bring you more pillows if you ask. The TV channels had the usual cable lineup, including Showtime and HBO, as well as Japanese programming (for the many Japanese guests). We ate at the hotel's Plantation Cafe one morning. Breakfast buffet is $16 which is cheaper than most of the Waikiki hotels and though not outstanding, it was totally fine for us--the usual eggs, bacon, waffles, pastries, etc.. I think you can buy coffee to go in the restaurant up until they close. Breakfast runs daily from 6:30 to 10 a.m. You can even get the buffet to take out. I can understand why the hotel does not have more restaurant options given their proximity to the ginormous Ala Moana mall. The food court at the mall opens at 8 a.m. There is a 7-11 convenience store just a block down the road in front of the hotel--and of course, it's open 24/7. The Wailana Coffee Shop which is down the road, across from the Hilton on Ala Moana Blvd. is a great place for breakfast---the best blueberry pancakes--and inexpensive. The hotel parking lot is small and it can be confusing trying to find your car. At $20 a day for self-park it is not cheap, but still cheaper than Waikiki where parking averages $30 or more. I think it's funny to hear people complain about paying $20 a day. This is typical for a big city and major resort!Price-wise, the Ala Moana hotel is a solid choice, more so for locals though, since we got an oceanview room for $169 at our Kamaaina rate. We could have booked a mountain view suite for $249, but the oceanview room was perfect, as the lanai (w/two chairs plus table) was shaded all day. We had a great view of Waikiki, the boats in Ala Wai harbor and Ala Moana beach park. The room was quiet even though the hotel was fully booked the weekend we were there. I did not hear any of our neighbors. Personally, I enjoy staying outside of Waikiki. I've stayed at several hotels in Waikiki over the years and the Ala Moana hotel always offers excellent value---but just don't expect much if you choose the Kona tower. You'll probably be happy in any category room in the Waikiki tower as long as you are on one of the higher floors. You will get what you pay for! Be careful if booking your room through a vacation rental company, as those rooms are not necessarily going to be on par with the hotel's rooms. Our party had 4 rooms booked through the hotel and all of them were in excellent condition. I book directly through the Outrigger.com website.

Had the wonderful experience of going to Oahu for work travel back in May of 2007. Stayed in the beautiful Ala Moana hotel located right next to an expansive outdoor mall and many restaurants. The view from the 19th floor balcony showed mountains straight ahead and the beach to the left. Wonderful views of the sunset every night. The room was cozy and clean; the exterior and interior of the hotel were top notch. Short walking distance to the yacht club across the main intersection. The conference center was also located a few short minutes away on foot.

I wanted to try VRBO on this trip, and found my options limited. Still, I work for a resort hotel, and $ 200.00 per night is not unacceptable in any major city. Though a private condo, it is within the Hotel, and I can tell that all hotel units are similarly furnished. The main attraction to this hotel is that it is part of the Ala Moana mall complex. My preference would not be for a high rise hotel in the future, now that I am more familiar with the area. Can't fault the location though. Actually, can't fault the hotel either. One sign is that a lot of airline flight crews stay here, meaning that it is not top of the line, but certainly acceptable. They have a top floor Signature steak and seafood restaurant, that was very noisy, albeit popular in the cocktail hour, notwithstanding the fact that it faced away from the sunset. Probably a local's watering spot. Their associated breakfast cafe is a buffet style, and completely acceptable. Many interior spaces are vacant, with promises of future tenants, such as a spa, etc. Realtor's ads in the elevator suggest it has been fairly recently renovated, which may account for the empty commercial spaces within.

This is my first stay at a hotel that was not on Waikiki. Convenient to lots of venues. You can go to the Ala Moana Shopping Center, not only to do some shopping, but to go to their eclectic food court to get a reasonably priced meal. The Center was just a short walk from the ramp connected to the hotel. There is a bus stop right outside the hotel that will take you anywhere you want to go. (Bus fare is $1 for seniors over 65, but don't forget to bring your Medicare card as proof of age. They do not accept a driver's license.) The beach is just across the street, as well as the convention center. The hotel has a nice store that is open until 11:30p, just in case you need food or toothpaste or whatever. There are 3 restaurants. The staff was efficient and pleasant. The downside, if you can call it that, is that the hotel is busy, usually bustling with activity. Don't try to check in at 3:00pm, the check-in time. I waited 45 minutes. They were fully booked the day I arrived, and everybody came at the same time. All in all, a nice hotel.

I used to live in Honolulu and when I come back to visit friends I like to stay outside the Waikiki chaos. I like Ala Moana Hotel because it's good access to Ala Moana beach, which is a lot more mellow than Waikiki Beach, and the Ala Moana Shopping Center. I recently stayed a night between flights and was glad to have the chance to wander the mall for a bit. Room-wise, it's a bit small but clean and bright.

This is not a resort property. For example, swimming pool is just that, no fun slides and the pool deck is not attractive and the view is surrounding buildings. It is a fairly moderate priced hotel and convenient if you want to stay out of the busy Waikiki area. As a neighbor island traveler to Oahu, my family and I like to book this hotel because it's right next to the Ala Moana Shopping Center and traffic is not so hectic to get to this property. After a late afternoon/early evening arrival, after checking in, we walk on over to Ala Moana Shopping Center for some shopping and dinner. No worries if you want to have a drink or two because you can simply walk back to the hotel and not worry about driving.

This is a moderately priced hotel in the Waikiki area. Some rooms have a bit of an ocean view but many don't. Also some rooms have a balcony that you can sit on and others don't. Many of the units here are privately owned. If you book through Hotels.com or VRBO you will get a privately owned place. This usually means you can get it for less but be aware that if anything goes wrong, including house keeping and maintenance, the hotel will not help you. So make sure you can contact the owner. Often there is no daily maid service throughout your stay if you are using a private owner. But you have to pay a housekeeping fee for them to clean the room when you leave.Nice little stores in the place. OK restaurants. Room has microwave and mini fridge. You can buy food in their store to eat in your room if you want.Huge lobby. Staff is nice.Resort fees apply. This is not a resort! So it does feel like a rip off. I booked through VRBO and had to pay the resort fees plus a "check in fee" of $40.Be sure you have all the fees understood to see if you are getting the best deal.Room, taxes, clean out fee, resort fees, check in fees...

When I lived on Kauai I regularly came to Oahu for work and would often stay at the Ala Moana hotel. Why? Because it's just outside the traffic and noise of Waikiki and it's cheaper than Waikiki hotels. The rooms are modern and there's underground parking. Not to mention that Ala Moana Shopping Center is right next door with it's awesome food court for easy dining options. Even if you're visiting as a tourist this is a good alternative to Waikiki hotels because you'll get more for your money but you'll have to walk a bit or ride the trolley or bus to get into Waikiki proper.

Not a great start to a business trip. Room is very small, so narrow that it is nearly impossible to open your luggage on the rack. The closet they provide is blocked by a wall so hanging clothes was tough. The room I sold and dingy. Furniture on balcony is filthy and would not be able to say when they cleaned it. Not sure where anyone else is staying but seriously you all have hot to be kidding me on your reviews. It smells like mildew in rooms. Lobby has no ac so you drop dead if waiting for someone. Anyway I would not recommend to business traveler at all. I will never stay again. Ps the staff was very nice.

A good stay with good restaurants and amenities. Staff was always smiling and helpful. About 20 mins from airport and hotel has shuttle service (about $10/person). Shops provided a good variety on gifts and supplies. Centrally located and a short walk to the mall. Nice beach Park across the street and an easy walk to Waikiki Beach... more shopping. No room service. In-room massages available and recommended. Local attractions services also available and recommended (see Steve).

I booked 3 nights here for a meeting and left after the first night. The room greeted me with many different colors of hair in the bathtub. Chipped worn furniture and very low end dirty bedding. The mountain view (15th floor) was the top of other buildings and don't look down! A bus lot a block long full of all types of buses. Tour buses with the tops off, wrecked and half draped traps. The ocean view rooms look out over a park where homeless people live, then you see the ocean. The retail shops have all closed in the hotel with the exception of 3. The food is good if you like chicken every day. The sweet potato rolls are great! The best part of this very busy area is the mall which is the largest outdoor mall in the states. All of the high end stores are here. But you have to go down a ramp and walk across the mall parking garage to get to them. I never felt safe in this area.

I stayed in one of the Ala Moana's handicapped rooms for three nights and look forward to staying there on my next trip. It is centrally located for going wherever you want to go and if you're a shopper, it's adjacent to an amazing mall. It has all the amenities you could ask for and the most comfortable bedding I've had in a hotel in a long while!!! Not only is there Kona coffee to enjoy in the room but also a microwave to warm up goodies! It has a large, well arranged lobby in which to meet friends and a small balcony as well. Enjoy a stay there!!

My third time in Honolulu, 4th time in Hawaii...I had always stayed on Waikik but needed to be near the Ala Moana Mall for this trip. It was an excellent hotel. Reasonably priced gift shop downstairs, kind staff, not too crowded pool, and just a 2 minute walk from the mall that provides endless shopping, food, and entertainment on tropical, rainy days. It was about a 10-15 walk to waikiki but that was bearable. A cab ride would have taken 3-5 minutes. Not a big deal but in Hawaii $10. Anyway, very reasonably priced hotel, updated rooms, all in all a GREAT stay and a very convenient location!

The best: The concierge is an Expedia local expert and makes outstanding recommendations and reservations for activities. Walking distance to a park with a lovely, and not too crowded, beach.The good: Spacious, beautiful lobby. Several good restaurants and shops right in the hotel. Pool, workout room, massages available in-room.The not so good: Our room was very small and basic and we had to ask for a blanket and extra towels. We were on the 4th floor and the view was over a parking lot and back streets. One night we had very noisy neighbors, but the staff was quick to respond. The traffic in the area is terrible all the time.Depends on what you prefer: The gigantic Ala Moana mall is right next door. If you want to shop at pricey designer stores, it's a great location. And if you want to be right in the heart of everything, halfway between Waikiki Beach and downtown Honolulu, this is the perfect location. But understand that it's a concrete jungle, not an outdoor paradise. If you're looking for a Hawaiian paradise, I think a different Island would be a better choice.

My husband and I stayed at the hotel for 4 nights. The location was perfect, the room was comfortable and the service was simply outstanding. We would ask the Concierge for suggestions on places to have authentic Hawaiian meals, directions, etc and they would give us attention and care. The morning we left to catch a plane back home (LA) I realized I had left my cell phone and IPad chargers on the nightstand. I called the hotel as we drove to the airport and they put me through to housekeeping. I spoke with Chris, then Tony and they were so helpful. I also gave them my information and today my chargers arrived in the mail. Since the postage was under $10, there was no charge. Now, that's service! We will definitely return!

Stayed at this hotel for five nights. Unfortunately I had a disabled room and the bathroom was hard to use. Apparently it was full house and they could not change my room. Later that day, there was a walk-in guests asking for a room and they checked in straight away so obviously it was not full. The room was a good size, comfy bed, TV with many channels, proper coffee and coffee maker in the room. The hotel was right next to Ala Moana Centre and convenient to get take away food and coffee. It was a walking distance to Waikiki, about 15 minute. Will stay there again as long as I get an abled room.

If you want a hotel that is not on the beautiful beaches and in the middle of town next to a shopping mall, then this is your place. Its a nice enough hotel that has seen better years but still a solid three stars. The staff is friendly and the access to the mall is as good as you can get, the mall is literally right across the street. The rooms are average but clean, nothing exceptional. I personally don't want to go to Hawaii to be by a Mall, I'd rather be sitting on a beautiful beach watching the scenery. Waikiki beach may look like only a 15 minute walk from the hotel but you cross numerous busy, busy intersections so it takes a good 30 minutes by foot.Other than that, the hotel gets the job done.

We wanted to check out the shopping scene in Honolulu so moved across from Waikiki beach to the Ala Moana Hotel right next to the Ala Moana Shopping Centre and close to Walmart & Ross stores. The hotel has a walkway from the second floor to the car park at Macys. We had room 1504 in the Waikiki Tower with 2 Queen Beds, a small but adequate bathroom, shower over the tub with grab rail, shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, coffee-maker, medium-size fridge, microwave, big TV, and a glimpse of the ocean as well as an interesting view of the building activity going on around the complex. I counted 5 cranes from our balcony. The hotel has a guest laundry, and some interesting tourist shops plus one with fresh and microwavable food. There is a Chinese restaurant on the same floor as the outdoor swimming pool. The hotel is used by flight crew so Reception can get busy at times. We booked direct with the hotel via its website and got a very favourable Senior's price

Great stay in Kona Tower; staff friendly & helpful; about to check out. Plantation restaurant good for breakfast; Japanese bar ok for a beer!Room light & airy; good shower & aircon; safe included plus comfortable queen bed.All in all a good 10 day stay

We stayed here for 3 nights for the last part of our US trip. The hotel was very clean although the bathrooms were very small. It is linked to the Ala Moana shopping centre which is great if you love shopping like me. However it is a little bit far from the main strip and beaches- probably a 15-20 minute walk. It was perfect for the last part of our trip but I think its a bit far from the action.

We recently stayed in this private apartment on the 33rd floor in Honolulu.It was beside the Ala Moana shopping centerThis was the best accommodation I have stayed in for a long time. We had a party of 8 and booked two apartments and ours was great in that it had so much space for all of us to get together whenever we wanted including for meals and socialising at night. It was very clean and had everything we needed including laundry.I could not recommend it highly enough.Thanks Kathy Australia.

We came for a convention at the nearby Convention Center and got a good deal on the room rate. I was frankly nervous because of some of the reviews but we had a great time. The room was fine, on the 24th floor with a sideways view of the Marina and ocean. I loved the flooring(slate tiles and Berber carpeting) because it was good on bare feet. The buffet breakfast, which was not included, was expensive but good, and we made good use of the fridge and microwave in the room for simple breakfasts and left-overs.The location turned out to be both good and bad: good for the proximity to the Convention Center and out of the madhouse of the center of Waikiki, but bad in that you had to take a cab or the bus for nearly everything else.I would be happy to stay here again, especially for a convention.

We stayed in the Kona Tower, 7th floor partial ocean view, very quiet but small room with queen bed, desk, large TV, armchair, fridge, coffee maker, ironing board,safe. free WIFI but $20 valet parking every day. No balcony and AC with quirks, had to call maintenance twice to adjust the AC which would shut off intermittently. Bed was too soft for my husband. Hotel needs a coffee shop, there's just no place to have a hot cup of coffee or snack. This is no frills lodging but the price is right for a short stay. Clean, convenient to the huge mall, so if you don't plan to spend much time in the room, a good place to stay. Service was fine in every way. Great Chinese restaurant.

I recently spent some time in Honolulu and stayed at the Ala Moana in Honolulu. The hotel is large and is well appointed for tourists and business alike. Tour operators can easily pick uou up here as well as being very good for a business location or an airline layover. About a 20 minute ride from the airport, the Ala Moana has stylish rooms in the Waikiki tower which contain refrigerators, mocrowaves, and comfortable bedding. The bathroom was clean and functional with just enough room to move around for two people though a little tight. The staff was pleasant and helpful. A good wait staff in the lobby area restaurant, and freindly and helpfull concierge round out a pleasant stay.If you want views you will need to ask for a high floor as the back faces the "city" which really is parking lots and dumpsters of the surrounding buildings. If it is wonderful views that you want you may want to look for another location.

Great Staff,Nice Lobby and Check in was quick. Breakfast spot was not good would recommend walking over to Ala Moana Mall and heading to the food court.Great Chinese Resturant in the Hotel. Good location if you need to go to the convention center(right across the street)

This hotel has a great location, next to Ala Moana Shopping Center. However, this is a heavily congested area, with construction at the shopping center and traffic at all time of the night. Have never had problems with staff, all friendly and efficient (including front desk, bellmen, valet service, housekeeping and maintenance). had problems with door locks/keys, had it changed twice. Other than that everything OK. Rates are not exorbitant, but one needs to know that this is not a five star hotel. Its a place where local people/residents would go. A reasonably priced hotel in a good location

Centrally located with a short walk to Ala Moana Beach Park and Ala Moana Shopping Center (shopping & restaurants) Stayed in the Kona Tower. Room was small, but decent for obe person. Room did have a refrigerator, coffee maker and microwave making it nice for an extended stay.

My husband and I are both senior citizens and we stayed at the Ala Moana for two nights before he went for eye surgery. We had a Kamaaina rate which is only $10.00 less then original rooms, so it's really no big discount, however we got a room that never should have been rented. There was construction going on all night. The sink plug was stuck. We called downstairs and they sent someone to fix it. By morning we noticed the toilet was leaking from the bottom and the sink faucets were also both leaking. We had to put towels around the bottom of the toilet so we could walk in the bathroom. We also had to put towels around the bottom of both faucets. We had to leave the hotel at 6:00A.M., and no one was at the front desk to help us.  By the time we got back from surgery, it was late and my husband just wanted to get to bed. The toilet and sinks still leaking and we put more towels around them. The next morning we had to leave again at 6:00A.M. and again we saw no staff. That evening I went down to the front desk to pay our bill and tell them about the problems. We even filled out one of those "room" forms they have and told them the problems with the room and deposited it in the lobby box. This happened 3 weeks ago and we never heard from AlaMoana Hotel although I asked for a response. They should have at least apologized and offered some compensation.

in the other part of the wourl ,i found the paradise near the beach,near the best and big shopping ala moana center,al most in the sky my bed room with singers birds,and people dancers and a very nice bar and splendid pool all the best the view the food,everythin perfect....

Have stayed here a few times. Nice hotel right next to Ala Moana shoping center. Nice to be not inWaikiki. Clean roms comfortable. The front desk can be rude though. We checked in late one time after runing a charter trip so we looked a bit worse for wear. The front desk staff were quite rude and turse. So take a word of advice dress nice. They will treat you better.

The two bedroom unit was well furnished, clean, functional, livable. Actually like home away from home, or rather condo away from condo....great view of the beach and the mountain. Kitchen was well equipped. The only thing was that we did it have a dining area in our unit. I mistakenly assumed that all units were the same. But that is not the case. While the units were furnished, the could've at least provided bath soap and shampoo like a hotel. The unit we stayed in was located on the 33rd floor. 3319 has better layout. We had 3313, and yes you can choose at time of booking. There is no daily cleaning - but they charge you a cleaning fee for each day of stay. Quite pricey! There is also a resort fee charge per day. Pool is okay but tiny. Not really worth being charged the resort fee.booked through Hawaii 50 website. Elevators can get packed on weekends...going down from the 333rd is not too bad, going up is another matter. Hotel has a connecting walk to the mall.

We stayed at the Ala Moana due to a very special price online. It is a fine, basic hotel if you plan on spending most of your time at the convention center or mall. It is, however, too far from Waikiki Beach and the other activities in the area. We had to drive and pay for parking or really get in our cardio that day to get close to the main area of Kalakaua Ave. It took about 15/20 minutes of walking just to get to the Hilton Village which is on the outskirts of the Waikiki area. We also found the noise level to be very high, especially on the weekend. For some reason, there seemed to be a party on the walkway to the mall on weekend nights. The room itself was a basic hotel room with microwave and dorm-size refrigerator. There is a gift shop down a hall on the first floor that sells food and gifts. Self-parking underground was $20/day and was oversold on the weekend. This hotel is fine for business travelers and there were a lot of airline personnel staying there.

I was accommodated in the Ala Moana Hotel for 14 nights. The hotel appears to cater to large parties of Tourists and some Aircrew. My mid evening check-in was fast, efficient but not particularly welcoming. The following evening, around the same time, a group arrival choked the check-in for nearly an hour. Given that, the room in Kona Tower was clean and appointed as expected, for a lower mid-range hotel. Location wise, it was for me, in a perfect position. Far enough from Waikiki to miss the madding crowd, but near enough to enjoy that area when desired. Easy for Friends to pick me up at the front foyer. The Shopping Centre a 2 minute walk over the 2nd Floor air bridge. Great Bars and restaurants on the 4th Floor of the Centre (use elevator rather than the confusing escalators!) I would stay there again on a future visit.

My husband and I were bumped from our Delta flight and given a night at the Ala Moana Hotel. Our all too brief stay was super! Everyone at the hotel was extremely nice. We were tired and the front desk clerk must have set a record for fastest check in ever. We were given an ocean view room on the 34th floor of the Waikiki Tower. The room was very clean, modern, and the A/C worked great. The king sized bed was very comfortable and we got a wonderful night's sleep. In the morning, we enjoyed the lovely view and the buffet breakfast at the Plantation Cafe. We were very pleased with the Ala Moana facilities and staff and would gladly return.

We stayed for one night. The last time I stayed at Ala Moana Hotel was about 10 years ago. Overall, it is evident they have remodeled and have improved tremendously. Our room was on the 9th floor. Our room was pleasantly quiet - no extraneous noise. View from the balcony was of the mountainside. Our room had a microwave, coffee maker, mini refrigerator, iron/board, hair blow dryer, flat screen TV and a few toiletries such as shampoo and conditioner. The room was comfortable for 2 people (had 2 double beds) however, a family of 2 adults and 2 children would be comfortable in this room. I did not use their amenities while here. We valet parked our car - the valet attendants were excellent and very attentive to guest needs. The hotel has a pedestrian ramp on the second floor which connects to the Ala Moana shopping center. It is extremely convenient to walk to restaurants and shops. It is also a 7 minute walk to the Ala Moana Beach Park where you can picnic or swim. I would definitely stay here again.

I arranged to attend a sailing course in Honolulu. The owner of the sailing school recommended that I stay at the Ala Moana Hotel. I looked for the Ala Moana Hotel via the website Booking.com and I made a booking for three nights stay in a room at the hotel. The hotel seemed to have what I required.However felt I there was something strange about the booking when I received email confirmation that stated the cost was US$ 388.05 and the number of guests would be 2 adults and 2 children. I responded immediately and restated that I was travelling alone. I received a confirmation response, for a modified reservation. When I arrived at the hotel the receptionist at the front desk informed me that the hotel could check me into the room, however the hotel would be in no way liable for my stay as my booking had been made through a company that owned condominiums. She further stated that I could not use the hotel services or other facilities provided by the hotel as I was a client of Luxury Suites International. LSI are a company based in Las Vegas USA. As a woman travelling on my own I prefer to use the facilities of a hotel such as room services, etc. The receptionist telephoned LSI whose response to me was that they had already taken my money and there was nothing that could be done. At that time the Ala Moana hotel was fully booked. So I reluctantly went up to the condo and found that two of the lights in the room were not working and there was no safe in the room. One of my first requirements in a hotel room is the use of a safe for my valuables, etc.I repeatedly tried to contact LSI on a number I later found out to be in Las Vegas. The Ala Moana hotel discharged responsibility for the situation. After many calls to the hotel reception, they found me a room in the hotel. The hotel charged me $30 for ringing LSI from the hotel phone. I did receive at least three calls from the Customer Service dept of Booking.com. I had left several messages for the LSI people but they wouldn't take my calls. I informed them by voice mail, that I had checked out of the condo and into the hotel. I have paid $780.31 US dollars to the Ala Moana hotel, for three night’s stay, which I was happy to pay because I was comfortable in my room and it had the facilities I was looking for in the first place. I am now disputing the amount of £375.67 with my credit card company which was taken out of my account and paid to LSI.

I have been staying at Ala Moana Hotel since 1983 when it was a lot more glamorous than it is today. It seemed to be declining in recent years but now has turned itself around without raising prices. Recent renovations have done much to improve the eye appeal of the property and although it does not make the rooms bigger it makes them brighter and cheerier with the best improvements to the bathrooms. The staff is hit and miss, the young lady who did my check in was distracted and did not look me in the eye; the man who checked me out was pure aloha. The reason I so often return is that I love the location. It is close to everything one needs and is not quite a touristy as Waikiki. You see plenty of local people who stay there as well as a lot of flight crews so you know it is a good hotel.

We've stayed at Ala Moana hotel many times during past 4 years. It's very nice hotel. Property has several restaurants to choose from, it's right by Ala Moana Mall, Wall- mart and the beach is right across the street. The location is just perfect for all your needs. The rooms are nice with a balcony. Stuff is very friendly. We will stay at this hotel again and again.

My wife and I stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel for four nights in April 2014. We had an oceanview room in the Waikiki Tower on a pretty high floor. It had a small balcony from which we could see the ocean and magic island.The room itself was fine. Reasonably large for Hawaii. Modern flat screen TV with a good selection of channels. Free wifi. Bedspreads/curtains looked a little dated. Room included both a microwave and small fridge, which was very helpful. Check-in may take a while depending on timing -- it seemed like they serve as a hotel for people who had cancelled/delayed flights.The hotel is in a good location if you're attending an event at the convention center or Ala Moana Shopping Center, or if you don't want to stay in Waikiki.We had a special rate for this hotel, but I'd consider staying here again.

The rooms were fine, clew but the bathroom a bit tired and in need of a revamp. A long way from anything other than the Ala Moana shopping centre, which adjoins the hotel. Bus services are fairly convenient, but the hotel is near the red light district and as a family with young children we weren't comfortable walking around after dark. It's about a 10 minute walk to the beginning of then strip in Honolulu. I would suggest paying a little more and staying in the main hotel strip, we were stuck with some very ordinary meal choices either at the hotel or the shopping centre.

United put us up here after a delayed flight. We were dead tired after airline ordeals, Ala Moana put us in a handicapped room, next to elevators and the key cards did not work. We call the front desk twice and have to wait for security in the hall for 30 minutes. No new key cards were brought? We had to go back to the desk and were issued new cards, these did not work either, called the desk again, waited another 25 minutes, security checked my ID again and says they will send maintenance to fix lock. I politely decline and take bags to front desk and ask for another room. They put us on another floor in another handicapped room next to the noisy elevators again! The keys did work, but we were too tired to move to another room and had to be up at 3:30am to get ready for early flight, I am 6'2" and the shower head came to my stomach, the noisy elevators and partyiers kept us up all night and made it easy to get up at 3:30 am. I would have enjoyed speaking with manager about being treated like riff-raff, but was much too tired at the time. I will never ever set foot in this hotel, and have advised United not to use this hotel.

The Ala Moana is located about a block and a half from the big convention center. It's also hooked through a parking garage entrance to the big Ala Moana Shopping Center. So yup, it's convenient. Ala Moana Park is just down the block and all the crowds and mess of Waikiki is not too far a walk away. The rooms are decent sized if not overly large, and most seem to have a small balcony. Our room had a view of the beach and ocean, although they were viewed through the gaps between other big buildings and were a fair distance off. It's not beach front, but it's a decent place with reasonable rates for a Honolulu hotel.

We stayed at this hotel for three days while over on Oahu for business. The rooms are small but functional. The fitness center is great and has sauna and steam room. Pool is small and no jacuzzi but it is very clean and well maintained. The hotel is connected to the shopping center which is very convenient and walmart is just behind. Internet was included and no resort fees but parking was expensive. I left a valuable necklace behind and although it was a hassle finding the right person in Security to talk to..... I did get it back safely. That was pretty honest! We will definitely stay here again.

US Air put us up at this hotel after a delayed flight. Everything went wrong from the get go. Tried to get in our room and the keys didn't work. It's late we are exhausted and stuck standing in the hallway. Called from a hall phone and the front desk said they would send security....10 mins later called again...."Oh they are busy right now you will have to wait" WHAT? Security finally shows up and treats us like we are riff raff, wants our IDs, calls the front desk, reads and spells our names out repeatedly to someone on his radio, keeps us waiting and waiting giving us the fish eye like we are trying to break into the place. Finally lets us in with no apologies for THEIR SCREW UP!! Then a maintenance man comes up and works on the stupid lock for 30 mins, has to come back twice. All we got was attitiude from the front desk...We were supposed to get a convenience pack of toothbush, etc....had to call twice for that. We were issued vouchers for meals...oh sorry "THOSE" participating restaurants are closed.you are SOL. The bathroom door is rotten and peeling at the bottom and there is a crappy caulk job trying to cover the mold. Feels like a Motel 6. I am certainly going to let US Air know to NOT use this place again.

Terrific location, nice facilities, near Ala Moana park, huge shopping mall and great views from Signature restaurant on 32nd floor with piano bar. Room quite small but adequate and compared to other hotels in Waikiki quiet

We just had a very good stay at the Ala Moana Hotel in Honolulu.*Full disclosure here that I was one of the lucky ones that managed to get the special $10.00 room rates.I wasn't honestly expecting a lot at the price we paid, but we had a very nice room on an upper floor, with a private balcony with a table and 2 chairs and a view that went 180 degrees from the hills to Waikiki. The room was clean, comfortable, with a good bed, small kitchen area and even a couch/table and chair inside with a sitting area. The room was impeccably cleaned everyday and one my biggest comments about hotels of this era is usually the quality of the air and air conditioning units. Often they are noisy and start/stop to maintain the room temperature - and this was the opposite - very good overall. The pool area and gym area was well appointed and the towel service which we used everyday for the beach was excellent.Access to the Ala Moana Mall is the best - I don't think you could be any closer to the best shopping in Hawaii, with more parking than you'll ever need. There's also valet parking for a small fee and if you don't mind walking a short distance, you can also find free overnight street parking.The added bonus was the access and proximity to the Ala Moana Park which is directly across the street. For those that enjoy swimming in the ocean, there is a dedicated 1000 metre swimming lane at the beach that's 100% protected from the waves. You can walk to the main Waikiki Beach area in about 10 or 15 minutes.The Happy Hour at the The Signature Restaurant on the top floor of the hotel was an added bonus. Good food, drink and one of the best views in Honolulu.Special thanks to Judy Pereira and GM Bill Comstock for handling a tough situation when the reservation system crashed on this deal offer.I would definitely recommend this hotel.

Don't let the title fool you, the stay and experience was great! But because we were next to the elevator, the room seemed smaller than the other room we rented. Highly recommend this place if you're going to KAWAII Kon since it's literally right down the street

Stayed at the HOTEL through Hawaii 5-0 VACATION RENTALS. Was the perfect location for a first visit and being solo. Went down to the ALA MOANA SHOPPING MALL and food court often.The bus services are all there for anyone taking THE BUS. ALA MOANA PARK is right down the street has a local feel to it. Great for running, walking, relaxing. The pool was clean and nice. The check in and out was really speedy as are the elevators. The room had a fantastic view from the back. Very clean and great kitchenette... I love Honolulu!!!

Stayed at this hotel because it was a short walk to the convention center where a conference I attended was held. The hotel overall was clean and welcoming. Nice to have refrigerator and microwave in room. The elevators were super speedy and the guest room in which I stayed was clean and comfortable. Easy walk to the Ala Moana shopping center where nice restaurants and high-end shops are located (as well as food court). Short walk to the Ala Moana park and beach area, which was pleasant to visit on a Saturday afternoon. Early morning garbage trucks outside (with their beep, beep, beep) annoying, but overall, a pleasant stay.

I was here for a conference. The hotel is convenient to a large shopping centre, and a short walk to the start of Waikiki Beach. The staff were very helpful and pleasant. The check-in and check-out were very swift. The rooms are clean. The pool is on a large deck, with nice winds to cool the pool experience. If I was back for a conference i would have no problem staying here, if I was vacationing I would be beside the beach.

On first impressions, this is an unassuming hotel, but once you have entered there is a lovely spacious lounge and reception area. The rooms are very well appointed and comfortable and we had a good view of the sea despite being quite far back from it.
