The furnishings seemed new although the bed was covered with an old-style bedspread. I liked having a coffee maker, microwave and fridge in the room (note, when using the coffee maker, it's important that the lid be on the pot while brewing!). My partial-view room mostly had a view of the other tower and a parking lot, but I was able to see the ocean too, so I guess partial-view is an accurate description!The high-speed Internet was free (yay!) but not wireless. I was barely able to get the cable to stretch far enough so I could stretch out on the bed while using my laptop. The exercise room was quite nice, modern and clean, with several cardio machines and weight machines. The gift shops had all the essentials as well as a good selection of non-essential gifty items. It was great to be able to walk back and forth from the convention center easily. The mall with its shops and restaurants was also close by. For runners/walkers, Ala Moana Park is just a couple of blocks away, and you can get about three scenic miles in by going there and following the path around its perimeter. Cab rides to the Waikiki Beach area are around $6-10 but it's not a bad walk either. Overall, I had an enjoyable stay at Ala Moana and would stay there again for business trips involving the convention center.

- booked a city view for the first night, then paid extra for a "partial ocean view" in waikiki tower for the remainder of the week. they kept me in the same room for the week, which overlooked the macy's parking lot and was very noisy. when i requested to move to the partial ocean view room as originally booked, i was told that i should remain in the city view room, in part because it was "easier for housekeeping". - then paid extra again to move to a full ocean view room. which was primarily a view of the building across the street.- when asked for a late checkout (all i needed was 15-30min due to a meeting) i was just told "no", because it was easier for people checking in.- no room service- not clean. a big clump of hair stuck in the towel. gross.- next to a mall which was fine, but also a bunch of "spas" (not the kind you take your daughter to...)

I stayed at the Ala Moana hotel on business. It was the off season and the hotel was not crowded. The Ala Moana is located across the street from the Honolulu Convention Center. I booked what was probably the cheapest room available and stayed in the hotel for a total of 7 nights. No ocean view. The room was small but clean. Despite what some reviewers have posted, the Ala Moana hotel has a lot going for it. Ala Moana park is across the street and there are great walking and jogging paths, even swimming, if you want to get a bit further away from all the tourists in Waikiki. A simple walk across the parking lot gets you to the Ala Moana shopping mall where there is an amazing food court, not to mention a Food Land market and pretty much anything else you might need for a business stay. This is not downtown Waikiki. It is safe to walk in the mall and around the hotel. One one side there are some seedy-looking massage parlors but it is safe. If you need to be close to the convention center I highly recommed the Ala Moana hotel.

As the title says, if you want shopping at the Ala Moana Centre, or need to go to a conference at the Hawaii Conference Centre, this is your hotel. I needed both, and the hotel did its job perfectly well. View not much to speak of - some ocean to the right, through some buildings, the rest of the sort of rampant over-development that has ruined Waikiki. Free breakfasts are always a plus, you can't stay closer to the Ala Moana, my wife's favourite place in Hawaii, Walmart is also close, the conference centre is very close, and if you want the beach Ala Moana is nicer than Waikiki and all its tourists. Waiting for check-in took a while, but as lots of people were arriving for a major conference, that is to be expected. The microwave in my room *did* work, and I have no complaints about the facilities except to suggest they get handheld showers rather than fixed. There's not a lot to say about this place. It's not that cheap, but then this isn't a cheap area. It did its job perfectly well, it has a great location for the non-touristy stuff, and the breakfast buffet isn't bad either.

Since my arrival on April 9, 2011 I asked for a wake up call and it was always 10-20 minutes later than I asked for until one day they decided not to call at all, this was despite the fact that i personally went to the front desk to ask for a wake up callBecause of their incompetence i missed my breakfast meeting at the conference which cost me $145.00. i complained to the manager Darryl and he promised to investigate what happened and would inform me but never did. I would assume they do this all the time thus it was not an issue to them.In case they read this i stayed in room 656.the rooms are also very small, good for an individual traveler.On the day of my departure there were 3 janitorial service individual just talking and did not even know that one of the elevator was full of vomit, unfortunately that was the elevator that came up to the 6th floor. I had to tellthem that there was vomit in the elevator and on the lobby level in the floor adjacent to the door of the elevator whcih they should have noticed if they were doing there job.I would not recommend this hotel to anyone if you have an issue with the hotel, the onsite managers do nothing

There is nothing but a clean room. View of parking lots and tagged buildings. If you are lucky you will get a view of the boats in the harbor... Good luck seeing the beach. You must walk a few miles for that. NO night club, no food service, and no service period. Not safe to walk around at night there so unless you want a place without service or tropical settings... dont go here. The pool is awful, no water service or food. Close to shopping if you like the large stores you already have at home.They do have ice machines... Microwaves do not work, and there is nothing to buy for food but junk food at very high prices in the little gift/store in the lobby.

We tooked the "red Eye" from Las Vegas and arrived at HNL early in the AM. we arrived at Ala Moana about 7:00 AM, and we were tired. We were told that our room would not be ready until the PM but they could give us a room at a higher price. This is OK if there was in fact no room available at our agreed rate but in the light of the disaster in Japan, we could not believe that the rooms were sold out the night before. I think we were had.

Paid $163 total per night through HotelClub for a Waikiki Tower room hoping it would be spacious for 2 adults and 2 kids, but it was pretty tight with the two double beds taking up 90% of the floorspace. One problem is the hallway/closet/bathroom take up about 30-40% of the entire total.Pros:Renovated not so long ago, so still is pretty clean and tidy.Proximity to mall, not far from park and beach. Mall with food court is next door.Very convenient to convention center.Shuttle stop at mall for trolleys.Cons:Tiny room (older Kona Tower) or small rooms (newer Waikiki Tower).Ocean view was obstructed, and partial ocean view is just a silver of sea in the distance. A bit far for walking to Waikiki beach (15-25 min).Pool a bit chilly for kids.

I wasn't expecting much so it wasn't a big surprise that I didn't enjoy my stay. The check in was a very bad experience. When I finally got to the counter, after over an hours wait, I was told that my room wasn't ready but if I wanted I could upgrade. I asked what I would get for the extra cost of the upgrade and was told "a room now". Isn't that borderline blackmail?There is nothing remarkable about the hotel. The rooms were below average and noisy and the service was bad. The only thing it has going is the proximity to the mall.

After travelling overnight from Australia we were very disappointed with this hotel. Thankfully it was only a one night stay. The hotel is very outdated, both furnishings and fittings. The hot water ran out after one shower. The tour desk lady did not seem to understand English and I walked away totally confused. We stayed for one night pre cruise and stayed post cruise opposite Waikiki beach which I would recommend as this is where the better restaurants and shops are.

Typically when I travel for work I don't have a rental car, so the Ala Moana Hotel is a great place for me! Anything a traveler needs is available on the property, and it's adjacent to the amazing Ala Moana Shopping Center, a short drive to Ward Center and Ward Warehouse (shopping) and all that Waikiki has to offer. The rooms are generally on the small side, but they're clean and modern. Internet is free, there are special rates for kama`aina, elders, and others. The staff is professional. When my hair dryer didn't work I called housekeeping and had a working hair dryer in a few minutes. The in-room microwave and fridge were great for me - I had dinner leftovers for breakfast.For business travel or shopping, it's wonderful. For fun, there is plenty to do, but when I go to O`ahu just for fun I prefer to stay in Waikiki.

_This was the recommended hotel for the HIM (Hawaiian Islands Ministries) conference._The staff was very pleasant and professional._It was so convenient to walk to the convention center and to the mall for coffee, lunch, dinner and shopping.

The hotel provides easy access to the Ala Moana Shopping Center. Who doesn't like a shopping center. Lots of places to eat and shop there. The lobby was very comfortable with many seating areas to lounge. I don't normally lounge in lobbies but because your so tired from hanging at the mall it's a great place to come back to and people watch. The hotel customers are very diverse - from all over the world as well as local.

It's not a touristy hotel, but it's got a great location on the outskirts of Waikiki adjoining the Ala Moana Shopping Center and just minutes from the Hawaii Convention Center. When we stay at this hotel, it's purely for the location benefits (for the annual HIM Conference at the Convention Center). Our room wasn't anything special, but it was clean and comfortable and suited us fine. My complaints were that the TV was small, not that it mattered much to me, and the air in the room was dry and very cold even when the air conditioner was turned off. I was shivering under the blankets for much of the night, but the beds were comfortable enough. We had a view of the swimming pool and of the Convention Center where we could watch each other walking to and from the center from the balcony. There were hardly any people in the pool, which was just a small blue rectangle that looked too cold to swim in. Not the most upscale hotel and fairly expensive for what it offers, but I would recommend it to business travelers or anyone going to a convention at the Center.

Spent four nights here on our way back to Australia from San Francisco. First stayed at the Ala Moana in 1977 so thought it was time to return! We had a room in the Kona Tower. The room, although quite small was clean had all we needed. The refrigerator and microwave were much appreciated. Breakfast in the restaurant was great and reasonably priced....hot eggs and crispy bacon and seniors discount ! We enjoyed walking to Waikiki and the shopping and food court at the Ala Moana Mall. Took a tour around the island which we booked from the hotel foyer. We hope to stay here again one day !

This condo was in a nice location if you want to be away from central Waikiki but still close to the action, transportation and shopping. Ala Moana shopping mall was part of our view as well as the ocean. Ala Moana Park was just two blocks away with nice swimming and the park itself was nice. Can watch the Friday night fireworks from here as well. Hotel staff was a little reluctant to help us because this is a privately rented condo but we managed to get the information we needed from them. Unit was clean, could use a second hand towel. Pool and weight room were clean and easily accessible. Pool felt cool until I finally swam in the ocean and they're about the same so can't complain. Also, it's hard to tell from the hotel site pictures but the deck area is huge and there is shade.

Four of us stayed at privately-owned unit 807 in the Ala Moana Hotel. The hotel location was a perfect base for touring or shopping at the Ala Moana shopping center, which is connected by a walkway. The room had a great view and had a sufficiently stocked kitchen. Everything seemed to be perfect until we went to bed on the first night. The king bed in the bedroom was just fine, but the mattress on the sofa bed was very uncomfortable – thin, hard and lumpy.We called the property manager the next day and requested roll away beds or a replacement sofa bed. She mentioned that no one has ever complained before; otherwise they would have taken a pro-active approach. We learned that the Ala Moana hotel does not have rollaway beds, so we were given the option of switching to a studio or another one-room suite which had the same foot print and furniture as our suite; she noted that the sofa bed might be the same, though. We wanted to be reasonable and make it easy for everyone, so we opted to stay in our room because we decided to pile blankets and pillows on the mattress for added padding.Unfortunately, on the second night, the sofa bed frame actually fell apart and my husband fell into the middle of the frame. If it wasn’t so unfortunate, the whole situation was almost laughable. We called the property manager the next morning and a maintenance person was sent in the afternoon to fix the frame. The following day, another maintenance person came by to deliver another mattress to put on top of our sofa bed mattress. Overall, the property managers did a good job of trying to rectify the situation. The unfortunate thing is that our sleep was terribly uncomfortable during the whole stay and with the added surprise of the frame falling apart, we really didn't feel rested during this vacation.I had requested one day of towel service after the first night and the property manager waived the $30 fee (which, by the way, is a really steep towel service fee) as a concession for the uncomfortable mattress. She was willing to do this even before the frame incident.The condo itself would have been perfect, but when I think about the overall stay, I would not stay there again. This is really unfortunate as our family travels all the time and Oahu is one of our frequent destinations. I've experienced all kinds of hotel sofa beds in my travels, but this rated as one of the most uncomfortable. If you’re considering this unit and plan to use the sofa bed, be sure to check whether the mattress was replaced/upgraded. If it was, then it might be a worthwhile stay. If you plan to use only the bedroom, then you'll be fine. If not for the uncomfortable sleep that cast a shadow upon an otherwise wonderful vacation, I would have been able to highly recommend this unit.As a side note, I also received quotes for other privately-owned properties at the Ala Moana Hotel after I had already committed to unit 807. Two other quotes (with rooms on higher floors) came in with a cleaning fee that was half the cost of ours.

The Ala Moana is a favorite of mine because it is conveniently located, clean, comfortable and affordable. This time it turned out to be safe as well. When the tsunami warning was issued, I called the front desk and they were calm and helpful, letting me know the Ala Moana is just outside the inundation area and it is a designated safe shelter. They advised me that as long as I was above the 2nd floor and I had food and water, I should be fine to stay and not evacuate. I got water from the gift shop, pizza delivered by Round Table, and comfotably watched the progress of the disaster on television throughout the night. All in all, I felt they were well informed and helpful--and it was much less traumatic because of it.

The Ala Moana Hotel is conveniently attached to the Ala Moana Shopping Center (Honolulu's largest) by a "skybridge" and the convenience of the Ala Moana Shopping Center is only appreciated after travelling into Waikiki (approximately 2 miles) and recognizing that if hotel guests want to purchase groceries and other consumable items at reasonable prices, the best place is in and around the Ala Moana Shopping Center.The Ala Moana Hotel was renovated recently and the rooms present with a uncluttered European atmosphere. Having booked through Priceline, I took the opportunity to confirm my booking by calling the hotel directly to confirm the reservation and spoke to the hotel's Customer Service Manager Darrel. Upon arriving at the hotel, I was informed that I was being provided with a complementary upgrade which provided me with a full ocean view. I would like to thank Darrel and the Ala Moana Hotel and Staff for being so accommodating and for making stay so pleasant. The Non-smoking room contained the following:1 king bed. Premium bedding. Desk. In-room safe. Complimentary wired Internet access. TV with premium cable/satellite channels and pay movies. Video-game console. Phone with voice mail. Clock radio. Microwave and refrigerator. Coffee/tea maker. Hair dryer. Iron/ironing board. Blackout drapes/curtains. Air conditioning and climate control.The rack rate on the room is around $329.00 but the Priceline rate was approximately 65% below that. I have attached pictures for the reader's benefit.I would recommend this hotel to anyone who wants to get away from the congestion of Waikiki Beach, yet have easy access to Waikiki Beach, should they desire.

Whether taking a dip in the 3rd floor pool, shopping next door at the vast Ala Moana shopping centre or reclining on our 34th floor apt balcony sipping champagne and feasting on the fantastic views across the city and ocean...we had another great visit to this lovely US state. Dinner at ROYS in the Embassy Sands Hotel was also a special treat. Being close to the bus depot we caught more buses than taxis which saved us a fair bit of cash.

I first stayed here, renting a condo with friends, 5 years ago and was thrilled to fine it's still top class when I stayed for 1 night in a hotel room last week. Luxury accommodation without the huge price tag. Rooms are big with all the amenities and pleasant balconies. The connection to the nearby Ala Moana Mall is simple and useful plus it's a short walk to the Waikiki neighborhood, while staying away from all the noise. We look up Outrigger and Ohana-brand hotels everywhere we go and are never disappointed.

As we entered the fresh atmosphere of the lobby we were greeted by hospitable and friendly people in the counter. We asked the lady to give us a room from 15th floor and above to have a quiet and peaceful time and she put us on the 18th floor, Awesome! We had an ocean view with this chic and modern guestroom with tropical setting. Time to grab something to eat and we headed to the Ala Moana shopping center just a walked away and find fastfood of different varieties in a very reasonable prices. We then checked for some bistro restaurants and fine dining on the list for our dinner, before stopping by to one of the grocery store located in the shopping mall to get some snacks and drinks. The hotel has a mini refrigerator, microwave and coffee maker. The modern fitness center and spa are some of our favorite amenities. After a steam bath, we felt rejuvenated and relax as we sit in our lanai overlooking the ocean with its slight breeze sipping kona coffee paired with the hot malasada. Strolling along Waikiki is a good sightseeing past time, but if you want to unwind and immerse yourself to an island relaxation go to the Ala Moana beach just across the hotel, or stay in the hotels clean and spacious sundeck with its large swimming pool and poolside bar. We're glad we stayed in this hotel and booked to their official web site and happy not getting ripped off.We love Hawaii ... weather of sunny mornings, cool in the afternoon with mild humidity, fresh air w/ little winds, coconut trees and other tropical plants in the background, clean and beautiful beaches, happy and hospitable people, authentic food w/ its fresh fruits and vegetables ... what a comfort to the soul, making you come back over n over again and dreaming of living in the island.

Positives:1. Free internet connection via ethernet cable, no WiFi2. Room clean and cool3. Bed comfortable and clean4. Good value for price compared to Waikiki hotels which cost twice as much5. Close to mallNegatives:1. Noisy; Walls are thin; You can hear conversations and the tv next door2. Around 4-5am... the drunk guests roll in from the club downstairs or nearby, and they woke us up with their obnoxious yelling.

I stayed six nights for a conference at the Hawaii Convention Center down the street and I had a great experience. The hotel is located outside of the main strip in Waikiki; it's a 15 minute walk to the shopping district on Kalakaua and Waikiki Beach. The hotel itself is adjacent to the large Ala Moana Shopping Mall. Ala Moana Park and beach are a one-block walk. The hotel staff were friendly and very helpful.

Overall, a nice place, with good prices for a Honolulu hotel near the Convention Center (where my meetings were). But it suffered due to having guests pay for Internet connections, either the Wi-Fi available only in the lobby area, or at the desktop computers in the Business Center.Also, the outdoor pool closed at sunset, which was lame. No hot tub, but had a sauna and a steam room adjacent to an above-average fitness center.

I didn't have high expectations, but I knew the hotel would provide exactly what I needed, which was a place to sleep. The front desk staff was friendly and helpful during check-in, but prior to that time they were not very service-oriented on the phone. Requests for an earlier than 3pm were flatly denied, with no offers to see what they can do, no upselling (appreciated but a missed opportunity to upsell in my opinion), and no offer to use a hospitality room while my room was being readied. Once checked in, however, staff was very polite and friendly.I rated sleep low because the pillows were bad (!), the bed was not level (my head was lower than my feet), and the guests in the next room chose to slam their door shut rather than close it quietly. All of these can definitely be improved, including the door shutting. A door closer is already installed so it would be a matter of adjusting it so the door does not close so quickly.All in all, the price was right, the hotel is right next to the shopping mall and in walking distance to basically anything you need. I did not eat at the hotel or utilize any of their other facilities.

I just returned from the Ala Moana and I wouldn't recommend it. Although we did get a good deal on Priceline, we found out at check-in that for us to get a room with two beds would have been an additional $40 a night. I have used Priceline on many occassions have never had this issue before. But, having said that, I can adequately review this hotel on their other shortcomings, not just this policy. The location is fine. I actually didn't mind it. We were only sleeping in the area, so we didnn't need to be right beside the cheesy and touristy shops of Waikiki. I didn't even mind the smallness of the room. I do, however, have a problem, with ill-flushing toilets, blood stains on my pillow, random hairs everywhere that were NOT mine, and the lack of overall care and courtesy found by the staff. The pool is closed, the nightclub is beyond bad, and the place just looks tired. No sense of Aloha here, that is for sure. But, hey, it was a bed and fairly cheap, and that's really the best thing I can say about this place.

I was excited for my first visit to Hawaii to stay at a 4 star hotel. The first impression of the Ala Moana was a snooty check-in girl "Jennifer". The room was very small but at least the partial view was amazing! The microwave shot sparks, the coffee pot is weird, there was mold outside of the bathroom, which they swear wasn't mold, and they kept calling me to confirm our address which we gave them at least three times. I did like the fact that it is attached to the most vast mall I think I've ever seen and just a 3-4 minute walk to the park with a small beach. I would say that there are much better places to stay for what you would spend here.

I could not of asked for a better location and for the price it was outstanding! The room was clean and staff was extremely friendly. I particurlarly liked the fact that it was so close to the beach and to the Ala Moana Mall that made everything so great. I could not of asked for better accomidations.
user_name:
m1a1lg
Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona

review_body: My wife and I already had a leisure trip in Honolulu. Ala Moana Hotel is an excellent accessible point. TheBus terminal is nearby Ala Moana Shopping Center which is just next to the hotel. We can take TheBus to go anywhere in O'ahu very easily. If you don't want to stay in hotel for a very long time and decide to go outside for different kinds of activities, Ala Moana is that your choice.

The unit was wonderful and the location was not bad 20minute walk to Waikiki, and we had a car some it easy to navigate on the Island..My biggest complaint and is huge; when you rent the the private units condos the hotels does not extend any customers service previlages, house cleaning, equipment failures plumbing etc. I inquired about house cleaning for two days. They said i could purchase it for sevens days or not at all and to contact the owner. . We had an electrical problem and I was informed to contact the owner in the San Francisco, and he had to get on the phone and have a not to pleasant conversation in order for them to assist us :)

I was happy to stay in the Ala Moana Hotel. I liked the location - convenient to Ala Moana Beach (a public beach about 10 minutes walking from the hotel), a mall (food court and grocery store so we saved money not eating in restaurants) and a 20 minute walk from Waikiki (didn't really like the beach or the area - reminded me of Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills), the state capitol, the self-directed Obama walking tour and the convention center. The hotel had a refrigerator and oven, housekeeping services were excellent, and it seemed like a very well-managed and maintained facility. The only "negative" that I had was some construction noise across the street, which, of course, wasn't the hotel's fault and there was no room service although there was a restaurant in the hotel. We had a lovely balcony. One more thing: the TV screen was a little small for a big room (if you watched TV in bed). The pool was lovely. All around, it was a super hotel.
user_name:
Susan W
New York City, New York

review_body: Ala Moana Hotel was the cheapest (within reason) hotel offered to me through a package deal on Priceline. Based on the photos and the reviews, I decided to give it a go.  Let me start by saying that the interior of the hotel is lovely. The decor in the lobbies, halls, and rooms is quite nice and the hotel staff were kind and eager to help. The mattress was perfect: not too firm, not too soft. If mall-shopping is your thing, this is the hotel for you, as it has a walkway to the large Ala Moana Shopping Center. One of the other upsides is a very close-by 7-11 we often used to get supplies in the morning (water, caffeine, and Sudafed, since we were both sick).Now, here's where it gets a little hinky. I paid extra for a room with a "partial ocean view". What I got was a view of the marina, and constant noise from the parking garage attached to the shopping center, so we couldn't leave the sliding glass door open. Parking in the garage downstairs is going to run you $20 a day. Don't both with the Plantation Cafe breakfast buffet available just outside of the lobby: we were both pretty disappointed in the quality considering the $15/each pricetag.While within walking distance of a small beach with a sunset view, the walk itself leaves a little to be desired: Used condoms, homeless, and garbage abound. Those themes followed through to the neighborhood surrounding the hotel with a few "day spas" that doubled as strip clubs once the sun went down.All in all, if you're going to one of the most beautiful beach islands in the world to go shopping... stay at the Ala Moana. If you want to lay in the sun and the sand.... you might look elseware.

Stayed here for conference in November 2010. It is very convenient to the Convention Center (about a block away). Hotel is very clean and comfortable. It is connected to a very high-end shopping mall. Our room was small, but clean and comfortable. Hotel hooked us up with a shuttle to Pearl Harbor. Very inexpensive and convenient. Only downside is that it is not really part of Waikiki beach and the neighborhood is still in need of renovation. There are a number of homeless people that frequent the park about a block to the south. Out our window we had a view of the go-go bars and run-down neighborhood. If you are taking taxis this wouldn't be an issue, but it doesn't look like an area you would want to stroll through at night. Not a problem during the day.

Booked special Kamaaina rate. Requested 2 double beds. Upon check in was told category I booked had no double beds...BUT for an additional $40 per day, I could get my requested 2 doubles. Felt they were nickel and diming me! Not appreciating my buisness! Room was not worth the additional $40 per day. Parking was overpriced.Not a happy experience.

After reading many reviews I was a little apprehensive about staying here, but we were going for my husband's work and he had a budget and they were the best-priced. Upon our arrival we were pleased to be upgraded to a partial ocean view. When we got to our room it was a full ocean view! The room was small, but very clean with no weird odors. We had a small fridge and a microwave which was very helpful. We also had a lanai that looked out to the Ala Moana shopping center as well as Ala Moana park.We had air conditioning that worked really well and the bed and pillows were great!I actually got a little cold the first night and would have liked to have a plumper bed covering or blanket. I sleep with a down alternative at home and I like the plushness.We had no trouble with valet parking. We ate at the only restaurant that was open at the hotel Saturday night when we arrived and it was very authentically Chinese, not my favorite, but it was good. A little pricey though.Our room was always PROMPTLY cleaned even though we left our room available at odd hours of the day.It is VERY convenient to the wonderful Ala Moana mall which has loads of places to eat. A couple of places deliver to the hotel which is nice as there is no room service.There is a gift shop with snacks and drinks that actually was reasonably priced. You will need your key to use the elevator, at least in the Waikiki Tower where we stayed.There was some traffic noise when the lanai doors were open and there is a bar at the mall that had bands each night that we could somewhat hear. If it got too loud we simply shut the doors.My absolute biggest complaint is about the pool. It was very basic, not so beautiful, but more than that, it has no steps, only four ladders. I thought this was strange and made entry difficult. Also it is NOT heated and while it is Hawaii and the outside temps were warm, the pool was COLD! Too cold to enjoy or even get into after sunning.Overall, for price, it was a good experience.

We live on the Big Island and stay at the Ala Moana Hotel on our trips to "the city". The location is the best being connected to the Ala Moana Shopping center and just across the street from the Ala Moana Park. If shopping is your thing, it's the best. If running or swimming is your thing, it is just across the street. Rooms are clean although we did not get wash cloths on our second day as they were "out of them". Nice sunning area and pool if you don't want to walk across the street to the beach. $20 a day for parking is a little much but at least your car is in a secure spot for the night.

My wife and I go to Honolulu regularly to visit close relatives, and this January (2011) we stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel. The location of this property is supreme being right next door to the largest shopping mall around, and literally across the street from one of the nicest parks which Honolulu has to offer . . . and across from the ocean to boot. Free internet access was a real plus, and because the hotel has vacancies in their hotel stores (I suppose this bad economy has hit Honolulu, too) the place is relatively quiet. There were very few tourists in sight, though it looks like the airlines use this hotel for their staffs. We felt safe and loved the location though we paid $20 daily for parking.

the rooms were decent & good value for the rates charged. Good location, near trolley bus & the Ala Moana beach park a few minutes walk. Very poor concierge with no ideas other than to try & sell overpriced tours. Best to do your own resarch & contact tour companies directly. Hotel staff reasonably friendly

Close to shopping mall with wonderful food court, bus transport, and beaches. We felt we received good value for our money and would certainly stay there again. The only downside is our room was very small.

We stayed at the Ala Moana hotel for 5 nights since my partner was attending a conference at the Conference center. It was only a 5 minute walk away which was great.The hotel was clean, had basic amenities and was close by to a mall and the Ala Moana park for swimming or just walking. It was a 15-20 min walk to Waikiki. There was a fitness center in the hotel which was decent for a hotel fitness center. There was also a pool, but it was very cold! They have a towel service and you can borrow their towels to go to the beach which was helpful.There are a few restaurants attached to the hotel which was convenient, and a microwave and fridge in the room which we used so that we could have breakfast and some snacks in the room. The people at the hotel were friendly, but didn't know much about the public transportation system. They sell all kinds of tours, but you can find the same tours for cheaper if you look through the different brochures on activities of things to do in Honolulu.Our room had a tiny balcony and we could sit outside and enjoy the mountains.There was a business center in the hotel; however, they don't manage it. So if you wanted to use the internet and don't have your own computer, you have to pay. They do have internet in the rooms, but it's not wireless.They say the rates start at $109, but we didn't see any rooms for that price. I don't think the price was all that great, but it wasn't bad. Overall, a decent place to stay.
Very convenient location to Ala Moana Center,Waikiki and local transportation.We felt very welcomed by the staff and housekeeping were very through in tiding our room

Nice property, near the convention center, a high end mall and lots of Japanese restaurants. Paid $80 a night via United.com for a condo room (same as hotel guest rooms, only privately owned) with a king bed, balcony, brand new bathroom and furniture. A good deal.Primarily Japanese guests (like 80%) and lots of tour crowds, but affluent and polite.About a mile walk from Waikiki Beach. Internet connection in rooms (ethernet) but no free Wi-Fi. Starbucks is in the adjacent mall.Best advice: Skip Waikiki, rent a car and drive to the North Shore to spend the day on a secluded and beautiful beach.TIP: Park on a side street near the nearby convention center and save $30 a day in hotel parking.

The last time I stayed at this hotel was more than 20 years ago. The only thing I remembered about that trip was that the hotel was next to the mall, and it was not within walking distance from Waikiki. Twenty years later, things have not changed much. I took the bus from the airport and got off at the mall. Check in was efficient, but not particularly friendly. All the receptionist was concerned with was getting a copy of my credit card. My questions about "when is check out time" and "how to get to Waikiki" were answered, rather bluntly, even before I finished asking the question. My room was located at the back of the hotel and had no view (therefore only $99 a night). The room was small, but adequate for a solo traveler. It has a microwave to heat water with, but the old-school a/c was noisy enough that I had to turn it off at night.I took the 'cable car trolley bus" that shuttles people from ala moana shopping center to Waikiki, but not after standing in line for about 30 minutes. All my meals were taken at the mall.A no nonsense, rather dated, high rise hotel, with a mall next to it. Convenient for shopping, yes; convenient for everything else, not particularly. I spent 20 dollars more last year when I visited Hawaii and stayed at a hotel in Waikiki, and I think that's what I will do next time. There's more to do in Waikiki and I can always take the shuttle to ala moana shopping center from Waikiki.
I had a very comfortable stay here once again. Great location for shopping.
Had a great time and close to shopping, beach and for relaxation. I stay here whenever I go to Oahu.

This hotel is not on the beach, but the Ala Moana beach & harbor are just down the block. The hotel is right next to the Ala Moana Mall, which offers many low budge dining opportunities and lots of shopping.I actually lived in this hotel for 4 months back in 1995 while working in Honolulu. I returned in 2010 to find the rooms remodeled very nicely. The room had a refrigerator and microwave. The airconditioning was quiet and we did not have any noise from other guests permeating our room.Our room in the Kona tower overlooks a couple of strip clubs. This did not bother us, as the mountains are in the distance. We didn't spend a whole lot of time in the room anyway, we were always out and about. The swimming pool closed too early.It is very easy to walk next door and take the public bus system anywhere on the island. We rode the buses to Pearl Harbor and back without any problem. The hotel is perfect for those running the Honolulu Marathon -- the start is a block away.Don't stay at the Ala Moana if you want to hang out at a beach resort. This hotel is more for business travelers who are looking for a great hotel in a good location.
Great for families. Convient to Ala Moana Shopping Center. Refrigerator and microwave oven that bakes and grills comes in very handy and a plus. Love the drawer space and semi suite style.

I love this hotel!! It is so beautiful and decorated very nicely. It is perfect if u r a shopaholic like myself since it is connected to the largest mall in Hawaii the Ala Moana shopping center. It also houses a very nice night club. The rooms are very nice for the price and contain a kitchenette. Make sure u get atleast a partial city view and try to stay up high we stayed on the 32nd floor. It is kept very clean and the beds are verry comfy.

Let me get the dislikes over with first...which really was more "not my favorite things but I can deal with it". I would still come back and stay at this hotel again!Dislike: $20 parking daily fee and in-hotel restaurants/lounges only open certain hours and some not every day.Like: Convenience of going to/from Ala Moana Shopping Center, self-serve parking, comfortable beds and pillows, great shower, and quiet room, nice minimalist lobby, beautiful Christmas trees throughout the hotel and its location!

We stayed 10 days at the hotel in the Kona wing. room was clean, quiet, but small. It is the hotel it you want to visit the Ala Moana Shopping Center, prk or beach. There is a walk way to the shopping center. It is convenient to the aiiport and to Waikiki. We would stay there again when we return to Honolulu. Improvemenst would be a larger TV WiFi, and the option to ask the cleaners to make up room early. Pool was close by on the 4th floor Kona but water was too chilly, Lots of lounge chairs and gorgeous sun. Gym is clean and well equipped.
user_name:
NikonGuy18105
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel. The lobby is beautiful, especially the fun decorations for the holidays. The room is compact, with modern furniture and a nice shiny LCD TV screen.

I found this hotel to be perfect for my recent business trip. I stayed here for 6 nights while visiting Maui, Kaui, and the Big Island for business day trips. The location is just a short drive to the airport. Being adjacent to the Ala Moana Shopping center was great for a quick dinner and to walk around after work. The room was clean and came with free internet, fridge, etc... I was also impressed by the full size gym, Not your usual hotel gym with a bike and treadmil in a small room. Valet was always around even for those very early departures to the airport. Very pleased and would definitely stay here again for future business trips.

For me, a business traveler, this hotel offered a GREAT view off of the 36th floor, quiet, comfortable and very clean. Hotel service was very good. True, the restaurant downstairs is open for breakfast only but has an excellent buffet. The hotel is within walking distance of other hotel restaurants. It is next door to the Mall (access on 2nd Floor) and close to the convention center and a block from the park. I like NOT being on or near Wakiki Beach and the noise and tourists (many of whom should not be in a swim suit!)

We're Hawaii residents and needed a place to stay while our home was fumigated. The best thing about Ala Moana Hotel is that it's easy walking distance to Ala Moana Shopping Center with a huge selection of places to eat. It was also conveniently located to my husband's office and my daughter's school. The rooms were comfortable and clean with a normal assortment of amenities (refrigerator, microwave, and complimentary high-speed Internet connection). There was a nice view of the Magic Island/Ala Moana Beach Park so this would be a great place to stay for watching fireworks on New Year's and 4th of July. The staff was courteous, friendly, and helpful. We would definitley consider staying there again.

I requested a king size bed and was given a double bed without so much as a comment about it from the front desk. I had to make a special arrangement with the assistant manager just to get a queen bed. What did I specify a bed for if the hotel can't come through with my request?The TV in the room is a tiny flat panel that is lost on the wall opposite the bed. Watching a football game, I was unable to read the statistics displayed on the screen.The hotel needs to upgrade to WiFi service for computer users. The pool was blah. The surroundings are poor; just dirty city area with no feeling of being in Hawaii.We requested a late check-out and were flattly denied.

Staff tried hard but were demoralised. Coffee shop is open only for breakfast, there is no room service meals, most of the shops in the lobby area are closed. And the bar is closed!! It's a long way from Waikiki or any beach and needs a longish walk and bus ride to get there. But it is immediately adjacent Ala Moana shopping mall which to my mind is the best for shopping in Honolulu. So if all you need is a room for shopping as we did it's fine - provided it's still open when you try to book
From the outside you would expect this very modern-looking hotel to have certain basic features. To keep it short: there is only a Chinese restaurant. There is no wifi. It is far from the beach.

The hotel is close to Waikiki, and everything in Honolulu without being in the congestion of Waikiki. As a former Honolulu resident, I really appreciate not being in the middle of Waikiki. The rooms in the Kona tower were a bit small and a little dated, but had everything we needed including a microwave and fridge. The rates also made it quite reasonable.

An average hotel and they really don't go out of their way to assist tourists or inform guests about the hotel amenities. It's very handy to the Ala Moana Shopping Mall with over 290 stores. The surrounding streets are very busy with traffic and noisy. It's a 15-20 minute walk to the Waikiki beach. Many homeless people in the area. Room was clean. The TV remote, strangely enough, must be aimed at a device on the desk below the wall mounted TV. The Priceline rating of 3 stars is generous. The morning breakfast buffet was good and the waitress, Debbie, was very personable. Depending on the purpose of your visit, shopping , business, or beach, this hotel may or may not suit your purpose.

I found the Ala Moana Hotel to be clean and located near the beach and shopping. It would have been a great hotel to stay at if I knew then what I know now. The hotel is half hotel and half condos (sold as hotel rooms). The front desk refers to this as the private side. I thought I had gotten a great deal but I did not. I was charged a check in fee ($40), exit clean fee ($50), daily clean fee ($10/day), and a resort fee ($15/day). This is in addition to the price I was quoted as the daily room rate. The fees added 60% to the final bill. Buyer beware!!!!!

We recently stayed at the Ala Moana for two nights. We were having a 2 night stop over prior to flying home to Australia. We were very impressed with the service upon arrival- quick and friendly. We stayed in a Queen city view room on the 5th floor in the Kona tower. Very clean room, lovely bathroom and comfortable bed. Ideal location for shopping at the Ala Moana shopping complex. A very short walk over the skybridge. We also enjoyed walking to the nearby beach park and down to shops and restaurants down the road. We got a shuttle from the airport to the hotel which only took about 20 mins. We got a taxi back to the airport and it was about $30.00.Overall great hotel, good value for money and good stopover/ shopping hotel. We will be back!

As a local customer from an outer island we always stay at Ala Moana for conveinence. I am an employee of a major hotel in Waikiki but since Ala Moana is conveinent we always stay there. After checking in late on a Friday we were told Valet is full & that we need to go to self park, fine. We always valet since we we had a lot of luggage since we were there for business. We go to self park and can easily see that self park is full along with a BIG SIGN that says lot full. The attendent tells us to park ANYWHERE just not in a handicap parking. Ok so cars are double parked and moving cones, just horrible but we got some parking that night. Sat night we come back to the hotel late again and once again are told VALET is full, we asked why and are told by the Valet that it's because of RUMORS (a night club). How can they allow a cluber to park in Valet/self park and not have parking for their PAYING GUEST! Once again we go to self parking and once again are told just park anywhere. Again we find parking NEXT to a handicap space. The space does not say no parking however there are white lines. So we figure it's ok to park there. Next morning we get into our car and find a $260 parking ticket. It's says we parked in a handicap stall. We did not park in a handicap stall. So to make a long story short, we called the Guest Service Manager (Daryl) who was extremely RUDE from when he answered the phone. He basically said to bad it was our falt and he aint going to help. We decide to call back and speak with a higher up manager (hotel manager-RON) and we get treated like crap once again. He would not help us but take off the parking charge, of course he would there was not PARKING! We thought at least he could help a little more to offset our bill but NO he said he couldn't. Bottom line...RUDEST CUSTOMER SERVICE i've ever had. I will never stay there again, I will tell all of my friend and family never to stay there again. They have lost many customers all due to Horrible customer service and word of mouth is huge! My hotel has higher standards and that's why people stay where they know customer service is at a higher level!!! Ala Moana Management...You are Horrible!
Access to the shopping center thru Macy's parking. Newly renovated. Where's the emergency stair exit? Staff is good. Relaxing. Pool is adequate.
This is a great place stay that's affordable and very clean. Great place for business or leisure. Had a great time and the staff was great.

Stayed here 4 nights in August. Very convenient location adjacent to the Ala Moana shopping center. It is not in Waikiki, but it is close enough to walk (our family generally does alot of walking when we travel). We were comfortable walking to Waikiki beach as well as to the opposite side of Waikiki past the zoo. The hotel is very much a business hotel, and not a vacation resort. There is a standard-type pool on the 2nd floor, clean, well-kept and manned. We had dim sum at the Chinese restaurant also and was not impressed, as we expected better and more selection.When we checked in, the bathroom in the first room we were given was a little dirty (hair in the tub, nothing dramatic just not CLEAN). We called and were immediately moved to the room next door.

If you have a conference at the convention center and don't mind not being on the beach in Hawaii (which I think is ridiculous), then this isn't so bad. You can get on the tourist bus near the mall and ride to Waikiki
One of the best experiences of my life. LOCATION, LOCATION, LOCATION - you are in the center of Waikiki, great restaurant and costumer service as well.

I got this hotel for 2 reasons, 1-To be close to the convention center and 2-Quality for the price and I thought it was a good pick for my needs. I was attending an international convention at the Hawaii Convention center and this hotel was only a few yards away! The price for this hotel was also a determining factor in booking this hotel. The room my boyfriend and I stayed at was small, but comfy. It was cleaned everyday and the service was good. If I were to pick a negative aspect, it would be that we were far away from the "touristy things in Waikiki." Although, this hotel is right next door to a very nice, big mall.

I stayed at the Ala Moana for five nights while in Hawaii for a Conference - I know - lucky me! It was an aweome trip and amazing experience. The hotel itself was fine. My room was small, but did the job. Nothing fancy. In fact, older and it showed - on the walls, in the furniture, etc. Got a good night's sleep and was happy to have a fridge and microwave. I was upgraded to an ocean view at check-in, but that room was not ready yet, and after a long day of travel, I prefered to get in and get settled so I could go explore. FYI - my rate was just $109/night!!!! Amazing, I think. For that reason only I'd stay there again and maybe rent a car... would have to do the math.The Ala Moana Shopping Center/Mall is a five minute walk from the hotel and has every high end store you can imagine - Gucci, Prada, etc. It also has more mainstream stores and plenty of places to get a manicure, which was perfect, because I needed one! The hotel is VERY close to the Convention Center (probably about or less than a 5-minute walk), and is about a 7-10 minute walk across a busy intersection to the Ala Moana Park - which is - the BEACH! I jogged along the water a few mornings and it was breathtaking (literally and figuratively!) The beach was not very crowded but the park was - with locals having BBQs and gatherings - it was pretty cool.The other conference hotel was the Marriott Waikiki and it was closer to all of the action (shops, restaurants) and to a busier beach. So to get to all of that - I had to take a cab. That was about $10 each way.The Ala Moana Hotel has an activities desk which helped arrange tours, but the desk has spotty hours, so book when you see someone there just in case. Also, you can arrange airport pick-up through Roberts for $9! (That was what it cost for me, not sure if it is per person.) There is also a large store with foods and drinks that are reasonable priced considering.

This hotel is actually very nice, and reasonably priced for a hotel of this level of quality. I found all the staff quite friendly, helpful and accommodating. The room was very clean and modern, bed was comfortable, though my TV was quite small. I wasn't particularly happy with the location. It is about two blocks from the convention center, so if you are having meeting there, which I was, this is a sensible hotel choice. However, it's not the best for the beach or for finding places to eat. The Ala Moana Shopping Mall has a food court, and there are the strip clubs in the neighborhood around the back side of the place for your night time entertainment, but that's about it. One small advantage to this place is that you are much closer to real Honolulu neighborhoods than you would be in most of Waikiki. So, if you're adventurous, go for a walk.

Not right on the beach like others but better actually...close to the Ala Moana park - beautiful walk, well used by locals and tourists alike, beside 2 lovely quiet beaches. Perfect for early morning walks. Next door to Ala Moana shopping centre - the selection of shops is mind boggling. Beside bus station so no matter where you're travelling to, there is a bus stop right across the road. Also free unlimited internet access was invaluable.

This hotel has a lovely and handy position if you are a business traveller attending conventions. The room facilities are good. It is great to have fridge, microwave and coffee maker if you are busy or on a budget. The cleanliness is good and accommodation of good average (not four star) standard. My main complaint with the hotel is the totally appalling approach to providing information to overseas business guests. I tried to check out the night before as I had to aeve at 4.30 am the next day to catch an early flight and the front desk staff were hopeless. They lost my company credit card deatils 5 times during my stay. The website fax details do not get information through to the front desk staff. The front desk staff looked at me blankly when I asked what the fax number was including the international dialling code. Unbelievably the front desk staff also had the cheek to tell me that I would have to wake up at 3 am to talk to the new person on shift to ask if they could prepare my check out receipt for my departure at 4.30 the next day. Apparently it was not possible for the front desk staff to write a note to the next shift. The hotel owners need to send their staff on MacDonalds customer relations training! I would not go back as I am cross that the hotel is far from cheap yet they were worse than a UK cheap chain

We were traveling as a party of 4, having reserved 3 ocean view rooms at the Ala Moana Hotel. We have stayed in this hotel many times before, and though it's not a fancy top of the line hotel, it's in a great location adjacent to the Ala Moana Shopping Mall, which makes shopping and eating really convenient. We had reserved Kama'aina rooms at a slightly discounted rate, which is a special rate reserved for Hawaii residents - we have lived in Kauai for almost 15 years. The check-in into 2 of the rooms was really pleasant and we had a great experience at the front desk - the clerk was delightful. The rest of our party was checking in at a later time that evening, which was our daughter returning from college in Europe. When checking in, we had a different clerk, her name was Joyce, and this lady was the exact opposite of the very nice lady who checked us in earlier. We were told that we couldn't have the Kama'aina rate on our 3rd room because my daughter didn't have her Hawaii ID with her, even though we were paying for all 3 rooms on our credit card. This in itself would have not been such a bad experience, hadn't it been for ignorance and bad attitude of the clerk. In the end, we received our Hawaii resident discount, but came away with a really bad feeling border-lining on having been the victim of racism (yes, there is reverse racism in the islands against “Haole's” which are Caucasian Americans). This happened on the evening shift of 9/28/10.This is a good example of how one bad employee can have a big effect on your business. Outrigger, please reprimand this clerk for her unprofessional behavior and conduct. Thank you.

Very convenient to shopping (Ala Moana Shopping Center) and beach (Ala Moana park). A little walk or trolley ride gets you to Waikiki Beach. Recommend staying in the main hotel tower. Worth the upgrade. Very clean. Staff friendly.

Bathroom too small & I injured and badly bruised my hip on a ridiculous large door handle.A short walk to shopping centre & closer to airport but too far from Waikiki beach.We used it just for overnight stay. No cafe at night.Breakfast was good.

Always enjoy my stays at the Ala Moana Hotel. There were a lot of people checking in, but the line moved quickly. Elevators are faster getting to floors now. Only negative is the self parking. We compete with the night life gang on Fridays and Saturdays. Hope I win the Smart Car!

I have stayed at the Ala Moana before but had forgotten why I didn't care for it. This trip - I stayed the first four nights of my business trip at the Hilton Prince Kuhio and the last four nights at Ala Moana. The contrast between the two hotels was night and day. Hilton Prince Kuhio ROCKS all over Ala Moana. But if you find yourself staying there - Waikiki Tower is a MUST! Otherwise your view, zero balcony, and the trek to the other tower every time you come and go is rotten. There were 3 hangers in my closet upon arrival and none of them had clips to hang pants. It took two visits for housekeeping to finally come up with enough extra crappy wire hangers. The hair dryer kept shorting out so they brought a different one but it had the same problem, just not quite as bad. The bathroom is dinky - barely enough room to get around the toilet when you want to take a shower. They don't vacuum. The floor is dirty. There is no room service. There is no scale in the workout facility, or anywhere else for that matter. The TV channels are minimal. The good things about this hotel is the cheap rate and the close proximity to the mall.

My husband's conference was being held at Ala Moana Hotel and we decided to stay over. We got a great Kamaaina price for a nice room. Room was very clean and the hotel staff was very friendly and helpful even though we are local too.I do like that you will now have to use your room key to operate their elevators. Hope to stay there again.

I stayed here previously in January for a wedding and I liked everything.The service was great and so was the room. Unfortunately that was not the case this time around. Don't get me wrong, the location is fantastic. Centrally located to everything, shopping, beaches, restaurants and nightlife. I was severely disappointed upon checking in. I was traveling with my girlfriend and wanted it to be a memorable trip so I reserved an ocean view suite. Upon check in i was told to wait 3 hrs. and then when I got the room it was a tiny little cubby hole facing the mountain! When asked what happened to the suite I reserved, the man at the desk told me I have a partial ocean view and what's my problem?! Then when I checked out, the rate wasn't adjusted what-so-ever! I asked the man at the desk and he said I should have said something upon checking in. The service is crap here!

Except for clean rooms there is not a good word to be said about this hotel. Reception and restaurant service is lousy, room faces on a ledge littered with cigarette fags, a loud and dark street with opposite a parking garage obstructing view to the mountains. Fitness facilities are a sick joke, sauna is out of order, around the pool loiter boozers, while gold deals are main business at rear entrance. Really never again!

Stayed in Kona Tower....aka: the "dorm" tower.Room Cleanliness:MOLD on walls beside heating/cooling unit .Dirty marks on carpet .Skirts on bed are dirty.Clumps of sand/dirt in corners.Location:Quite a hike to WaikikiClose to Ala Moana Mall, but who needs to shop that much?!Room General:The window faced a building.Service:NOT helpful at all, quite arrogant...."laissez faire" attitude.Quietness:Dorm-like feel, VERY thin walls, loud guests in rooms & hallways.Closing Remarks:IF THE PRICE SEEMS TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE, IT PROBABLY IS. If you can live with a noisy, dirty, moldy room facing a building with next to no service, please roll the dice.

My wife and I always enjoy staying at the Ala Moana Hotel. It is extremely convenient to be near the Ala Moana Shopping Center and the other areas we like to frequent. The rooms are kept in good shape. Kamaaina rates are very enticing. We will come back as often as we can!

My husband I stayed at the Ala Moana August 14-17, 2010. The lobby is nice. They were VERY slow checking us in and not very pleasant. We waited over 30 minutes and there were not many people in front of us. The rooms were a DUMP!!!! In the first room I found hair in the bed. They did switch us. The second room was not much better. The shower curtain had mold on it. There was hair on the hinge of the bathroom door. The place had not been dusted in a very long time. They did not vacuume our room the whole time we were there. We even found black sludge in our tub one morning when we woke up.The hotel is conveniently located near the Ala Moana mall if you are interested in shopping. The Cafe is only open for breakfast. If you do not want an expensive Chinese or Japanese dinner you will need to go elsewhere to eat.

We stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel in January 2010. We were upgraded to a room with a balcony overlooking the harbor. The rooms are very clean and modern. One thing about some hotels in Honolulu is that you might get a room that feels musty and not so clean. However, you never get the feel of that at Ala Moana Hotel. On the negative side, the televisions are fairly small in each room. The size of the television is more like the size you'd put in your kids room rather than a hotel room. The pool is nothing special. Unfortunately, the pool is near the parking lot of the Ala Moana Mall, so do not expect too much peace and quite. However, the biggest positive about this hotel is its proximity to the mall. You literally walk across the parking structure to get to the mall. So if your stay in Honolulu is not to spend much time at the hotel, but go to the mall and do the other tourist activities, the hotel has a great centralized location. As for the service, the service is below average at best. It takes quite a bit of time to check in if there is a line. There is a VIP line, but the individuals working there tend not to call over people from the regular line if there is no one they are serving. Overall, a clean and modern hotel with a great location in Honolulu. However, average in service and overall amenities.

Next year it will be 40 years since our first stay at the then-new Ala Moana Hotel. As newly arrived residents of Maui, it was a pleasure to go to THE meeting place for locals and visitors, The pool bar was full of after-work business people, and entertainment was for everyone.I've seen the hotel go through several eras of change, and the present condition of the lobby and rooms is definitely an improvement over the brief period of decline. It is lighter, more modern while still keeping some of the old sense of place. Of course it's location is a big plus. And alas, parking is still a big problem, especially when the hotel is full. The price for valet parking is $20.00 per night, self-parking for a single woman in the dingy garage is not recommended by me. and yes, they will now tow you away if you park in the shopping center's lot overnight.Another missing element is a cosy restaurant with good food. Even an all-day coffee shop would be nice to find, tucked away somewhere, maybe even with a wine bar. Travelers are so often on a different time line and while there is a convenience store, and a microwave in the rooms, the existing Chinese dinner restaurant and the breakfast-only cafe, while OK, don't fill in the missing hungry-moments.

Overall the stay was nice, but after a night out on the town you get stuck going around in circles because there's no parking. If you call parking three or four blocks away convenient, while lugging your luggage behind you; something is wrong with you. As for my husband and I, getting away from Maui for some down time was all we we're looking forward to. After seeming like forever trying to find parking, I demanded for my husband to drop me off so I can speak to the manager in charge to resolve this issue. (More like a nightmare!) We we were able to get a refund on one night of parking totaling $15.00. I believe we should have been given a voucher for a two night stay for the inconvenience after being told by parking attendance that due to the many locals staying at this establishment, there was no parking. Now why didn't they mention this on their website when we were looking for a night out on the town. Was this an oversight or did we have to discover this on our own. How dreadful and inconvenient this whole nightmare was. We local people deserve more than this! Other than that, the maid service was fantastic, but I don't believe we will be returning. Aloha.... Aqua Resorts here we come! At least they have valet parking and convenient parking available. Oh yes, one more thing. After checking in at about 11:00, we were given the wrong room key where we discovered all the way up on the 31st floor, that it was occupied. We local people like to keep it local, but when we are treated in a less than touristic way, I think there's something with this picture. We all contribute to trying to keep the economy going, but business and pleasure sure gave a whole new meaning to what we experienced. Have a nice stay and be sure to ask, is the lot full. Aloha from Maui, not so satisfied with parking two or three blocks away. Not to mention stepping off of the elevator where three huge bags of trash is the first thing you notice. Get up in the morning and guess what, it's still sitting there. Not very four or five star. You think.

We chose this hotel for a brief one-night stay before taking a cruise. We were most pleased that the hotel had a choice of arrival time on the reservation page AND the room was available immediately upon check-in. Room was clean and well-maintained. Restaurant for breakfast was very good with great buffet selection. Shops in the hotel were convenient and price competitive to others in the area. Proximity to great shopping and restaurants next door at the Ala Moana Mall was a definite plus. Overall a great choice. We'll be back on our next visit.

I travel to Honolulu about once each year. I have family there. This is my second stay at the Ala Moana Hotel. I like the Ala Moana because it is adjacent to the Ala Moana Shopping Center where there is everything that you need including restaurants (sit down and fast food), grocery store, pharmacy, post office and everything else you see at a large shopping mall. The hotel is centrally located in Honolulu, a short drive to just about anywhere. Very convenient. Secure indoor parking is relatively inexpensive at $14 day. Hotel is rather luxurious and clean. The lobby area is very welcoming. The rooms are very nice for the price ($109/night). I had a king room in the Waikiki Tower on the 28th floor on the Mauka (mountain) side. View from my small lanai which had a table and two chairs, was very nice. Rooms look like they have been renovated within the last 5 years or so. Good climate control, very good bathroom fixtures, free wired internet, a safe in the closet, comfortable beds and comfortable furniture (arm chair, loveseat and coffee table). The room included a fridge, microwave/toaster and coffee maker. My only complaint is that the flat panel TV was very small. Six very fast elevators, so very little wait. Elevators require key cards therefore the floors are safe. Staff is very helpful and friendly. On-site restaurants are very good. Very good breakfast buffet for $15 at the Plantation Cafe. The Royal Garden Chinese restaurant on the third floor is one of the best in Honolulu. Very large pool and deck area, clean and well maintained. The fitness center is well equipped with treadmills, ellipticals, exercise bikes, weight machines, free weights and exercise mats. Towels are available at the pool and the gym. The hotel is not on the beach, though it is across the street from Ala Moana Beach Park where there is a protected beach, tennis courts and snack stands. It is a great place to go for an early morning run or walk.In summary, the perfect hotel and stay for my needs. I highly recommend this hotel for all travelers if you are not looking for a hotel on the beach.

The hotel parking was unavailable both in the self park and valet. The hotel bell staff told me that my only option was to park next door at the Ala Moana Shoppibg Center but that I had to keep moving my car every couple of hours or it would get towed. For three nights I dutifully woke up every two hours to move my car, I got zero sleep and was really upset at the end of the stay. I will not go back here again!

First of all our room was nice. The microwave plate inside was dirty it was not clean. And second their doors do not shut correctly, actually it does not shut you will have to push it close. One night our door just opened ,then went to look if someone was trying to come in but there was no one. So called front desk to make a complain and to see if someone was trying to get in, they sent the manager to come up and check to see who tried to open the door but it didnt show anyone trying to open it, then discovered that the door does not close properly, I was pretty upset because that is not safe at all. but all the manager could say was sorry about that. And that we have to push to close ourself. not safe at all you could get rob. they just could give us 1 day of free parking that's alot of bull..

I have stayed at the Ala Moana Hotel at least once a year for over 12 years. Location is very convenient since it is connected to the Ala Moana Shopping Center.Every stay is different, especially now that the rooms are individually owned and just managed by outrigger. Rooms vary in decor and facilities. Some rooms comfortable, while others sterile. Overall rooms are small but usually quiet and I get a good nights sleep.Even the service at checkin can be great or very cold. Most recently I was on Oahu for lasik surgery and stayed at the Ala Moana because it is walking distance to the surgery center. I wanted to walk back to the hotel after surgery since my vision would be impaired. I requested early checkin while making online reservations. When arriving there I was told nothing was available for early checkin. That's fine, it was just a request, however the front desk agent was very cold, sterile, uncaring about my reasoning for early checkin. Basically in Hawaii we say she had no "Aloha". At least when you are denying a request it would be nice to have a smile and friendly words. She was cold and uncaring, I got the surgery done and walked back to the hotel to checkin. Original front desk agent gone so different front desk agent this time and she was astounded that I didn't checkin earlier. She was upset and said to me "I don't understand why didn't she let you checkin earlier" She was warm and friendly and oozed "Aloha" so the checkin was about as good as I've ever had even though i could barely see after surgery and had to be shown where to sign on the form.Another time I was given my cardkeys at checkin and when i got to the room door was already open and the maid was still there cleaning the room. So I asked the maid when will the room be ready and she said about 30 minutes. So I went shopping at Ala Moana Shopping Center and returned about an hour later. Tried the cardkey and it didn't work. I had been give two card keys, even thought I was a solo traveler, and had put the other cardkey in my backpack. So I retrieved the other cardkey and it also didn't work. Went to the front desk and the agent told me to meet security at the room. 5 minutes later the security guard came tried both cards and it didn't work. I went back downstairs and told the agent that the cards didn't work. She explained to me that the cards can go bad if they are put in your wallet, near your credit cards. Both cards? One of which stayed in my backpack and was nowhere near my wallet. She blamed me for the problem. I never tried any of the cards since the door was open and the maid cleaning the room. I think the card wasn't programmed correctly or the card reset after the maid finished cleaning the room. I'm not sure about this because I don't know hotel procedures. What I do feel is that whatever happened wasn't my fault. I didn't do anything wrong, but the front desk agent told me I was at fault. That ruined the trip from the beginning.Bottom line is that you can get good service and a good room sometimes. At other times it can be bad service and a bad room. Very inconsistent.

Ala Moana is conveniently located next to the shopping center, which is great if for nothing else than the food court. The facilities are clean, beds comfortable, and service decent. But it's still a tourist oriented facility, and they nickel and dime you. Parking is $15/day, and the breakfast buffet is between $10-15 each. We arrived to two twin beds instead of a queen, and they quickly moved us rooms, but that room had hair in the bed, on the floor, and in the drawer, so they moved us again to the same type of room, but about 20 floors higher. Once we were situated, things were a lot better. Every room has a mini fridge, which was nice for leftovers. Overall things were pretty good, and we'll likely stay again.

I have stayed here over the years and loved it, then was so discouraged these last few years. Well, this time it was like going to a new hotel! There was full staffing at check in and they were friendly and happy. I got upgraded and the room was to die for. The room was clean and the support staff ...all the support staff were incredibly friendly and helpful. Of course, being next to Ala Moana Shopping Center is always a HUGE PLUS.

The hotel is fairly nice, as I said, not the worst I've stayed at but not the best. They're trying to be green, so they have several signs around the room explaining how they're doing this (ex: in the bathroom the sign says "if you want fresh towels- throw them in the tub, if you want to reuse the towels just leave them hanging up, ect). The location isn't bad, but it is a bit noisy because of street traffic (where is it not, though?) and the Ala Moana shopping center is a short walk away. The shopping center has a fairly good mix of expensive and inexpensive stores, and lots of good food places. I personally think it's better than staying in Waikiki because there are more options to eat at local places and walmart is really close by if you forgot to buy something for the trip.We had a room in the tower facing the city and mountains, but there is a window by the elevators where you can view the ocean. The beach is also very close by.There are several different gift shops on the main floor, and the prices aren't too terrible. They have t-shirt for only $15, when they could probably be charging more. Food can be a bit expensive, but there are a lot of options if you don't feel like going out to find something.The absolute WORST thing about this hotel is that they do NOT clean the carpets. I noticed a blob of chocolate with ice cream on the floor under the night stand and several stains all over the carpet. You'd think if they just finished fixing up the hotel that they'd want to keep it clean...

At first, we were not sure if staying so close to the Ala Moana Centre was a good idea seeing as we had stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village previously. As it turns out, the Ala Moana Hotel was a plesant surprise and provided us with an enjoyable stay while in Honolulu. If you want to shop, this is the place to stay!After flying 14 hours to get to Honolulu, we were greeted by a friendly receptionist (Barbara) who kindly gave us an early check-in to the room. We were also given a 10% off voucher for Macy's (which lasted 3 days). The rooms were comfortable and secure and there was little noise from outside. Our room was fine for 2 people for 2 weeks as it had an in-room safe, free cable TV, free and fast internet access, microwave etc. The pool area was nice after a long day shopping also! The room was cosy and had a mountain view only but for $129 per night + tax we were very happy with the hotel. The reception staff, room sttandants and bell desk staff were very friendly and helpful. For any last minute needs, a 7-11 style store is located in the hotel and is open from 7am to 11pm. Free Hawaiian-style entertainment in the Pakele Lounge on Thursday nights.We did notice some areas that might need improvement - limited nightly restautant options in the hotel, slow and expensive internet access in the lobby and the coffee maker in the room was tained with an bad aftertaste (hence, we bought a cheap kettle from Sears). Apart from that, the hotel was great!Perhaps the best aspect of this hotel is being so close to the Ala Moana Centre! The hotel connects to level 2 of Macy's and is a short stroll over the flyerover. This proved dangerous as there were too many bargains to be bought! Also close by is Ross For Less and Walmart which are also great stores for affordable bargains. The Ala Moana Centre had some great restaurants which proved useful at night - Ruby Tuesday, Islands Burgers, Longhi's Restaurant and Macaroni Italian Restaurant.We would recommend this hotel for serious shoppers!

This is a very pleasant hotel away from Waikiki and the Waikiki crowds but BEWARE of its valet parking. We stayed 8 nights in late March when Hawaii is not crowded and all the beaches, except Waikiki Beach and Ala Moana Beach Park, are relatively deserted on the weekdays. The biggest plus is its location, next to Oahu’s largest shopping mall, Ala Moana Shopping Center. There is no better place to experience the company of locals than in the mall’s food court and mainline stores. The check-in was smooth and quick and the room was adequate for its price range. The maid service was adequate, always enough towels and the balcony table, where birds gathered for bits of food in the morning, cleaned everyday. It was interesting to see the Hawaiian professionals meeting almost daily in the hotel’s conference rooms or a 20th high school reunion in the hotel’s main restaurant. The local professionals and reunion goers seem like the same people you see in any big city or small town meeting or reunion except the locals wear aloha shirts or t-shirts and colorful dresses, and are relaxed. We did not try the hotel restaurants since the adjacent shopping mall and outside the city have much more choices, for example, Islands (burgers, chicken, fish) or California Pizza Kitchen at the mall.The downside of our stay is the hotel’s valet parking. Due to a shortage of rental cars, we had a choice of a Dodge Charger or a Hyundai premium sedan. We chose the Charger to an unknown Hyundai sedan. As much as we liked the Charger’s acceleration and power, a member(s) of the hotel’s valet parking staff liked the Charger more.
