Housekeeping staff was very pleasant and helpful They were the ones who made our stay the best! Once they found out about the allergic reaction, they washed all his sheets and towels separately in hot water to wash out the detergent for every day of the rest of our stay. My only complaint is that management of the hotel didn't call to check and make sure everything had been resolved, meaning that they didn't care or they were never told. Upon arrival, we asked for a Waikiki tower upgrade. The only benefit really was two beds instead of one. The view the registration clerk kept boasting about wasn't as great as anticipated. Instead of having a view of the beach, we got a back view of some parking structures and older hotel buildings in the dark, dingier part of Honolulu. But, we did get a little lanai which was nice to sit out on.It was a good stay overall. If you were paying and had a choice though, I'd think you could find something better with relatively similar in amenities. If you're coming for Waikiki, definitely find something a bit closer. This is more in the commercial area of town, not recreational.

This was a pleasure/business trip. We needed to be near the convention center. I was very impressed by the appearance of the hotel (very nicely remodeled/updated, great service) and the location was FANTASTIC. We could walk right across the street to the convention center, but it was also a very easy walk to the beach (which turned out to be a great beach to hang out at since it's not too busy) and Ala Moana mall is right next door which made it convenient to grab and coffee or a quick bite to eat. Also, you can catch the bus anywhere right outside of the hotel. All this and a great price (it included free internet and room safe which our friend at the Hilton Hawaiian Village had to pay separately for).
The front office staff very warm and helpful and knowledgeable. Very friedly. Bellman were nice. Clean rooms. so convenient to the mall!

If you are visiting Hawaii for a shopping experience, I would suggest to stay at this hotel. If not, go in town. I would also suggest to pay a little more and get a bigger room. Waikiki tower rooms are also recommended. Kona tower rooms do not have a "lanai" (patio). Over all i would rate this hotel a 7, if you only need a place to sleep. 2 people can't fit in the entry way of room and you can make sheshe and wash your face at same time because bathroom is so small. Visit rumours for a great evening! its in the hotel lobby!!!

Even though the hotel is not located directly to Waikiki Beach it's very easy and quick to get there due to Honolulus excellent bus services. Nevertheless, the hotel is very close to the beautiful Ala Moana Beach and next to a fantastic shopping center with fab shops and restaurants. Freindly staff, good rooms!

During our stay we ended up having to call maintenance at least 12 times to come into our room to fix the clogged toilet only to have the poroblem fixed at 11:00pm the night before we left.Can you imaging having to "GO" and having to wait for maintenance to come fix the problem and then "FINALLY GOING". only to turn around and call them back up again?

If the person who dealt with me on the front desk hadn't been so rude I may have stayed here longer as it was a fairly convenient location in terms of shopping and tours etc. I stayed in the Waikiki Tower. The view was lovely. The room was clean, well furnished, modern and quiet. Another plus for me were the gym facilities. Nice and spacious with excellent cardio equipment. Its a pity they employed one very rude person on the front desk... she really spoiled it.... other staff even apologized for her behavior!

I have stayed at the Ala Moana every July for the last 3 years for a conference. The first year my baby was only 3 weeks old, so my partner came with me. Now each year they come at the end of the conference and we spend an extra couple of days. I have also stayed here for random 1-nite trips to Honolulu (we live on a neighbor island). When we go to Honolulu, we usually try to fit in shopping, so the bridge over to the Ala Moana mall is awesome. If you read the reviews on here they seem uneven, and I think that is because of the difference in the 2 towers. Both towers have recently been updated and the rooms feel very fresh, but the Kona tower has much smaller rooms and smaller beds. The Waikiki tower is probably only about $20 more a nite for king bed and full lanai (balcony), so it is worth it if you're her on vaca. The partial ocean-view rooms in that tower actually have really good views, you get the city and the harbor, beautiful. Bathrooms are pretty standard. I have always been treated well here. One year I was able to get a late check-out because my daughter fell asleep. The next year they couldn't because they already had the room booked, but they held our bags at the bell desk all day and when we returned from our day at the beach, they offered us 30 minutes in a Kona tower room where we were able to shower and change for our flight back. super nice.also, we never drive in honolulu (ugh!). i grew up in a big city so i am very comfortable with public transportation, and honolulu has a great transit system. the ala moana center is central for probably half the bus lines on the island, so being right next door is very convenient for getting around the island. if you want to really experience the daily flavor of oahu, nothing like hitting the bus system, i promise you.i really like ala moana and look forward to my trip there every summer!

Been to all of the major hotels in Waikiki and I have found the Ala Moana Hotel my favorite hotel hands down. Rooms are new and clean, all with great views, the front desk remembers me by name and the room rates very reasonable. I also love the fact that I do get a room upgrade by those that know me! They have a great Cantonese Chinese restaurant on the 3rd floor that serves great Dim Sum during lunch hour and my friends can park at the Ala Moana Shopping Center at no cost. Let's not forget that it is convenient to go shopping at the Ala Moana Shopping Center, take a walk at the Ala Moana Park/Beach and if I have to work out in the gym...for free.

I recently stayed on the 31st floor of the Ala Moana with family for three nights on vacation and overall was pleased with our stay. Although the Ala Moana Hotel is clearly an older structure from the 1970s, it was renovated relatively recently with a lovely contemporary design. The room was tastefully decorated, very quiet, and clean, with a decent mountain-side view, and the bed was pleasant and comfortable. Air conditioning quality is average (the unit could be a little quieter) but tolerable. The third-floor pool is mid-sized but still relatively good for a rooftop-type pool (9 feet deep at the deep end). The location next to Ala Moana Center and the nearby beach park is convenient, since it means one can enjoy great sightseeing, shopping, and dining without having to get in the rental car and sit in Honolulu's notoriously bad traffic. Now, the downsides, which is what we all read TripAdvisor for. The hotel is adjacent to the shopping center (and is connected by a skybridge) but is not directly adjacent to the beach park; you have to walk about half a mile to the beach. The rooms are rather small by American standards and have full rather than queen beds. It is possible to book a group of four into one room, as we did, but it will feel cramped. However, a couple or a single traveler would find the room size fine. The hotel charges for parking like most Honolulu hotels, although one would expect the daily rate to be a bit cheaper since it's not located in Waikiki per se. The third-floor pool is nice if you want privacy (relative to the the beachfront resorts in Waikiki where tourists wander through the pool areas), but inconvenient if you're the type who likes to go back and forth between pool and ocean. Finally, the good and bad thing is that the Ala Moana Hotel is not in Waikiki. So you don't have the crime, noise, and traffic of Waikiki, but it also means that if you want to go hang out at all the cool places in Waikiki, you have to get in the rental car, ride TheBus, or walk east over a mile in the sweltering tropical humidity.

I will say right away that this hotel is a hike from waikiki beach. Obviously it is a great two second trip to the ala moana mall as the the hotel name would indicate. The rooms are spotless, the view I had was amazing. The beach across the street was satisfactory. I would stay here again for sure, even if it was on vacation.

We were going to catch a cab to our hotel, but we took the shuttle bus for $10 each from the airport.We checked into our room at Ala Moana Hotel and were very lucky to be able to do this straight away because our plane landed at around 7am, and check-in was meant to be at 3pm, with no guarantee that we were allowed in earlier.We were very tired and had a snooze for about 2 hours, then we got up and went next door into Ala Moana Shopping Centre. Staying there was just great. We really paid less because we weren't in the heart of Waikiki, and for that we also got a very modern & refurbished hotel room - something quite hard to come by in Honolulu at the affordable price so it seems. Also the pros of staying here was probably that it was not as busy as other hotels would've been, with less traffic & noise about.We had a mountain view room. It was clean, it was comfortable.2 things I didn't like - shower curtain - bad luck, I'll get over it! (as opposed to shower screen). also the pillows - too puffy, high and soft. I prefer a firmer pillow. It was really hard to get comfy. After the 1st night I called reception and asked if they had different ones. They said no, they're all the same. I ended up using the pillows from the sofa couch which were a bit firmer, but smaller. Maybe next time I can bring my own.That night we didn't want to even make an effort to find a restaurant to eat at for dinner. We remembered we saw Domino's pizza on the way in, so we called to have a pizza each delivered to our room. $40 for 2 regular pizzas! When I said "What?!" Thinking that I mis-heard, the guy said ok i'll make it cheaper. I said Oh why so much? He said because you have extra toppings! (Standard we thought...) But anyway, we got the pizzas for $28 after that LOL.Most people said it would be too far to walk from Ala Moana, especially with the warmer weather conditions, but we walked it every time. The weather was completely bareable, and we're not even fit people.We ended up at Ala Moana shopping every night, wheather it be for more goods or just for dinner. I highly recommend it if you are into shopping. Being from Australia and travelling at 95c, we sure did make the most of cheaper levis, guess and armani.Because we'd spent so much, we didn't really want to go downtown for restaurant dinners, therefore had the luxury of buying food from Ala Moana food court. Doesn't get much cheaper then that.One late afternoon, we spent at Ala Moana Beach park, which was nice. Fairly quiet and we hung out there until sunset and took some great photos.

Good price. Best dining value: Take hotel's 2nd floor walkway to big shopping mall next door. Go down to acre-sized food court with 20+ selections for reasonably-priced food. Nice beach & park are in walking distance. Beach is public & locals crowd it on weekends. Hotel pool offers towels to take to the beach and the front desk was courteous and helpful. Pool closes at sunset.... no fun. Our room was clean every day. We would still return here if the price was right.Beware of seedy strip clubs and vagrants 1 block behind the hotel. AVOID the hard-sell tourist companies that lure you in with free breakfast and try to sell you expensive tours. They are not honest. Go to Long's Pharmacy in the mall for reasonably priced dry goods & touristy souvenirs.

I came here on business, and got a budget room ($109/night). It was small, but OK, until I noticed I was getting quite a few extremely itchy little bites on my feet and ankles (I mean like, one every 10 minutes). This seemed to horrify the manager on-duty, who quickly sent me to a bigger, better room, without any irritating fauna that I noticed. Please don't let this scare you off. I know this story sounds bad, but things like this can happen anywhere, and doesn't necessarily mean its a bad place. The manager responded appropriately, and to my satisfaction.The hotel is just a couple of blocks from the Convention Center, and right next-door to the Ala Moana Mall. The Mall is definitely the place to get meals and for shopping. Also, the hotel is a block away from Ala Moana Park (and beautiful public beach), about a 15-minute walk from the Hilton Hawaiian Villages, and about 25 minutes walk from Waikiki beach. Honolulu is an expensive place. Food costs about 150% the mainland price. You have to pay a fee for almost everything, though the in-room internet at this hotel is complimentary, and runs from hard-wired routers. This is not the case at the Hilton Hawaiian Villages, where internet runs $15.00 per day. But, if you want to print-out your boarding pass at the Ala Moana, you have to fork over 30 cents a minute to use the business center. Because their printer was not working when I was here, I asked someone at reception if they would print out my boarding passes. She said "no". Several hours later, I asked a different person at reception the same question, and she did it cheerfully. In Honolulu, ABC stores are a good source of supplies at OK prices - a single can of beer only costs about $1.60 there, while you will pay around $6.50 for a glass of beer in a hotel bar. The hotel is quiet, has a nice pool, and a classy lobby, but is just a little the worse for wear. While its not perfect, its a reasonable place, and I do recommend it.

We stayed two nights in an ocean view 1BR suite in the Waikiki Tower on the 34th floor. Very nice property. The location is excellent--Waikiki is a short ten minute walk--and best hotel if you've already experienced Waikiki or want something more centrally located. Walk from the lobby across a pedestrian bridge to the largest outdoor shopping center with EVERYTHING, including a huge food court, restaurants, fine dining, and everything from A to Z, budget to luxury... you name it it's there. Hotel public areas are beautiful--clean and a great first impression. Staff contact (bell, check in, front desk, housekeeping) always personable, efficient, excellent. A panoramic ocean view overlooking the Ala Moana Shopping Center parking lot/Macy's from balconies off the LR and BR. Clean, upscale modern business furnishings, comfy bed and LR sofabed. There were mini fridges, microwaves and more than adequate cupboard spaces in the LR and BR areas, as well as a more than adequate closet area The LR comfortably seated 6 of us when we had company. The bathroom was large enough with a good-size tub/shower and fine amenities. The laundry area in the older tower was clean and brightly lit and all machines were working well (although It took us awhile to figure out how to double up quarters in the slots). What we liked best: (1) Location!!! Great jogging, beautiful, large beach peopled with more isle residents than visitors, shopping, bus access, avoiding the Waikiki crowd... what's not to like? (2) City/Mountain view. We looked at a suite and room on the opposite side of the tower and it appeals because of the fantastic city lights at night when we're actually in the room. (3) Fitness center. Wow!What we liked least: (1) The TV's--Small, and awkward location in LR. (2) Internet access in LR only; the BR had a wonderful working desk but no access. (3) The layout (no door to BR) is such that the light from the bathroom or hallway shines directly in your face if you're lying in bed while someone uses bathroom. Overall: this is a great choice for business and leisure travel.

During our 11-night stay at the Ala Moana Hotel, we traveled to another island. This required us to take our personal belongings. Much to our surprise, when we returned, our room key would not work. I called the front desk who verified that we had in fact not checked out and was paid in full for the remainder of our stay. I waited outside our room with our baggage and tired children for security to arrive. After speaking to the guest services manager, he informed me that housekeeping told him we had checked out since we took our toothbrushes. Unbelieveable. He then told me, that he called the room and entered and verified that there were no toothbrushes. Needless to say, I was disappointed and disgusted. What kind of business are they running anyway? What kind of hotel locks out a guest because their toothbrush is not found in the room even when the room is paid for in full. Also, I paid for daily parking in advance and could not park my car due to the overwhelming response during the 4th of July weekend. The lot was completely full. It was a mess. Traffic was backed up for blocks. We should've been guaranteed a parking stall. Very unprofessional. I do not recommend this hotel at all.

Hotel was surprisingly quiet for being in such a busy area.I had a nice (albeit smallish) room with a stunning view. Some restaurants in the hotel, however, some were closed. Nightclub in the hotel is fun and frequented by locals as well as tourists.Shops on the bottom floor proved quite convenient.Business service center is awful - i spent $12 to print a report, and hotel internet is unreliable. The view almost makes up for it.

I stayed here during a conference and the location is excellent, very close to the conference center, just adjacent the huge shopping mall and not at all too far from the Ala Moana Beach Park or Waikiki, for someone used to do some walking at least. It's a relief not having to stay right in the middle of Waikiki which resembles some of the not so interesting parts of touristy places in the Mediterranean or in the Canaries. Taking the beach walk is perfect. Getting on The Bus is also very convenient from the Ocean side of the Ala Moana Center and it's The way to go around the town, to Pearl Harbour etc.The hotel staff is efficient and we had no problems with housekeeping. I'd have liked the pool to be open after sunset. The gym is open until 10 PM though. The Ala Moana Center is OK but for a European it is a weird experience to have to cross a wide parking deck no matter where you try to enter it on foot. In some places, you almost can't see that there's anything there behind all parked cars.

I've stayed at the Ala Moana 6 times now and it's really grown on me. It's not perfect, but you really can't beat the location or the price. The hotel itself is not beach front, but the Ala Moana beach park is an easy walk. The shopping center is incredibly convenient and has lots of great food options, and Waikiki is only a $8 cab ride away. Also, the fitness center is very nice and rooms come with free high speed internet.The down side is that the rooms are pretty basic and housekeeping is hit or miss. I get the feeling that the cleaning is pretty superficial. The service is fine although not extraordinary, and the food in most of the restaurants is acceptable. Room service is limited. However, for $120-150 in the middle of a big city, let alone in a vacation destination like Hawaii, I really don't think you can beat it.

We found the hotel to be extremely well located. Just outside of Waikiki, attached to shopping, and convenient to town and other areas of the island made it an enjoyable stay. Hotel room in Waikiki tower is small but the balcony made for pleasant morning coffee. King bed room with a pull out sofa bed had room enough for 2, would be tight but do-able with 3. Other reviewers mentioned far walk to Waikiki but we found a short cut. Cut thru the Hilton Hawaiian and follow the beach walk along the shore line until you pass the pink hotel. Cross back thru the white Moana hotel and you'll find yourself in the heart of the Waikiki drag. This cuts 10 mins off the commute. The proximity to the shopping center (supermarket, drug store, and of course shoes!) was great. Staff was friendly.

This hotel is about 2 blocks back from Ala Moana Beach Park, and connected to the Ala Moana shopping center. The good things - * Clean room, I had a balcony with a bit of ocean view. The room was a good size, with 2 double beds, 2 chairs, work desk.* Easy access to Ala Moana, which has many options for quick food and several nicer restaurants.* Ala Moana is a huge shopping center, and many people specifically come to Honolulu to shop there. So if shopping is on your list of things to do, this location cannot be beaten.* Only a couple of blocks to Ala Moana Beach Park. This park is mostly frequently by locals. It is very protected, great for swimming (but no snorkeling or surfing). Paddle surfing lessons are held here. There are big grassy areas and during the day people are playing ball, running with kids, etc. Overall it's a nice park and beach area, and less crowded/touristy than Waikiki.* Fridge and coffeemaker in the room mean I can eat breakfast in room inexpensively. They will bring a microwave on request.* The fitness center is better equipped than average!Problems (generally minor) - * Room service menu is very limited, only 6-9pm. I often get room service breakfast on the first morning of a business trip. If you like to eat breakfast in-room, you need to plan to get something and store it in your room. This is easy enough - there is an ABC Suprette a couple of blocks to the east, and another ABC store in the mall. * Pool is quite small. For swimming, I'd simply go to the beach.* Long-ish walk to Waikiki. If you want to rent a kayak or surfboard, or do any of the activities out of Waikiki you need to get there or arrange a tour with a shuttle. Many people grab towels from the pool at this hotel and then take a taxi or the trolley to Waikiki. It isn't that hard to do, but if you had really little kids it would be a pain.Bottom line:If you're looking for a less-expensive hotel, are traveling adults-only or with older kids, and shopping is on your to-do list, then is a good choice. If you have little kids and/or want to only spend time at the beach, this isn't a good choice.

We loved the Ala Moana Hotel due to it's location - near bus stations to all points in Oahu, hotel is connected to the best shopping center in Oahu with food court and restaurants around and a post office as well as Foodland grocery store, We also loved that it is just accross the Ala Moana beach park. If you like the convenience of almost everything and be away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, then this is the best place to be. Service was very good from the moment we checked to the day we checked out. It was a nice surprise to be upgraded from a small room at the Kona tower to a bigger room in the Waikiki tower. If you rent a car, it's $15/ day for self park and $20/ day for valet. Our breakfast buffet was included in our room rate which I think is very reasonable price compared to eating out. Buffet had large selections from french toasts, bagels, rice, omelets, scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, coffee, juice and fruits. The only down side is their internet connection, we had problems connecting to their high speed internet service but was given a discount due to this. Our rooms were cleaned on a daily basis before noon and given fresh towels as well. No noise heard if you close your lanai door. To sum it up, we had a great stay in this hotel.

I was supposed to spend several weeks at this hotel while working in Honolulu, but decided to move to a different hotel in Waikiki after one week and was glad I made the move. In a nutshell, the pros: adjacent to the mall, close to Ala Moana Beach Park, fairly close to downtown, helpful/friendly staff, GREAT fitness center, and coin-op laundry on two floors. The cons: my room looked out over parking lots and buildings (no greenery whatsoever), noise from bars on the top level of Ala Moana Center could be heard at night, and the room was kind of dated (small tv, polyester bedspread).To expand futher.... my stay seemed fine at first, but got depressing after about a week. I had a room on a high floor with a view. I could see the ocean if I stood on the balcony. However, when in the room looking out, all I could see was buildings and pavement. In addition, my room had line-of-sight to the top level of Ala Moana Center, so I could hear the noise from the live band(s) at night, even over the air conditioning. Also, the room seemed like it could use an upgrade – for instance switching from the slippery polyester bed spreads to washable cotton.Laundry: There are laundry rooms on the 13th and 6th floors, which is a nice amenity. The 13th floor laundry stays open til midnight and 6th floor laundry is open 24/7. The coin changer is on the 13th floor. The machines take quarters only. There are 2 washers and 2 dryers on the 6th floor and 5 washers (including one high-efficiency machine that holds 1.5 loads) and 5 dryers on the 13th floor. The cost was $2.25 per wash (or $2.75 for the high-efficiency machine that included a digital count-down timer – 38 minutes for a wash), $2.25 per dry, and $1.25 for detergent (only the powdered type was available). The Foodland grocery store in the Ala Moana Center sells a small container of “All” laundry detergent for $4.29 that lasts for 8 loads of wash. There was nothing resembling a clothesline in my room, not even over the tub, so I relied on a combination of the dryer and hanging items on the hangers. Eight “real” hangers were provided in the closet.The Bus: You can easily take the bus from Ala Moana Center to Waikiki. There also is easy access to downtown (i.e. Bishop/King street vicinity). In spite of where the hotel told me to go, I found that the best bus stop was out the side door, and across the street (under the various ramps). Most of the buses stopping there turn and head downtown. The 57 in particular seemed pretty fast (for downtown, not Waikiki). The #8, 19 and 20 continue to Waikiki, so don’t get on those unless that’s where you are headed. Verify with the bus driver that you’re getting on the right bus.Tip of the day: The little refrigerator in the room does a pretty good job, but don’t expect miracles. I found out the hard way that one should not put a large quantity of warm sticky rice with chicken in the fridge and expect it to be safe to eat the next day. The fridge just can’t cool it down fast enough and food poisoning can ensue. The fridge was fine for things like yoghurt, cheese, cold cuts, etc., just not large quantities of hot food.

We just wanted to spend one day in Honolulu before going on to one of the outer islands. We had read the reviews online and decided the Ala Moana was the best fit with what we wanted to do.We booked via the internet - a very smooth process. We had one minor bug - we never got a confirmation e-mail. We did confirm the reservation by phone before departure. No worries...the phone lasted longer than expected. The staff person was concerned that we were arriving after the restaurant closed and wanted to make sure we didn't go to bed hungry! She also made sure we knew where to catch the shuttle bus.Thanks to weather delays we ended up arriving after midnight. One bonus we hadn't thought of when booking was this hotel is the first stop for the airport shuttle - less than 25 minutes away. For some of the Waikiki Hotels it can be well over an hour. If we were younger we probably hit the nightclub when we arrived. It was obviously a favorite with locals. As it was we appreciated the professional staff on the front desk. Check in was smooth and quick.The room had everything we wanted - microwave, fridge and in room safe. We had a great view of Ala Moana Park from the lanai, and enjoyed having our morning coffee out there. The bed was very good. I didn't wake up feeling like an old crock with a sore back - a rare event for me at a hotel.The location is great. The shopping center next door has everything. Ala Moana park is not anywhere close to being crowded, unlike the main beach a Waikiki. If you really need to, Waikiki beach is within walking distance. Honolulu has a good bus system, and nearly every route connects at the shopping center. Makes it very easy to live without a rental car.We only had the buffet breakfast at the hotel. I thought it was better quality than a typical buffet, and the staff was very attentive.
A ideal hotel for a getaway. Quiet, contemporary design, excellent staff. You can enjoy the location being central to everything but not feel you are overcrowded by other hotels.

Wonderful Aloha service at checkin, Front Desk agent Jean was very accomodating and upgraded to ocean view suite. The hotel was obviously not full and the larger, nicer room was appreciated. The fitness center is one of the best I've seen in any hotel.

Perfectly serviceable hotel for my needs (work). I cannot imagine staying here on vacation, but then again, I'm not into Waikiki Resortland so I wouldn't want to stay anywhere in the vicinity. Big plus is its location - it's fairly easy access to H1 and just around the corner from Ala Moana/Nimitz. For those who need to be near a mall, Ala Moana mall is right next door and is accessible through a second floor bridge. It's easy to get to Ala Moana park, too.The room is clean and contemporary, but teeny tiny. The bed linens are "sanitized" according to a little sign under the glass top of the bedside table - yeah, I wasn't too worried in a place like this (or am I just being naive?). The bathroom is also quite small but clean. I did have to request a change of the shower curtain liner, as the first one just reeked of mildew and I couldn't take it any more. Oh, and the rooms aren't Wifi, which I *hate.* The lobby is apparently wired for it, but I just don't see the point.The pool area is pleasant, although traffic noise is inescapable. Liked the workout room. There's a club (???) in the lobby that I did not even begin to think to check out. Ditto the restaurants. All of the staff were perfectly friendly and responsive.I'd stay here again for business, but never for vacation.

You won't confuse this hotel for a Hyatt or Hilton, but it's a great value for being pretty much right in the middle of Honolulu. The staff is friendly and the location is pretty great. It's also a lot better than many of the shady non-resort places in Waikiki.Good: It's a great value, and is "attached" (sort of) to an enormous shopping and dining complex. There's trolley service to Waikiki for $2 each way, which beats the pants off trying to find parking. Ala Moana Beach Park is right across the street.Our room was pretty well equipped, and came with a refrigerator and microwave. Parking is $15 a night (as of September 2008) in the hotel garage - lower than most places in town.Bad: The parking garage that connects the hotel to the shopping mall can be kind of shady at night. My wife and I were approach by vagrants several times.The walk to Waikiki is a little bit longer than it looks on a map - it was about a 30 minute walk for two reasonably in-shape people. But, if you aren't absolutely set on staying in Waikiki it's not that big a deal and (as above) there is a trolley service.Pool is tiny with not much shade. The rooms (at least in the Kona tower) are also a little on the small side. They're fine for two people but any more than that would probably begin to get uncomfortable.No room in the hotel has a really stunning view (the main tower faces the road), so get whatever's cheapest.

We stayed at this hotel for only one night and had a pleasant stay. The hotel room was nicely appointed (note: the room was small, but that didn't detract from the stay); the hotel has been renovated nicely. It's in a great location for shopping-- within walking distance to the Ala Moana Shopping Center. It's also easily accessible from the airport. Parking costs extra. The fitness center was nice and had plenty of workout options (aerobic machines and weights). There's also a really nice pool. Customer service was quite good at this hotel. We would stay here again.

Bad Beds!!!/ Pretty hotel with nice elevators that worked, the view was great from the 16th floor. BUT>>>the rooms were small and the beds were harder than in the stone age! I have stayed in rooms in 3rd world countries for $50 a night that had much nicer and newer mattresses. These must have been from the 70's!the Mgt. was called and housekeeping brought another mattress pad. wow!!I had to take off the bedspread double it and put it under the pad. still not much better, all for $175. a night I will not stay here again. Aqua Equus down the street has much nicer rooms with new pillowtop mattresses and flatscreen TVS, for under $100 a night if you need to be by the Marina.

I go to Honolulu each year to present workshops, so I'm not a typical tourist. Ala Moana caught my eye because it offered WiFi, had some in-room facilities such as microwave and fridge, and was very close to the convention center.The facility was clean and quiet, but with limited amenities in terms of regular restaurant hours, bar hours and so on. This inconsistency is difficult for a person who is working and comes back to the room tired and wanting something more substantial than a microwaved meal.The Ala Moana shopping mall is right next door, which does offer a lot of restaurants and the like, but it's still a walk, and the hours are limited as well. The neighborhood behind Ala Moana is a mix of storefront restaurants, adult entertainment venues, and just not all that savory, particularly for families or women on their own.The location is what will upset most people that visit Ala Moana, particularly if they're expecting to be on the beach. There's a lovely pool, and I had a great lanai with an impressive view. The WiFi worked fine, and most of the staff was very friendly and as helpful as they could be despite the limited amenities.

My husband was in Honolulu for work and was advised to stay here by a coworker. I joined him at the end of his stay here (three nights). The room was very nice and the lanai was wonderful. Location was excellent - close to shopping and dining. The tour desk was always willing to help when looking for places to eat and how to get to destinations (Dole Plantation). The pool area is beautiful and we were lucky enough to have a room that faced the ocean - a definite bonus once you look past the Macy's parking lot. Free internet was good (reasonably high speed - about 100K/s at night) and parking was convenient (prepaid was $12/day parkade - up to $32/day if you just pay as you visit). When husband arrived, he had two double room and requested a change to king, which they accomodated. He thought it was a larger, nicer room for the same price! Overall, would recommend. We debated changing hotels (as we'd already booked at another location for our vacation time) since we liked this one so much.

Since this is the second time I stayed there, I was able to compare it to what it was like in 1999. It has been completely renovated. It's very modern and clean. I was lucky to have a partial view of the Ala Moana Park. There is a refrigerator in every room, which was convenient for my 5 day stay to help out with our sister office in Honolulu. It's a walk distance to the famous Ala Moana mall, which is a convenient place to catch the bus to the business area and Waikiki. The people in the hotel are very friendly. The few times I went to look for the concierge, he was nowhere to be found.I saw the small swimming pool but did not arrive there during its open hours. For someone who did not bring my computer, I was surprised that they did not have any free computers to do some basic things such as confirm airplane seating.

The hotel is convenient located close to Convention Center, but the area is not nice. The only nice place are the Hard Rock Cafe' and a huge mall on the opposite corner.The hotel is also far from Waikiki, and a little overpriced. Our room was very little and noisy. But clean.Also, they charge your car $15 per night for parking.We don't think we come there again. Maybe you can find better.

Make no mistake, this hotel is designed for business travellers, not tourists looking for a beach location.The room was clean and quiet, the bed was comfortable, the internet connection worked, and the staff was professional. No surprises at this location. Parking was $18 (slightly higher than a Waikiki hotel I stayed at on the same trip). There was a laundry facility but I didn't use it. The hotel is about 5-8 minutes on foot to the shopping mall, depending on how fast you walk.Getting to the main part of Waikiki requires transportation, especially if you are carrying gear. There is a beach within walking distance but it's not as nice.If you're looking for a tourist centric hotel, with a short walk to the beach and a fawning staff, you're not going to find it here. But you can be certain that the rooms will be clean, the air conditioning will work, and there won't be a mildew smell (which many Waikiki hotels have).Discounted rates are very reasonable.

had a bad experience the last time i stayed there and will never stay there again..if you're there on business and paying a very low rate it might be worth it..no'aloha' spirit here..and if you're thinking of renting a condo there its a real waste and ripoff...hotel does not deserve a 3 star rating
My wife and I stayed here after we got married in Hawaii. The service, room standards and quality were excellent. The rooms were newly renovated. We'd definitely stay again!

After a long flight from Pennsylvania to Hawaii, we were pleased with the quality of this hotel. Free Internet service in the rooms was a huge plus as we were able to tell family & friends that we made it safely. Nice pool. Large, clean room. Excellent service. Hotel stored our bags for the day (for a fee of course) and had no trouble finding htem once we returned. Cabs readily available. Reception gave good directions for taking bus to see Pearl Harbor.

My girlfriend and I checked into the Ala Moana on July 3rd to July 8th. We stayed in a condo in the Waikiki Tower.When we checked in there was a long line but the desk clerk was very friendly. We were able to check in early which we were very happy about. Our hotel room was clean with two queen beds, microwave, and refrigerator. The bathroom was clean too. There was also a small balcony with two chairs and a table. Our view was partially obscured by other large buildings but we weren't in our room much to mind.The location of the hotel was what we really enjoyed. If you want to stay in the heart of Waikiki..then don't stay here. But it's only a short bus/taxi ride away. It was nice not to be knee deep in tourists and the beach at Ala Moana Park across the street was a 3-4 minute walk. A lot of locals checked into the hotel on the 4th because it is so close to where the fireworks would be. We probably could have watched the fireworks from our room, but we chose to hang with the locals and enjoy the show up close. The fireworks were breathtaking and was 20 minutes long. (We've seen the fireworks in Sydney as well..and it gave them a run for their money.)The staff at the hotel was EXTREMELY friendly and knowledgeable. Everyone from the parking attendants, to the bell desk, to the concierge (who printed directions for us) made us feel welcome. My mom sent us some goodies through room service and the hotel even followed up and called my mom to let her know they had been sent.One sort of cheesy thing was the club downstairs ("Rumors") seemed to have a "Sweet 16" party of some sort every night. Definitely a non-issue for us but may not be something someone wishes to encounter when relaxing on vacation.On the plus side, the hotel is adjacent to a FANTASTIC shopping center which has EVERYTHING. So finding food or picking up those random things you forgot is not a problem.While we didn't check out the pool from our balcony view we could see it was always pretty packed.Overall, we were extremely pleased with our stay and would consider staying there again.

We stayed here for a night before a wedding that we were attending in the northern part of the island. It was fine for what it was. Check-in also took a long time - there were only two people working at the reception (though there were spaces for 8) but it went smoothly once we got to the front. The rooms were very small - barely enough room for us to lay our suitcases down and to still be able to walk around the room. This meant it was also crowded when we were trying to get ready in the morning. We also booked a "mountain-view" which we were barely able to see through the other hotels that bordered ours. On a happier note, the sheets/bed were very comfortable and its location next to the Ala Moana mall was greatly appreciated when we arrived and were very hungry!! It was late so not much else was open, but we did enjoy a great meal at one of the mall restaurants. The cost of the breakfast buffet was a bit outrageous. Be warned - its $16.99 per person. This is not posted anywhere so make sure you are willing to spend this much before you sit down! We found out the hard way. Since parking was $15 for 24 hours, who would have guessed that it was more than that for one of us to eat? Yikes!

While on our trip in Oahu, my family and I had a good stay at this hotel so we thought...But, when we arrived home I received a $600 charge on my credit card. When I contacted the hotel about the charge, the assistant manager said that the carpet in the room we stayed in was damaged with cigarette burns, which is bizarre since none of us smoke. When I spoke to the General Manager later that day, he told me that he did not know what the burns were from but were large scorch marks...so now I have been told two different things. I had him email me the pictures, which showed four small round stains that my children remembered seeing when we arrived and thought were dirt marks. We can't believe that they are charging us $600 for their dirty carpets. BEWARE!!!! Have a hotel employee do a walk through when you check in so you are not slapped with a bogus charge. We're never staying there again.

– We stayed at the Ala Moana for our two nights in Honolulu because my first night there was already paid for by the university and it seemed like a lot of trouble to change hotels for just one night. In retrospect, I can’t decide if I’m sorry about that or not. We found the hotel to be adequate overall, but it’s certainly nothing we would have chosen for ourselves. The location next to the Ala Moana Shopping Center is ideal for those who want to shop, and it was about a 15 minute amble to the water’s edge of the Ala Moana Park. Our room, #757 in the Kona Tower, was tiny but nicely appointed with a queen bed, pull-out sofa, and a flat screen TV which we never turned on. Our immediate view was of the parking garage for the mall, with the marina and then the ocean beyond that. There was a sliding glass door but no balcony—excuse me, lanai—to speak of. The temperature control was an old-fashioned variety so that the fan could be hot or cold, on or off, and it was always humid in the room. We either froze with the fan on all night or suffocated with it off. By the time we checked out any clothing that had been left out in the room was noticeably damp. The complimentary high-speed internet was a joke. The one time we were able to get a connection, it took entire minutes to load the homepage. We waited so long for our email to download that we left it while we went to dinner but the connection timed out before we returned. Wi-Fi was available, but for a charge! In a business/convention hotel! Based on the rate we paid our last night, $149/night plus taxes, I’d say this place was an okay value.

We found a 2 bedroom condo high atop the Ala Moana and spent a week there last month. Since we stayed in a condo this review will be on the Hotel itself not the rooms.Our main purpose in going to Hawaii was fun on the beach & in the ocean.If that's your purpose this is NOT the best hotel for you. The beach at ALA Moana Park is QUITE a hike & then there are very few waves. It was too calm for us. We ended up taking a cab down to Waikiki when we were ready to swim each day.It is connected to the Ala Moana mall which made shopping & eating very convenient. The staff at the hotel was very friendly. The elevators seemed to move fairly quickly so there was never much of a wait for one. Looks like they have done a recent renovation there so the lobby & hallways appeared nice not worn at all.So bottom line if you are there for meetings at the Convention Center this hotel should do you just fine. If you are interested in fun in the sun or nightlife move on down to Waikiki.

Great hotel recently refurbished in Waikiki Tower. We were upgraded to a junior suite which was very swish. This was a privately owned condo the hotel sells off and rents.It had a big kitchen but no pots/pans//cutlery to use so assume this was all in a locked cabinet. For two nights we did not need them anyway.Great view of city lights at night and water/marina in the day. Very quiet at nigt due to good soundproofing.King bed was loveley and we had 2 balconies. Right next door to Ala Moana shopping centre with access via the hotel that was convenient. Also close to Ward centre and other shops around if you are prepared to walk. great hotel would stay again

I wasn't a huge fan of this place. Late at night, when I checked in, the lobby was horrendously lit with fluorescent lights and bad music was blaring from the nightclub just off reception...it was a pretty disconcerting way to be greeted after travelling for 12 hours. As well, the people I dealt with when I checked in were completely vacant and focused more on each other than on dealing with me...very bizarre...and when I went back down with all my stuff because the key wasn't working, they didn't say anything to me, but just joked to one another, "I've been having some trouble making keys today." No "sorry about that" or anything. I don't much care about stuff like this, usually, but I was pretty irritated.I found it little dingy, in parts - the carpets in the hallway and the room are really stained, as was the little loveseat in my room. Pretty gross. Otherwise, the room was fine. Functional. What I found strange was the lack of amenities for such an enormous hotel. There was not a crumb of food to be found when I arrived there at 11pm on a Sunday night. I hadn't eaten for way too long, and was starving - but was directed to the 7-11. Weird. I also find it odd that in such a large hotel, there's no coffee/pastries place...there's nowhere to go to just grab a quick coffee/tea and pastry, for instance - you have to do the whole sit-down breakfast buffet. Overall, I was pretty underwhelmed.

This is probably a great hotel for business and wonderful if you're a shopper but this is not a great family hotel. We were visiting family and they selected the hotel, I would have picked something else. The view out to the city and beach was nice. There are no activities per se at the hotel and the pool is just a regular roof top pool that is not little kid friendly. The proximity to the Ala Moana shopping center is great. It is near Ala Moana beach park (which is a great and very calm beach) but it is about a 15 minute walk over there. The service was slow at times and snappy at others. Between the king bed, fold out couch and crib we were very cramped. The vanity is in the bathroom itself (which is a bit small) so showering and getting everyone ready at the same time was a challenge. While the hotel was recently renovated and very modern the a/c unit was one of the old fashioned kind where it is either freezing or off. Plus, there is no comforter (just a very, very thin coverlet) so between 2 sheets and a light blanket it was at times uncomfortable. There is a fridge but we were missing the microwave. The hotel was a bit hit or miss. The location can't be beat for business travelers or ardent shoppers but it just wasn't the hotel for us.

As a native of Hawaii ...I hate to report what awful accomodations this hotel has... not to mention their lack of aloha or simple customer service..This room was like staying in a dorm..the video on the website viewing the room is a joke and thank goodness we were only staying there for one night ..I can't imagine where real travelers would put their luggage or anything they bought during their stay. It makes me laugh when people in the business of providing service don't have any and then when their company closes or they lose their jobs they don't think its their fault....Outrigger management should re-evaluate the purchase of this property...Highly not recommended

The hotel lobby and staff are above average. Stayed one night and toilet backed up at 2AM (without using it). Plumber responded quickly, but couldn't fix it. Had to change rooms at 2AM. Stayed another week at different time and room cleaning was missed one day. Called customer service and was told he would call back after talking to the General Manager. I am still waiting for the phone call.There are two restaurants in the hotel a Chinese and a Japanese. They also have a limited breakfast buffet that is horribly overpriced. No where to get a cup of coffee or a sandwich. It is about a 15 minute walk to the Alamona Center where there is everything including a food court with many, many choices.I would think that a hotel of this size should have more eating choices. Oh, no room service, period.

It's a couple blocks inland, but within 15-20 minute walking distance to all the action at Waikiki beach if you're looking for a Hawaii vacation without all the hotel cost, and don't mind a small hike. The rooms are clean and modern, although a little small. It's also next to a large mall. I had no complaints, I enjoyed my stay and the staff were helpful.

We travelled from Barcelona, Spain with my husband and our 5-years-old daugter , and we stayed in a condo rented via www.rbo.com, our very confortable condo(great bed and matress), full kitchen, lovely livingroom Breakfast at Plantation cafe was not too much good but the staff was very kind. We had dinner at Aaron's Top on the 34 th floor and it was not too much expensive, and it was the only meal I really enjoyed in 21 days...(I missed a lot Spanish food, salads, more vegetables, ). On the 13th floor there is a laundrette, very convenient for a long trip if you don't want travel with lots of suitcases.....If a return to Hawaii some day I'll stay again in Ala Moana Hotel.
